  <example>Given N total items and a fraction f, the count of the subset is N × f.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute the total of a repeated quantity by multiplying the count by the per-item value. This yields the aggregate measure for the group.</description>
  <example>If there are C items each with value v, the total is C × v.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the complement rule to find the count of the remaining subset: total minus the known subset. This is useful when one subset is given and the other is implied.</description>
  <example>For N total items and A items in subset A, the count of the other subset is N – A.</example>
</note5>
5. <description>Verify results by checking that all parts sum to the total and that no rounding errors occurred. This ensures consistency and accuracy.</description>
  <example>After finding counts A and B, confirm A + B = N and that any decimal conversions were handled correctly.</example>
Break the fence into its four sides, compute each side’s length, multiply by the slats per foot, then sum.

1. <note1>
  <description>When adding or subtracting decimals, align the decimal points vertically and perform column addition or subtraction, carrying or borrowing as needed. This ensures each place value is correctly combined.</description>
  <example>To compute 2.75 + 3.25, write them as
  2.75
+ 3.25
———
  6.00
</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify repeated multiplication: a·b + a·c = a·(b + c). This reduces the number of operations and can make mental math easier.</description>
  <example>For 5·4 + 5·6, factor out 5: 5·(4 + 6) = 5·10 = 50.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When subtracting a sum from a total, subtract each term sequentially or combine them first. Either way, the result is the same, but combining terms can reduce steps.</description>
  <example>From 100 subtract (20 + 30): you can do 100 − 20 = 80, then 80 − 30 = 50, or combine: 100 − 50 = 50.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always verify your result by performing the inverse operation. For subtraction, add the result back to the amount subtracted; for addition, subtract one addend from the sum.</description>
  <example>If you found 50 after subtracting 30 from 80, check by 50 + 30 = 80, confirming correctness.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Keep track of units and context throughout calculations. Labeling each amount (e.g., dollars, tickets) prevents mixing up values and ensures the final answer is meaningful.</description>
  <example>When subtracting $30 from $80, note both are in dollars, so the result $50 is also in dollars.</example>
</note6>

category: Counting and Summation
 <note1>
  <description>Use the multiplication principle: when each of n₁ items has a₁ attributes and each of n₂ items has a₂ attributes, the total attributes = n₁·a₁ + n₂·a₂. This applies whenever you have distinct groups with uniform counts per group.</description>
  <example>Suppose there are 5 boxes each containing 4 red balls and 7 boxes each containing 6 blue balls. Total balls = 5·4 + 7·6 = 20 + 42 = 62.</example>
</note1>
 <note2>
  <description>When adding multiple products, group like terms: (n₁·a₁) + (n₂·a₂) + … = Σ (nᵢ·aᵢ). This simplifies the expression and makes it easier to spot cancellations or common factors.</description>
  <example>For 3 groups with counts 2, 5, and 4 and attributes 3, 2, and 5 respectively, total = 2·3 + 5·2 + 4·5 = 6 + 10 + 20 = 36.</example>
</note2>
 <note3>
  <description>Check for special cases or outliers: if one group has a different attribute count, handle it separately. This prevents mixing up the uniform groups with the unique case.</description>
  <example>In a collection of 10 shapes, 9 are triangles (3 sides) and 1 is a pentagon (5 sides). Total sides = 9·3 + 1·5 = 27 + 5 = 32.</example>
</note3>
 <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to factor common multipliers: n₁·a₁ + n₂·a₁ = (n₁ + n₂)·a₁. This can simplify calculations when multiple groups share the same attribute count.</description>
  <example>For 4 groups of 7 items each and 6 groups of 7 items each, total items = (4 + 6)·7 = 10·7 = 70.</example>
</note4>
 <note5>
  <description>Verify by reverse engineering: if you know the total and one group’s contribution, subtract to find the other group’s total. This helps catch arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>If total items are 50 and one group contributes 20, then the other group must contribute 50 – 20 = 30. You can then check that 20 + 30 = 50.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
    <description>When multiple agents work together at constant speeds, the total work done is the sum of each agent’s contribution. In uniform motion, work = speed × time, so combined work = (sum of speeds) × time.</description>
    <example>Two cyclists ride at speeds v₁ and v₂ on a track. If they start together and finish at the same time, the total distance covered is (v₁ + v₂) × t, where t is the time taken.</example>
  </note2>
  <note2>
    <description>For a fixed total work, if the number of agents increases, each agent’s share of the work decreases proportionally. Thus, time per agent scales inversely with the number of agents.</description>
    <example>If three workers complete a job in T hours, then each worker’s share is T/3. If you double the workers to six, each worker’s share becomes T/6, so the total time remains T (assuming identical efficiency).</example>
  </note3>
  <note3>
    <description>When agents’ speeds are scaled by a factor k, their time to complete the same work is scaled by 1/k. This follows from work = speed × time, so time = work/speed.</description>
    <example>Two machines each produce at speed v. If a third machine of speed v/2 is added, the total speed becomes 2.5v, so the time to produce the same batch is (1/2.5) times the original time.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure speed, time, and distance (or work) units match. A mismatch can lead to incorrect scaling or arithmetic errors.</description>
    <example>If speed is given in km/h and time in minutes, convert time to hours before computing distance = speed × time, or convert speed to km/min if time is in minutes.</example>
  </note6>
  <note6>
    <description>Use the inverse proportionality between speed and time: if speed doubles, time halves; if speed triples, time reduces to one-third. This principle simplifies many uniform-motion problems.</description>
    <example>A car travels at 60 km/h and takes 2 hours to cover a distance. If its speed increases to 120 km/h, the time becomes 1 hour, since time ∝ 1/speed.</example>

Define variables for each unknown age (e.g. R for Ruby, S for Sam).
Set up two linear equations based on the given relationships (e.g. R = 6S, R + 9 = 3(S + 9)).
Solve the system by substitution or elimination to find the present ages.
Check that the solution satisfies both original conditions and that ages are positive integers.
Use a consistency check: ensure the future ratio matches the stated multiplier.

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a fixed multiple of another, express it as a scalar times the other variable. This captures proportional relationships succinctly.</description>
  <example>Let A be twice B. Then write A = 2·B. If B = 5, then A = 2·5 = 10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When one quantity exceeds another by a constant, model it as the smaller plus that constant. This handles “more than” or “less than” statements directly.</description>
  <example>Suppose C is 7 more than D. Then write C = D + 7. If D = 3, then C = 3 + 7 = 10.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Translate each verbal relationship into an algebraic equation. This systematic step ensures all conditions are captured before solving.</description>
  <example>Given “A is twice B” and “B is 5 more than C,” write A = 2·B and B = C + 5. These two equations fully represent the problem.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Substitute one equation into another to reduce the number of variables. This elimination technique simplifies multi-variable systems.</description>
  <example>From B = C + 5 and A = 2·B, substitute B into A: A = 2·(C + 5). If C = 4, then A = 2·(4 + 5) = 18.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>After finding individual values, sum them to get the total. Always verify that each variable satisfies its original equation.</description>
  <example>If A = 18, B = 9, and C = 4, then total = A + B + C = 18 + 9 + 4 = 31. Check A = 2·B and B = C + 5 to confirm consistency.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>When items share a common unit cost, express each item’s cost as a multiple of that unit cost. This simplifies calculations by reducing the number of distinct variables.</description>
  <example>Suppose one unit costs U. If another item costs twice as much, its cost is 2·U. If a third item costs half as much, its cost is 0.5·U. All costs are then expressed in terms of U, making the total cost straightforward to compute.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Compute the total cost of identical items by multiplying the unit cost by the quantity. This leverages the distributive property to avoid repetitive addition.</description>
  <example>For Q items each costing C, the total is Q·C. For instance, if you have 4 items each costing 3·U, the total is 4·(3·U)=12·U.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When combining multiple categories of items, sum their individual totals to get the overall total cost. This step aggregates all contributions into a single expression.</description>
  <example>If you have totals T₁, T₂, and T₃ from three categories, the grand total is T₁+T₂+T₃. For example, if T₁=12·U, T₂=18·U, and T₃=10·U, then the overall cost is 12·U+18·U+10·U=40·U.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Use the budget constraint to form an equation: total cost = budget. This equation can be solved for any unknown variable or used to check feasibility.</description>
  <example>If the total cost is 40·U and the budget is B, set 40·U = B. If B is known, solve for U; if U is known, verify that 40·U ≤ B.</example>
</note6>
<note7>
  <description>After finding the total cost, compute the remaining budget by subtracting the total cost from the initial budget. This gives the leftover amount.</description>
  <example>If the initial budget is B and the total cost is T, then the remaining budget is B−T. For instance, if B=65 and T=40·U, then remaining = 65−(40·U).</example>
</note7>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the distributive property to multiply a sum by a constant: a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c. This simplifies expressions with multiple terms.</description>
  <example>Compute 5·(3 + 7) by writing 5·3 + 5·7 = 15 + 35 = 50.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When adding several products, group like terms by unit price: sum = (quantity₁·price₁) + (quantity₂·price₂) + … . This organizes the calculation and reduces errors.</description>
  <example>For 2 items at $3 and 3 items at $5, sum = 2·3 + 3·5 = 6 + 15 = 21.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Convert decimals to fractions or vice versa to simplify multiplication: e.g., 1.5 = 3/2. This can make arithmetic with whole numbers easier.</description>
  <example>Multiply 4·1.5 by rewriting 1.5 as 3/2: 4·(3/2) = 12/2 = 6.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the commutative and associative properties to reorder and regroup terms: a + b + c = b + a + c, and (a + b) + c = a + (b + c). This can reveal simpler groupings.</description>
  <example>Compute 2 + 5 + 3 + 4 by grouping as (2 + 3) + (5 + 4) = 5 + 9 = 14.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify by re-adding or re-multiplying in a different order. This check catches arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding 2·3 + 4·5 = 6 + 20 = 26, recompute 4·5 + 2·3 = 20 + 6 = 26 to confirm.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Model the total weight as a linear function: Total = BaseWeight + (Number of Items × ItemWeight). This captures the relationship between the number of items and the overall load.</description>
  <example>For a truck with base weight B and each box weighing w, the total weight is T = B + n·w, where n is the number of boxes.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Set up the inequality Total ≤ Capacity to ensure the load does not exceed the limit. This translates the problem’s constraint into a solvable inequality.</description>
  <example>Using T = B + n·w and a capacity C, write B + n·w ≤ C to find the maximum n.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Isolate the variable by subtracting the base weight and dividing by the item weight: n ≤ (Capacity – BaseWeight) / ItemWeight. This yields the maximum integer number of items.</description>
  <example>From B + n·w ≤ C, subtract B to get n·w ≤ C – B, then divide by w to get n ≤ (C – B)/w.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Apply the floor function to n = (C – B)/w to get the largest integer ≤ (C – B)/w. This ensures the computed n is an integer and does not exceed the capacity.</description>
  <example>If (C – B)/w = 12.3, then n = ⌊12.3⌋ = 12, so 12 boxes can be loaded.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify by substituting back: compute Total = B + n·w and confirm it ≤ C. This check guards against arithmetic or rounding errors.</description>
  <example>With n = 12, check T = B + 12·w ≤ C; if T = 5000 and C = 5000, the load is exactly at the limit.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert units by multiplying the quantity in the smaller unit by the conversion factor to get the larger unit. This works because the conversion factor is the ratio of the two units.</description>
  <example>Convert 12 cups to gallons using 16 cups per gallon: 12 cups × (1 gallon/16 cups) = 0.75 gallons.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use dimensional analysis to track units through each step. Multiply by factors that cancel unwanted units, ensuring the final result has the desired unit.</description>
  <example>Find cups per day then per month: (8 cups/day) × (30 days/month) = 240 cups/month, where days cancel and you end with cups.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When dealing with repeated daily amounts over a period, multiply the daily rate by the number of days. This linear scaling applies whenever a constant rate is applied over time.</description>
  <example>If a machine produces 5 widgets per hour and runs for 8 hours, total widgets = 5 × 8 = 40.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the final unit matches the problem’s requirement. If it doesn’t, reapply the appropriate conversion factor.</description>
  <example>After finding 240 cups over 30 days, confirm the result is in gallons by dividing by 16: 240/16 = 15 gallons.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of rounding intermediate results. Keep full precision until the final step to avoid cumulative errors in multi-step conversions.</description>
  <example>When converting 12.5 cups to gallons, compute 12.5/16 = 0.78125 gallons exactly, rather than rounding 12.5 to 13 cups first.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute the daily increase in power consumption by adding the new gadget’s rate to the existing rate. This gives the total power used each day after installation.</description>
  <example>Original rate: R₁. New gadget rate: R₂. Total daily rate = R₁ + R₂.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert daily power usage into weekly usage by multiplying the daily rate by the number of days in a week. This scales the daily increase to a weekly figure.</description>
  <example>Daily rate: P. Number of days: D. Weekly usage = P × D.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Calculate the cost increase by multiplying the weekly power usage by the cost per kilowatt-hour. This yields the total extra expense for the week.</description>
  <example>Weekly usage: W. Cost per kWh: C. Cost increase = W × C.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use unit consistency: ensure all rates and costs are in the same units (e.g., kWh, dollars) before multiplication. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>Check that P is in kWh/day and C is in dollars/kWh. If not, convert P to kWh/day or C to dollars/kWh.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by comparing the computed increase to the expected range. If the result is too small or too large, re-examine the units and arithmetic.</description>
  <example>Estimate a rough increase: (R₂ × C) × D. Compare to the computed value to verify plausibility.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert time spans into a common unit (e.g., minutes) by multiplying hours by 60 and adding minutes. This ensures all durations are comparable before further calculations.</description>
  <example>For a job lasting 2 hours and 15 minutes, compute 2×60 + 15 = 135 minutes. Use 135 minutes in subsequent steps.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Subtract any breaks or pauses from the total time to get the actual working duration. This adjustment prevents overestimating earnings or progress.</description>
  <example>If total time is 135 minutes and a break of 30 minutes is taken, then working time = 135 – 30 = 105 minutes.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the unit-rate formula: total amount = (working time ÷ rate interval) × rate per interval. This scales the rate to the actual time worked.</description>
  <example>With a rate of $5 every 10 minutes and 105 minutes worked, compute (105 ÷ 10) × 5 = 10.5 × 5 = $52.50.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for integer or fractional results by verifying that the division of time by the rate interval yields a whole number or a simple fraction. This helps catch rounding or miscounting errors.</description>
  <example>Since 105 ÷ 10 = 10.5, confirm that the rate interval divides evenly or that the rate is adjusted accordingly to avoid fractional units.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by estimating the result with simpler numbers or by reversing the calculation. This ensures the final answer is reasonable given the context.</description>
  <example>Estimate 100 minutes at $5 every 10 minutes gives about 10 × 5 = $50. Since 105 minutes is slightly more, the result of $52.50 is plausible.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the basic distance–rate–time relation: time = distance ÷ speed. This formula applies whenever an object moves at constant speed.</description>
  <example>For a trip of D units at speed v, the time is T = D/v. For instance, if D = 10 and v = 5, then T = 10/5 = 2.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a journey is interrupted or split into segments, compute each segment’s time separately and then sum them. This ensures you account for all parts of the trip.</description>
  <example>If a route is split into two equal parts of length D/2 at speed v, each part takes (D/2)/v, so total time = 2·(D/2)/v = D/v.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Halfway points often simplify calculations: distance to halfway = D/2, so time to halfway = (D/2)/v. This avoids re-deriving the full formula.</description>
  <example>For a total distance D and speed v, halfway time is (D/2)/v. If D = 8 and v = 4, halfway time = (8/2)/4 = 1.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check units consistency: distance must be in the same units as speed. Convert if necessary before applying the formula.</description>
  <example>If distance is given in miles and speed in miles per hour, no conversion is needed. If speed were in km/h, convert miles to km first.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify that speed is constant over the entire segment. If speed varies, use the average speed or integrate over time.</description>
  <example>For constant speed, T = D/v. If speed changes linearly from v₁ to v₂ over distance D, use T = D/( (v₁+v₂)/2 ).</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a percentage larger than another, compute the new value by multiplying the original by (1 + percentage/100). This converts a percentage increase into a direct multiplier.</description>
  <example>For a base amount B, a 20% increase yields B × 1.20. If B = 100, the new amount is 100 × 1.20 = 120.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find the total of multiple groups, sum their individual totals. This applies whenever you have several categories or batches to combine.</description>
  <example>Group A has 50 units, Group B has 75 units, and Group C has 120 units. The combined total is 50 + 75 + 120 = 245 units.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a rate is given per unit per time, multiply the total units by the rate and by the number of time periods to get the total earnings or output.</description>
  <example>If each unit yields $0.50 per day and there are 200 units, then daily earnings are 200 × 0.50 = $100. Over 5 days, earnings = 100 × 5 = $500.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check units and time consistency: ensure the rate matches the time frame (e.g., per day, per week) and that you multiply by the correct number of periods.</description>
  <example>A rate of $0.20 per unit per hour applies to 100 units for 8 hours. Earnings = 100 × 0.20 × 8 = $160. If the rate were per day, you’d multiply by the number of days instead.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a stepwise breakdown: compute intermediate totals (e.g., group totals, adjusted values) before combining them to avoid errors and keep the process clear.</description>
  <example>First find the total units in all groups: sum of A, B, and C. Then compute the total earnings by multiplying that sum by the rate and by the number of collection days.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Use the arithmetic series formula to sum a constant sequence: for n terms with first term a₁ and last term aₙ, the sum is n·(a₁ + aₙ)/2. This applies when the quantity changes by a fixed amount each period.</description>
  <example>Suppose you receive 3 gifts in the first month and 7 gifts in the last month over 5 months. The total is 5·(3 + 7)/2 = 25.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When a quantity increases by a fixed amount each period, model it as an arithmetic progression: aₖ = a₁ + (k–1)d. This helps compute any term or sum of terms without listing all values.</description>
  <example>If you start with 2 items and add 1 each month for 4 months, the sequence is 2, 3, 4, 5. The 4th term is 2 + (4–1)·1 = 5.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Break a multi-year problem into yearly (or period) segments, compute each segment’s total separately, then sum them. This modular approach simplifies complex schedules.</description>
  <example>For a 3-year plan, compute Year 1 total, Year 2 total, and Year 3 total, then add: Total = Year1 + Year2 + Year3.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Use the sum of the first n positive integers formula: 1 + 2 + … + n = n(n + 1)/2. This is useful for counting consecutive monthly purchases or any linearly increasing count.</description>
  <example>To sum purchases of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 items over 5 months, compute 5·6/2 = 15.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always verify your total by checking edge cases (e.g., first and last periods) and by re-deriving the sum using a different method (e.g., pairing terms). This guards against arithmetic or conceptual errors.</description>
  <example>If you sum 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, you can pair (4+8), (5+7), 6 = 12+12+6 = 30, matching the direct sum 4+5+6+7+8 = 30.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any fractional remainder into a decimal or percentage to simplify arithmetic. This makes it easier to add or compare parts of a whole.</description>
  <example>For a stick that is 1/4 full, convert 1/4 to 0.25 or 25%. Then if the total length is L, the used portion is 0.25·L, and the unused portion is (1–0.25)·L.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the complement rule: unused portion = 1 – (used fraction). This avoids recalculating the used part separately.</description>
  <example>If a container is 3/5 full, then the unused fraction is 1 – 3/5 = 2/5. Multiply 2/5 by the total capacity to get the unused volume.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When adding multiple fractional parts, first convert them to a common denominator or decimal form, then sum. This ensures accurate total when combining different fractions.</description>
  <example>To add 1/3 and 1/4, convert to twelfths: 4/12 + 3/12 = 7/12. If each represents a portion of a total T, the combined unused portion is 7/12·T.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the sum of all fractional parts (used + unused) equals 1. This verifies no part is lost or double-counted.</description>
  <example>If you have fractions 1/6, 2/3, and 1/2, compute 1/6 + 2/3 + 1/2 = 1/6 + 4/6 + 3/6 = 8/6 = 1 2/6, which exceeds 1. You must re-express or re-check the fractions.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>After finding the total unused fraction, multiply by the original total to get the actual length or volume. This final step converts the abstract fraction into a concrete measure.</description>
  <example>If the unused fraction is 5/12 of a rod of length L, then the unused length is (5/12)·L. For L = 12, this gives 5 units.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentage probabilities to decimal form by dividing by 100. This is essential for accurate multiplication in probability calculations.</description>
  <example>For a 70% chance of an event, use 0.70 in formulas. For a 3% chance, use 0.03.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the complement rule: P(A) = 1 – P(not A). This simplifies finding the probability of an event when its complement is easier to compute.</description>
  <example>If the chance of a defect is 12%, then the chance of no defect is 1 – 0.12 = 0.88.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the multiplication rule for independent events: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B). This gives the joint probability of two independent outcomes.</description>
  <example>If the chance of a defect is 0.15 and the chance of a secondary issue is 0.05, then P(both) = 0.15 × 0.05 = 0.0075.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the binomial distribution to find the expected number of occurrences: E = n × p, where n is the number of trials and p is the probability of success in each trial.</description>
  <example>With 1000 trials and a 0.02 chance of success, the expected successes are 1000 × 0.02 = 20.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check independence assumptions before applying multiplication or binomial formulas. If events are not independent, use conditional probability or other methods.</description>
  <example>If two defects can occur together, assume P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B|A) rather than P(A) × P(B).</example>
</note1>

Breakdown of Rotations per Distance:  
  <note1>  
  <description>  
To find the number of rotations per unit distance, divide the total rotations by the distance in the same units. This gives a constant rotation rate that applies to any segment of the journey.  
</description>  
  <example>  
If a tire completes 725 rotations over 2 miles, then per mile it rotates 725/2 = 362.5 times. For a 5-mile trip, rotations = 362.5 × 5 = 1812.5.  
</example>  
  </note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the additive identity to combine quantities: for any numbers a, b, c, d, the sum (a + b) + (c + d) equals a + b + c + d. This lets you group additions in any order without changing the result.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have a = 5, b = 7, c = 3, d = 4. Compute (5 + 7) + (3 + 4) = 12 + 7 = 19, which matches 5 + 7 + 3 + 4 = 19.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the commutative and associative properties of addition to reorder and regroup terms for easier mental arithmetic. You can swap or group terms to simplify intermediate sums.</description>
  <example>Given 8 + 2 + 7 + 3, reorder as (8 + 2) + (7 + 3) = 10 + 10 = 20, making the calculation straightforward.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the subtraction identity to remove quantities: for any numbers a, b, c, d, the expression a + b + c – d equals a + (b + c – d). This helps isolate the final subtraction step.</description>
  <example>Start with a = 20, b = 5, c = 3, d = 4. Compute 20 + (5 + 3 – 4) = 20 + 4 = 24, matching 20 + 5 + 3 – 4 = 24.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Track sign changes when subtracting: subtracting a positive is the same as adding a negative, and vice versa. This clarifies the net effect of multiple additions and subtractions.</description>
  <example>Compute 15 + 6 – 4 – 2 by rewriting as 15 + 6 + (–4) + (–2) = 15 + 6 – 4 – 2 = 15.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a quick sanity check by estimating or rounding each term to a nearby round number. Compare the estimated result to your exact answer to catch arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>For 12 + 18 – 5 – 3, round to 10 + 20 – 5 – 3 = 22. The exact result 22 matches the estimate, confirming correctness.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentage statements into decimal multipliers by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply by the total to find the count of individuals satisfying the condition.</description>
  <example>“20% of the group” becomes 0.20. If the total is T, then 0.20×T gives the count of those in the first category.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute the complement of a percentage by subtracting from 100% (or 1 in decimal form). This is useful when you need the remaining portion after accounting for one category.</description>
  <example>If 20% are in category A, then 100%–20%=80% (or 0.80) are in the complement. Multiply 0.80×T to find the size of the remaining group.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply successive percentages to a reduced group by multiplying the decimal form of each percentage by the current count. This handles nested percentage statements.</description>
  <example>From the complement of size C, if 60% are in category B, then count_B = 0.60×C. The remaining count is 0.40×C for the next category.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the subtraction method to find the final category: subtract the counts of all previous categories from the total. This ensures you account for all groups without nested multiplication.</description>
  <example>Let T be total, A be count_A, B be count_B. Then count_C = T – (A + B). This directly gives the size of the last category.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all computed counts equals the total. This check catches arithmetic or percentage errors and ensures consistency.</description>
  <example>After finding A, B, and C, confirm A + B + C = T. If they don’t match, re-examine each percentage conversion and multiplication step.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert time units by multiplying by the appropriate factor: minutes to hours multiply by 1/60, hours to minutes multiply by 60. This ensures all time measures are consistent before summing.</description>
  <example>For a session lasting 40 minutes, convert to hours by computing 40 × (1/60) = 2/3 hours. If you have 3 sessions, total time is 3 × (2/3) = 2 hours.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Compute total time for a fixed schedule by multiplying the number of sessions per day by the session duration, then by the number of days. This gives the baseline time before any additional or reduced sessions.</description>
  <example>If a student has 6 sessions of 40 minutes each per day for 5 days, total baseline time is 6 × 40 × 5 = 1200 minutes, or 20 hours.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Account for extra sessions by adding the product of extra sessions per day and session duration, multiplied by the number of days. This adjusts the baseline time to include additional attendance.</description>
  <example>With 2 extra sessions of 40 minutes each per day over 5 days, extra time is 2 × 40 × 5 = 400 minutes, or 6.666… hours, which you add to the baseline.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Handle a fraction of total time by multiplying the total time by the given fraction. This is useful for allocating a portion of overall time to extra activities.</description>
  <example>If the total weekly class time is 20 hours and you need 1/16 of that for studying, compute 20 × (1/16) = 1.25 hours for extra studying.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Sum all components—baseline, extra sessions, and fractional allocations—to get the final total. Always convert to the same unit (e.g., hours) before adding.</description>
  <example>Adding baseline 20 hours, extra 6.666… hours, and extra studying 1.25 hours gives a total of 27.916… hours, which you can round or leave as a fraction as needed.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Translate verbal age statements into algebraic expressions by assigning a variable to the current age and expressing future or past ages as that variable plus or minus the time interval.</description>
  <example>“In 5 years, someone will be twice as old as they are now.” Let x be the current age. Then x + 5 = 2x.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>Set up an equation by equating the algebraic expression for the future age to the desired multiple of the current age, then solve for the variable.</description>
  <example>“In t years, someone will be three times their current age.” Write x + t = 3x, then solve for t.</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>Isolate the variable by collecting like terms and dividing by the coefficient, ensuring you perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.</description>
  <example>From x + t = 3x, subtract x to get t = 2x, then divide if needed to find the unknown.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
  <description>Always check the solution by substituting it back into the original verbal statement to confirm it satisfies the condition.</description>
  <example>After finding t = 2x, verify that x + 2x = 3x holds true, ensuring the interpretation matches the problem.</example>
</note5>
  <note6>
  <description>Be cautious of sign errors when dealing with past ages (subtracting time) or when the multiplier is less than one, as these can lead to negative or non-integer solutions.</description>
  <example>If the problem said “in t years, someone will be half as old,” watch for t = –x, which indicates a past event rather than a future one.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
    <description>When a quantity is described as a fraction of another, represent it as a multiplication: if A is f times B, then A = f × B. This converts verbal relationships into algebraic form.</description>
    <example>Suppose a container holds f times the volume of another. If the second container’s volume is V, then the first container’s volume is f·V.</example>
  </note2>
  <note2>
    <description>Chain multiple fractional relationships by multiplying successive factors: if A = f₁·B and B = f₂·C, then A = f₁·f₂·C. This avoids intermediate steps.</description>
    <example>Given A is f₁ times B, and B is f₂ times C, compute A directly as f₁·f₂·C without finding B explicitly.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Use the reciprocal to reverse a fraction: if a quantity is f times another, then the other is 1/f of that quantity. This is useful for undoing scaling.</description>
    <example>If X is f times Y, then Y = (1/f)·X. For instance, if Y is half of X, then Y = (1/2)·X.</example>
  </note5>
  <note6>
    <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all quantities share the same unit before multiplying or dividing. This prevents unit mismatches in calculations.</description>
    <example>When computing volumes, confirm both volumes are in cubic units before applying any fraction or multiplication.</example>
  </note7>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total demand by summing individual weekly orders. This gives the overall requirement before any supply adjustments.</description>
  <example>Suppose three customers order 10, 15, and 20 units weekly. Total demand = 10 + 15 + 20 = 45 units per week.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Find weekly shortfall by subtracting supply from total demand. This identifies how many units are needed each week.</description>
  <example>With supply of 40 units and total demand of 45 units, shortfall = 45 – 40 = 5 units per week.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Convert weekly shortfall to monthly shortfall by multiplying by the number of weeks in a month. This scales the weekly gap to a monthly basis.</description>
  <example>If the weekly shortfall is 5 units and there are 4 weeks in a month, monthly shortfall = 5 × 4 = 20 units.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the formula: Monthly shortfall = (Total demand – Supply) × Weeks per month. This combines demand, supply, and time into one expression.</description>
  <example>Given demand = 45, supply = 40, and weeks = 4, shortfall = (45 – 40) × 4 = 20.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check for negative results: if supply exceeds demand, the shortfall is zero or negative, indicating surplus. Always verify the sign of the result.</description>
  <example>If supply = 50 and demand = 45, shortfall = 50 – 45 = 5 (positive), but if supply = 45 and demand = 50, shortfall = 45 – 50 = –5 (surplus).</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert all time units to a single base unit (e.g. minutes) before summing. This avoids errors when adding times expressed in different units.</description>
  <example>Suppose a task takes 2 hours and 15 minutes. Convert 2 hours to 120 minutes, then add 15 minutes to get 135 minutes.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>Use the formula Total Time = (Number of Tasks) × (Time per Task). This linear model applies when each task takes the same amount of time.</description>
  <example>If each of 8 tasks takes 15 minutes, then total time = 8 × 15 = 120 minutes.</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>When tasks have different durations, compute each group’s total separately and then sum. This handles mixed workloads.</description>
  <example>Group A has 5 tasks at 10 minutes each (50 minutes) and Group B has 3 tasks at 20 minutes each (60 minutes). Total = 50 + 60 = 110 minutes.</example>
</note3>
  <note4>
  <description>Convert minutes to hours by dividing by 60. This is useful when the final answer is required in hours.</description>
  <example>180 minutes ÷ 60 = 3 hours.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
  <description>Always check for unit consistency and perform a sanity check: ensure the computed total is reasonable given the per-task times and counts.</description>
  <example>If you calculate 200 minutes for 10 tasks at 20 minutes each, verify 10 × 20 = 200 minutes. If it doesn’t match, recheck your multiplication.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total revenue by multiplying the rate per unit by the number of units sold or used. This applies whenever you have a constant price or rate and a known quantity.</description>
  <example>For a service charging $r per unit and sold for n units, revenue = r × n. For instance, if r = $p and n = q, then revenue = p × q.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying the cost per unit by the number of units consumed or produced. This is used when expenses are uniform per unit.</description>
  <example>For a cost of $c per unit and usage of m units, total cost = c × m. For example, if c = $d and m = e, then cost = d × e.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Calculate profit by subtracting total cost from total revenue. This gives the net gain or loss in any transaction or operation.</description>
  <example>Given revenue R and cost C, profit = R − C. For instance, if R = f and C = g, then profit = f − g.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the unit-rate method to find total cost or revenue when you know the cost or rate per unit and the total number of units. This simplifies multi-step calculations.</description>
  <example>If each unit costs c and you have m units, then total cost = c × m. Similarly, if each unit generates r revenue and you have n units, then total revenue = r × n.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify that units are consistent before performing multiplication or subtraction. Mismatched units can lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>Ensure that the rate is in the same unit as the quantity (e.g., dollars per hour with hours). If not, convert units first (e.g., hours to days) before computing.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When two or more agents work at constant rates, their combined rate is the sum of their individual rates. This lets you treat them as a single “super-agent” with a unified rate.</description>
  <example>Agent A works at rate r₁ units/hour, Agent B at r₂ units/hour. Together, they work at (r₁ + r₂) units/hour. If the total work is W, time = W/(r₁ + r₂).</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert “per unit time” rates into “per time” consumption by multiplying the rate by the time interval. This gives the actual amount consumed in that interval.</description>
  <example>If a machine produces r items/minute, then in t minutes it produces r·t items. For instance, at 5 items/minute for 3 minutes, output = 5·3 = 15 items.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When one agent’s rate is a multiple of another’s, express the faster rate as k·(slower rate). This simplifies summing or comparing rates.</description>
  <example>Worker X’s rate is r, Worker Y’s rate is 3r. Combined rate = r + 3r = 4r. If total work is 40r units, time = 40r / (4r) = 10 time units.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the unitary method: find how long it takes one agent to complete the work, then scale by the number of agents. This avoids summing rates directly.</description>
  <example>If one painter takes T hours to paint a wall, two painters take T/2 hours. If one painter paints at rate r, two painters paint at 2r, so time = W/(2r).</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that rates and time units are consistent. Mixing hours and minutes or units and items without conversion leads to errors.</description>
  <example>If a printer’s rate is 10 pages/hour, converting to pages/minute gives 10/60 = 1/6 pages/minute. Then in 15 minutes, output = (1/6)·15 = 2.5 pages.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a fraction of another, express the relationship as “quantity₁ = fraction × quantity₂” and solve for the unknown. This works whenever a part-to-whole or ratio relationship is given.</description>
  <example>Suppose A is 1/3 of B, and A = 4. Then B = 4 ÷ (1/3) = 12.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find the mean of two numbers, add them and divide by 2. This is the arithmetic mean and applies to any pair of values.</description>
  <example>For values X and Y, the mean is (X + Y)/2. If X = 5 and Y = 12, the mean is (5 + 12)/2 = 8.5.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all quantities are in the same unit before performing arithmetic. Mixing units can lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If one length is given in inches and another in feet, convert both to inches (or feet) before adding or averaging.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a problem gives a ratio or fraction, invert the fraction to solve for the whole when the part is known. This is the reciprocal method for “part-to-whole” problems.</description>
  <example>If P is 2/5 of Q and P = 6, then Q = 6 ÷ (2/5) = 6 × (5/2) = 15.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by substituting back into the original relationship. This ensures no algebraic or arithmetic mistakes were made.</description>
  <example>After finding Q = 15 from P = 6 and P = 2/5 Q, check 6 = (2/5) × 15 = 6, confirming correctness.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a fixed multiple of another, express it as k·x. This captures proportional relationships succinctly.</description>
  <example>Suppose one item costs k times another. If the second item costs x, then the first costs k·x.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate verbal “times” or “double” statements into multiplication. Phrases like “double” become ×2, and “half” becomes ÷2.</description>
  <example>“The first cost is double the second” becomes cost₁ = 2·cost₂.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to sum multiple terms: a·x + b·x = (a + b)·x. This consolidates repeated terms into one expression.</description>
  <example>If you have 2·x + 3·x, rewrite as (2 + 3)·x = 5·x.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a total is given and one part is known, find the other part by subtraction: unknown = total – known. This isolates the missing component.</description>
  <example>If the total cost is T and one item costs C, then the remaining cost is T – C.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify by substituting back into the original relationships. This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>After finding x, check that k·x equals the stated multiple and that x + k·x equals the total.</example>
</note5>

Let’s solve the problem by counting rows and stars systematically. Here’s how:

<note1>
  <description>When a total count is partitioned into groups of equal size, the number of groups is the total count divided by the group size. This works whenever each group has the same number of items.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 20 items arranged in groups of 4. The number of groups is 20 ÷ 4 = 5.</example>
</note1>

<note2>
  <description>For groups of different sizes, compute the count of each size separately by dividing the total by the group size (if it divides evenly) or by using subtraction to find the remainder. This handles mixed-size partitions.</description>
  <example>With 20 items, if 4 items form one group and 5 items form another, you get 20 ÷ 4 = 5 groups of 4 and 20 ÷ 5 = 4 groups of 5.</example>
</note3>

<note3>
  <description>After finding counts for some groups, subtract those counts from the total to determine the remaining items. Then divide the remainder by the size of the remaining group to find its count.</description>
  <example>From 20 items, if 5 groups of 4 (20) and 4 groups of 5 (20) are already accounted for, subtract 20 + 20 = 40 from 20 to get 0 remainder, so no other group exists.</example>
</note4>

<note5>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all group counts equals the total. This check ensures no items are left unaccounted for or double-counted.</description>
  <example>If you have 5 groups of 4 and 4 groups of 5, the total is 5×4 + 4×5 = 20 + 20 = 40, which matches the original total.</example>
</note6>

<note7>
  <description>When the total is not divisible by a group size, use integer division to get the whole number of groups and note any remainder for further analysis.</description>
  <example>For 21 items in groups of 4, 21 ÷ 4 = 5 with a remainder of 1, so there are 5 full groups of 4 and 1 leftover item.</example>
</note7>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a percentage increase into a multiplier by adding the percentage to 100% (or 1) and dividing by 100. This gives the factor by which the original quantity is scaled.</description>
  <example>For a 20% increase, compute 1 + 20/100 = 1.20. If the original value is V, the new value is V × 1.20.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a rate changes, multiply the original rate by the increase factor to get the new rate. This directly applies to speed, production rates, or any per-unit measure.</description>
  <example>If a machine’s output rate is R units per hour and it increases by a factor of k, the new rate is R × k units per hour.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute total quantity by multiplying the rate by the time: Q = rate × time. This formula applies whenever you know how much is produced or consumed per unit time.</description>
  <example>If a printer prints at P pages per minute, then in T minutes it prints P × T pages.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the inverse relationship: time = total quantity ÷ rate. This is essential when you know the total amount and the rate but need the time.</description>
  <example>To find how long it takes to print Q pages at P pages per minute, compute time = Q ÷ P minutes.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure rate units match time units (e.g., words per minute, pages per hour) before combining or dividing. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If a rate is given in words per minute but time is in hours, convert time to minutes (or vice versa) before applying the formula.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Model each day’s activity as a vector of counts for each exercise type. This lets you represent daily totals in a structured way and perform algebraic operations on them.</description>
  <example>Day 1: [100, 50, 20]. Day 2: [100+20, 50–10, 2·20] = [120, 40, 40].</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply linear transformations to each component of the vector: add, subtract, multiply, or divide by constants. This captures any fixed change rule for each exercise type.</description>
  <example>For Day 2, pushups = 100+20, squats = 50–10, presses = 2·20, yielding [120, 40, 40].</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Sum the vectors component-wise to get the total across days. This aggregates all counts into one vector for further analysis or reporting.</description>
  <example>Day 1 + Day 2 = [100+120, 50+40, 20+40] = [220, 90, 60].</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Use the dot product of the total vector with the all-ones vector to compute the overall count of all exercises. This is a quick way to sum all components.</description>
  <example>Dot product of [220, 90, 60] with [1, 1, 1] = 220+90+60 = 370.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Check for consistency: ensure each transformation rule is applied uniformly and that no component is overlooked. This prevents arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>Verify that Day 2’s pushups = 100+20, squats = 50–10, presses = 2·20, and then re-sum to confirm totals match expectations.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Identify the total number of items by multiplying the count of groups by the count per group. This applies whenever you have multiple identical sets.</description>
  <example>For 5 boxes each containing 8 pencils, the total pencils = 5 × 8 = 40.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the unit price to find the cost of one item, then multiply by the total number of items. This is the standard cost calculation.</description>
  <example>If each widget costs $3.50 and you need 12 widgets, total cost = 12 × 3.50 = $42.00.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When items come in pairs or groups, first determine the number of groups, then multiply by the cost per group. This avoids handling each item individually.</description>
  <example>For 7 pairs of gloves at $4.00 per pair, total cost = 7 × 4.00 = $28.00.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that units match before multiplying. Convert all quantities to the same unit if necessary to avoid errors.</description>
  <example>If you have 2.5 dozen eggs and each dozen costs $3.00, convert 2.5 dozen to 30 eggs, then multiply by cost per egg if needed, or directly compute 2.5 × 3.00 = $7.50.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a quick sanity check by estimating or using a simpler case. This helps catch arithmetic or unit mistakes.</description>
  <example>For 10 items at $12.00 each, estimate 10 × 10 = $100, then compute 10 × 12 = $120. The estimate is close, confirming the calculation is likely correct.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the complement rule to find the subset of interest: if a fraction p of the total fails, then the fraction that succeeds is 1–p. This works whenever you know the failure rate and need the success rate.</description>
  <example>Suppose 20% of participants fail a test. Then the success rate is 1–0.20=0.80, so 80% pass. If there are 50 participants, 0.80×50=40 pass.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply a percentage to a subset to find its size: multiply the subset’s count by the given percentage (as a decimal). This is used when you know the proportion of a group that meets a criterion.</description>
  <example>Out of 40 students who passed, 60% are female. Then the number of female passers is 0.60×40=24. The remaining 40–24=16 are male.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the complement within a subset to find the other category: if a fraction q of a subset is one type, then the rest (1–q) is the other. This is useful when you know the proportion of one subgroup in a larger subgroup.</description>
  <example>In a group of 30 employees, 40% are managers. Then non-managers make up 60% of 30, so 0.60×30=18 non-managers.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Combine multiple fractions in sequence: if p of the total fail, then (1–p) succeed, and if q of those succeed are one type, then the other type is (1–q)×(1–p). This handles two successive selection steps.</description>
  <example>25% of applicants fail an initial test, so 75% pass. Among those, 30% are women, so men are 70% of 75%, giving 0.70×75=52.5 (round as needed).</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that your fractions and percentages sum to 1 within each stage and that the final counts are nonnegative integers. This ensures consistency and avoids logical errors.</description>
  <example>If 20% fail and 80% pass, then 80% of 80% (women) plus 20% of 80% (men) should sum to 80%. Indeed, 0.20×80=16 and 0.80×80=64, and 16+64=80.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a fraction of another, multiply the base quantity by that fraction to find the smaller quantity. This works because fractions represent parts of a whole.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a container holds 20 liters and you need 3/4 of it, compute 20 × (3/4) = 15 liters.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a total over multiple periods, multiply the per-period amount by the number of periods. This applies whenever a rate is constant over time or other intervals.</description>
  <example>If a machine produces 5 widgets per hour and runs for 8 hours, the total output is 5 × 8 = 40 widgets.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always simplify fractions before multiplication to reduce arithmetic complexity. Simplifying early can prevent large intermediate numbers.</description>
  <example>Instead of computing 12 × (7/4), first simplify 7/4 to 1 3/4, then multiply 12 × 1 3/4 = 12 × 1 + 12 × (3/4) = 12 + 9 = 21.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check unit consistency: ensure the units of the fraction and the base quantity match before multiplying. Mismatched units can lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If you have 100 meters and need 1/2 of it, confirm both are in meters, then compute 100 × (1/2) = 50 meters.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use estimation to verify the plausibility of your result. A rough estimate can catch arithmetic or unit errors before finalizing the answer.</description>
  <example>For 18 × (1/2) × 7, estimate 18 × 0.5 ≈ 9, then 9 × 7 ≈ 63, so the final answer should be around 63.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is increased by a percentage p, multiply the original by (1 + p/100). This converts the percentage increase into a multiplicative factor.</description>
  <example>For an original length L, a 20% increase yields L × 1.20. If L = 10, the new length is 10 × 1.20 = 12.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity is decreased by a percentage p, multiply the original by (1 – p/100). This converts the percentage decrease into a multiplicative factor.</description>
  <example>For an original length L, a 15% decrease yields L × 0.85. If L = 20, the new length is 20 × 0.85 = 17.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>To find the total of two or more quantities, add them directly. Ensure all quantities are in the same unit before summing.</description>
  <example>If one segment is 8 units and another is 12 units, the total is 8 + 12 = 20 units.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that percentage-based calculations use the correct base (original value) and that the final result is in the required unit.</description>
  <example>When increasing 50 by 30%, use 50 × 1.30 = 65, not 50 × 1.30 = 650 if you mistakenly used 500 as the base.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use estimation to verify results: round percentages and values to simple numbers to check that the computed total is reasonable.</description>
  <example>For 40 increased by 25%, estimate 40 × 1.25 ≈ 40 × 1.2 = 48, so a computed total of 48 is plausible.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When multiple quantities are related by a chain of equalities (e.g. A = B, B = C, C = D), you can substitute them to express all variables in terms of one base variable. This reduces the number of unknowns and simplifies the system.</description>
  <example>Suppose A = B, B = C, and C = D. Then A = D. If D is expressed in terms of a parameter t, you immediately know A = t as well.</example>
</note2>
  <description>When one quantity is a fixed multiple of another (e.g. X = k·Y), you can replace X with k·Y in all equations. This turns multiplicative relationships into additive ones, making it easier to combine with other relations.</description>
  <example>If X = 3·Y and you have X + Y = 10, substitute to get 3Y + Y = 10, so 4Y = 10 and Y = 2.5, then X = 7.5.</example>
</note3>
  <description>After expressing all variables in terms of a single parameter, use the total constraint (e.g. sum of all parts equals a constant) to solve for that parameter. This step ties the abstract model back to the real-world total.</description>
  <example>With A = t, B = t, C = 2t, and D = 2t, and total T = A + B + C + D, you get T = t + t + 2t + 2t = 6t. If T = 12, then t = 2.</example>
</note4>
  <description>Always check that the parameter value is positive and that all derived quantities are nonnegative. This ensures the solution makes sense in the context of the problem (e.g. no negative or zero quantities).</description>
  <example>If t = 2, then A = 2, B = 2, C = 4, D = 4, all positive. If t had been negative, you would discard it because negative quantities are not feasible.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Verify your solution by substituting the found values back into all original relationships. This confirms consistency and catches any algebraic mistakes.</description>
  <example>With t = 2, check A = B = 2, C = 2t = 4, D = 2t = 4, and A + B + C + D = 10. Since the sum matches the given total, the solution is correct.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Identify the first term and the common ratio of a geometric sequence. The first term is the cost of the first period, and the common ratio is the factor by which each subsequent period’s cost multiplies the previous one.</description>
  <example>For a sequence where the first period costs C and each next period costs r times the previous, the first term is C and the common ratio is r.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Count the number of terms in the sequence. If the total duration is T hours and the first hour is free, the number of paid periods is T – 1.</description>
  <example>For a total of T hours with one free hour, the number of terms is T – 1, so you sum the first T – 1 terms of the geometric sequence.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the finite geometric series sum formula: S = a·(rⁿ – 1)/(r – 1), where a is the first term, r is the common ratio, and n is the number of terms.</description>
  <example>With first term a, ratio r, and n terms, the sum is a·(rⁿ – 1)/(r – 1), which directly gives the total cost without adding each term individually.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for special cases: if r = 1, the sum is simply a·n; if r = 0, the sum is a (only the first term); if r = –1, the sum is a·(–1)ⁿ if n is odd, or 0 if n is even.</description>
  <example>When r = 1, S = a·n; when r = 0, S = a; when r = –1 and n is odd, S = –a.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify the result by summing the first few terms manually to ensure the formula applies correctly and to catch any off-by-one errors in term counting.</description>
  <example>Compute the first three terms a, a·r, a·r² and add them; compare with a·(r³ – 1)/(r – 1) to confirm consistency.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a monthly rate to an annual rate by multiplying by 12, since there are 12 months in a year. This applies whenever a quantity is given per month and you need it per year.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a service costs $x per month, then the annual cost is 12 × x. If x = 15, the annual cost is 12 × 15 = 180.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the unitary method: first find the cost for one instance, then multiply by the total number of instances. This is useful for any scenario where you know the cost per unit and the total units.</description>
  <example>For example, if one wash costs $y and you do n washes, the total cost is n × y. If y = 15 and n = 48, the total is 48 × 15 = 720.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the distributive property to simplify multiplication: a × (b + c) = a × b + a × c. This can make mental arithmetic easier when dealing with sums inside parentheses.</description>
  <example>For instance, 12 × (40 + 8) = 12 × 40 + 12 × 8 = 480 + 96 = 576. This breaks a complex multiplication into simpler parts.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that your result aligns with a known benchmark or by reversing the calculation. This helps catch arithmetic or unit conversion errors.</description>
  <example>If you calculate annual cost as 180 and know that monthly cost is 15, you can check by dividing 180 by 12 to see if it returns 15. If it does, the calculation is consistent.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use estimation to quickly verify the magnitude of your answer. Round numbers to the nearest convenient value before multiplying to get a rough estimate.</description>
  <example>For example, if you have 48 washes at $15 each, round 48 to 50 and 15 to 15, giving 50 × 15 = 750. Your exact answer (720) should be close to this estimate.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert units by multiplying the quantity by the conversion factor. Use the formula: new_quantity = original_quantity × conversion_factor. This works whenever you need to change one unit to another.</description>
  <example>Convert 5 liters to milliliters by multiplying 5 L × 1000 mL/L = 5000 mL.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total from per-unit values by multiplying the per-unit amount by the number of units. Use: total = per_unit × number_of_units. This applies to any scenario where you know a rate and a count.</description>
  <example>If each widget costs $2 and you buy 7 widgets, total cost = 2 × 7 = $14.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions: a × (b + c) = a × b + a × c. This helps break complex multiplications into simpler parts.</description>
  <example>Compute 4 × (3 + 5) by distributing: 4 × 3 + 4 × 5 = 12 + 20 = 32.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check unit consistency before combining quantities. Ensure all terms share the same unit before addition or subtraction. If not, convert first.</description>
  <example>Adding 2 kg and 500 g: convert 2 kg to 2000 g, then 2000 g + 500 g = 2500 g.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify results by reversing the steps or using an alternative method. This helps catch arithmetic or unit conversion errors.</description>
  <example>If you found total calories = 48, divide by the per-ounce rate (3) to get 16 ounces, then multiply back: 16 × 3 = 48 to confirm.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a percentage increase to a multiplier by adding the percentage (in decimal form) to 1. This gives the factor by which the original quantity is scaled.</description>
  <example>For a 20% increase, compute 1 + 0.20 = 1.20. Multiply the original amount by 1.20 to get the new amount.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the multiplier to the original quantity: new = original × (1 + p/100). This directly yields the increased value without intermediate steps.</description>
  <example>Given original = 50 and p = 20, new = 50 × 1.20 = 60.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the formula for percentage change: change = original × (p/100). Then add this change to the original to get the new total.</description>
  <example>With original = 50 and p = 20, change = 50 × 0.20 = 10, so new = 50 + 10 = 60.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that the new value is greater than the original when p > 0 and less when p < 0. This guards against arithmetic or sign errors.</description>
  <example>Since 20% is positive, 60 > 50, confirming the increase.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always round only at the final step if the context requires whole numbers. Intermediate calculations should remain in decimal form to avoid rounding errors.</description>
  <example>Keep 50 × 1.20 as 60.00 before rounding, then round to 60 if needed.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “k times” another, set up the equation x = k·y. This models a direct proportional relationship between x and y.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a number x is three times another number y, write x = 3·y. This captures the idea that x is exactly three times y.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity changes by a known amount, represent the new value as x + Δ or x – Δ. This accounts for increases or decreases in the original value.</description>
  <example>If a score x increases by 5 points, express the new score as x + 5. This directly models the change in the original value.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine the proportional and change equations into a single linear equation: k·y + Δ = x. Solve for the unknown by isolating it on one side.</description>
  <example>Given x = 3·y and x + 5 = 14, substitute to get 3·y + 5 = 14, then solve 3·y = 9, so y = 3.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check your solution by substituting back into both the proportional and change conditions. This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>After finding y = 3, verify 3·3 + 5 = 14 and that 3·3 = 9, confirming the original conditions hold.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Watch for sign errors when dealing with increases or decreases. A negative Δ indicates a decrease, and a positive Δ indicates an increase.</description>
  <example>If a value decreases by 4, write x – 4; if it increases by 4, write x + 4. Mixing up the sign can lead to incorrect results.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When combining contributions from multiple sources, sum each quantity before further operations. This ensures you account for all items correctly.</description>
  <example>Suppose Person A has a items and Person B has b items. The total is a + b. For instance, if A has 12 units and B has 8 units, the combined total is 20 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into algebraic expressions. Phrases like “more than” or “less than” become addition or subtraction in equations.</description>
  <example>If B contributes c more than A, and A has a, then B’s contribution is a + c. For example, if A has 15 units and B contributes 7 more, B has 22 units.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use division to determine how many complete groups of size k can be formed from a total of T items. The quotient gives the count of full groups.</description>
  <example>With T items and each group requiring k items, the number of groups is T ÷ k. For instance, 30 items divided into groups of 5 yield 6 full groups.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Apply the ceiling function when partial groups are not allowed. If T ÷ k is not an integer, ceil(T ÷ k) gives the minimum number of full groups needed.</description>
  <example>For 23 items and groups of 7, 23 ÷ 7 = 3.285…, so ceil(3.285…) = 4 full groups are required.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check for leftover items after grouping. The remainder indicates unused resources and can guide further decisions.</description>
  <example>Dividing 23 items into groups of 7 yields 3 full groups (21 items) and 2 leftover items. These leftovers may be used in a smaller group or discarded.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total pay for a group by multiplying the number of workers by the per-worker rate and the hours per week, then by the number of weeks. Use T = n × r × h × w for n workers, rate r, hours h, and weeks w.</description>
  <example>For 50 workers at $20/hour for 40 hours/week over 4 weeks, T = 50 × 20 × 40 × 4 = 160,000.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a fraction of workers leaves, find the remaining count by multiplying the original count by (1 – f), where f is the fraction departed. This gives the new workforce size for subsequent calculations.</description>
  <example>If 20 workers leave from an original 50 (f = 0.4), remaining = 50 × (1 – 0.4) = 30.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum payments over multiple periods by computing each period’s total separately and then adding them. This avoids recalculating the same base rate and hours across periods.</description>
  <example>Period 1: 50 workers × $15/hour × 40 hours/week × 4 weeks = 120,000. Period 2: 30 workers × $15/hour × 40 hours/week × 4 weeks = 72,000. Total = 120,000 + 72,000 = 192,000.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to factor out common terms when summing identical rates and hours: T = (n₁ + n₂) × r × h × w. This simplifies the arithmetic.</description>
  <example>With 50 in month 1 and 30 in month 2, T = (50 + 30) × 15 × 40 × 4 = 80 × 15 × 40 × 4 = 192,000.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that the sum of individual period totals matches the result from factoring. This helps catch arithmetic or logic errors.</description>
  <example>Compute month 1 = 120,000 and month 2 = 72,000. Sum = 192,000. Factorized sum = 80 × 15 × 40 × 4 = 192,000. Both agree, confirming correctness.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a fixed fraction of another, express it as Q₁ = k·Q₂, where k is the fraction. This models proportional relationships directly.</description>
  <example>Suppose one worker’s output is 3/4 of another’s. If the second worker produces Q₂ units, then the first produces (3/4)·Q₂ units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find the total of two related quantities, add Q₁ + Q₂. This sums the individual contributions to give the overall amount.</description>
  <example>With Q₁ = (3/4)·Q₂ and Q₂ known, compute total = (3/4)·Q₂ + Q₂ by combining like terms.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine like terms by converting to a common denominator: a/b + 1 = (a + b)/b. This simplifies sums of fractions into a single fraction.</description>
  <example>For (3/4) + 1, rewrite 1 as 4/4, then add: (3/4 + 4/4) = 7/4.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check for unit consistency: ensure all quantities share the same unit before adding. This prevents mixing incompatible measures.</description>
  <example>If one quantity is in “units” and another in “pairs,” convert both to the same unit before summing.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by reversing the steps: use the total to recover the original quantities. This confirms the solution is consistent.</description>
  <example>Given total T and Q₂, compute Q₁ = (3/4)·Q₂ and check that Q₁ + Q₂ = T.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “k times” another, set up the equation x = k·y. This models one quantity being a constant multiple of another.</description>
  <example>Suppose a collection is three times the size of another. If the smaller has y items, then the larger has x = 3·y items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate “plus or minus” statements into addition or subtraction: “x plus m equals k·y” becomes x + m = k·y, and “x minus m equals k·y” becomes x – m = k·y.</description>
  <example>If a set has m more items than k times another set, write x + m = k·y. If it has m fewer, write x – m = k·y.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Isolate the unknown by rearranging: from x + m = k·y, derive x = k·y – m; from x – m = k·y, derive x = k·y + m. This solves for x in terms of known quantities.</description>
  <example>Given x + 5 = 4·y, subtract 5 to get x = 4·y – 5. Given x – 3 = 2·y, add 3 to get x = 2·y + 3.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the solution is an integer and nonnegative if the context requires whole items. Discard any fractional or negative results that don’t fit the scenario.</description>
  <example>If x = 4·y – 5 yields x = 7, it’s valid. But if x = 4·y – 5 yields x = 2.5, it’s invalid for counting items.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by substitution: plug the found x back into the original relation to ensure both sides match. This confirms the solution’s correctness.</description>
  <example>After finding x = 4·y – 5, substitute into x + 5 = 4·y to get (4·y – 5) + 5 = 4·y, which simplifies to 4·y = 4·y, confirming the solution.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Translate comparative phrases into algebraic expressions by assigning a variable to the base quantity and expressing other quantities as multiples or differences of that variable. This clarifies relationships and sets up equations.</description>
  <example>Let x be the number of small items. If large items are double the small ones, then large = 2x. If medium items are three less than small, then medium = x – 3.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the sum of all parts to form a total equation: sum of each category equals the overall total. This ensures all categories are accounted for.</description>
  <example>With small = x, medium = x – 3, large = 2x, extra-large = (2x)/2 + 6, the total is x + (x – 3) + 2x + ((2x)/2 + 6) = T, where T is the known total.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Combine like terms and simplify the total equation to a single linear equation in one variable. This reduces complexity before solving.</description>
  <example>From x + (x – 3) + 2x + (x + 6) = T, combine to get 5x + 3 = T, then isolate x by subtracting 3 and dividing by 5.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Check that the solution is a nonnegative integer and satisfies all original relationships. This guards against extraneous or invalid solutions.</description>
  <example>If solving yields x = 4, verify that medium = 1, large = 8, extra-large = 10 are all nonnegative integers and match the described differences.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always verify by substituting the found values back into each original relationship. This confirms consistency and catches arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>After finding x = 4, check: small = 4, medium = 1, large = 8, extra-large = 10, and confirm each difference and multiple condition holds true.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Identify the base consumption rate and any scaling factors for different categories. Use the base rate as the starting point and multiply by the appropriate factor for each subgroup.</description>
  <example>Suppose a standard item consumes R units, and a special item consumes k times that amount. For n standard items and m special items, total consumption = n·R + m·(k·R).</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert fractional or percentage rates into decimal multipliers. A rate of “half” becomes 0.5, “one-third” becomes 1/3, etc., to simplify multiplication.</description>
  <example>If one group uses 0.5 of the base rate, multiply the base rate by 0.5. For instance, if the base is B, the subgroup’s consumption is 0.5·B.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the distributive property to factor out common terms when summing multiple groups. This reduces repeated multiplication and simplifies the expression.</description>
  <example>For groups of size n₁ and n₂ with consumption rates R and k·R, write total = n₁·R + n₂·(k·R) = (n₁ + n₂·k)·R, then compute the sum inside the parentheses first.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by estimating the total with rounded or simplified values. This helps catch arithmetic or conceptual errors before final computation.</description>
  <example>Round R to the nearest convenient number, say R≈10, and approximate total ≈ n₁·10 + n₂·(k·10). If the rough estimate is far from the exact result, re-examine the setup.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify unit consistency and ensure all quantities are in the same units before summing. Mixing units (e.g., pounds vs. ounces) leads to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one group’s consumption is given in ounces and another in pounds, convert both to the same unit (e.g., ounces) before adding to avoid unit mismatch errors.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “double” another, represent it as 2×(that quantity). This captures the proportional relationship succinctly.</description>
  <example>Suppose one ingredient costs C. If a second ingredient costs double that, its cost is 2·C. For instance, if C=5, the second ingredient costs 10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Sum individual costs by adding them directly. This linear aggregation works whenever costs are independent and additive.</description>
  <example>Given costs C₁, C₂, and C₃, the total cost is C₁ + C₂ + C₃. For example, if C₁=2, C₂=3, C₃=4, the total is 9.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute the total cost over multiple periods by multiplying the weekly (or per-period) cost by the number of periods. This scales linearly.</description>
  <example>If the weekly cost is T, then over n weeks the total is n·T. For instance, if T=10 and n=4, the total is 40.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions: a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c. This can streamline calculations when a common factor appears.</description>
