<note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a total quantity is known, subtract that fraction from 1 to find the remaining fraction. This works because the sum of all parts equals the whole.</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, if you have completed f of them, the remaining fraction is 1 – f. For instance, if T = 100 and f = 1/4, then remaining = 1 – 1/4 = 3/4 of T.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Convert a fraction of a total into an absolute count by multiplying the fraction by the total. This gives the exact number of items or units represented by that fraction.</description>
  <example>Given a total T and a fraction f, the count is f × T. For example, if T = 80 and f = 3/5, then the count = (3/5) × 80 = 48 items.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Use the complement principle: if you know the completed portion, the leftover portion is the complement of that portion. This avoids re-deriving the whole when only the part is given.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have written p pages out of a total of T. The pages left = T – p. If p = 1/3 of T, then pages left = T – (1/3)T = (2/3)T.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Always check that the sum of the completed fraction and the remaining fraction equals 1 (or the total). This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>If you find that completed = 2/5 and remaining = 3/5, verify 2/5 + 3/5 = 1. If the sum is not 1, re-examine your fraction calculations.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>When dealing with mixed numbers or improper fractions, convert them to a common denominator before adding or subtracting. This simplifies the arithmetic and reduces errors.</description>
  <example>To add 1/2 and 1/3, convert to sixths: 1/2 = 3/6 and 1/3 = 2/6, so 1/2 + 1/3 = 5/6. Then subtract from 1 to get remaining = 1/6.</example>
</note5>

1. <note>
  <description>Compute total quantity needed by multiplying the rate (units per batch) by the number of batches. This gives the raw amount before any discounts or promotions.</description>
  <example>For a rate of R units per batch and B batches, total units = R × B. For instance, if R = 1 unit/batch and B = 8 batches, total units = 1 × 8 = 8 units.</example>
</note>
2. <note>
  <description>Apply a buy-one-get-one-half-off promotion by grouping items into pairs: each pair costs full price plus half price. This simplifies the calculation of discounted totals.</description>
  <example>With a price of P per unit, each pair costs P + 0.5P = 1.5P. For 8 units, form 4 pairs, so total cost = 4 × 1.5P = 6P.</example>
</note>
3. <note>
  <description>Use the unitary method: find the cost of one unit, then multiply by the total number of units. This is a straightforward way to handle any linear pricing.</description>
  <example>If one unit costs P, then N units cost N × P. For example, if P = $6 and N = 8, total cost = 8 × 6 = $48.</example>
</note>
4. <note>
  <description>Check for integer pairing: ensure the total quantity is even when using a “buy-one-get-one-half-off” scheme. If odd, handle the extra unit separately (e.g., at full price).</description>
  <example>For 7 units, form 3 pairs (cost = 3 × 1.5P = 4.5P) and pay full price for the remaining 1 unit (P), so total = 4.5P + P = 5.5P.</example>
</note>
5. <note>
  <description>Verify the result by comparing two methods: one using the promotion directly and one using the unitary method. Consistency confirms correctness.</description>
  <example>Compute total cost via pairing: 4 pairs × 1.5P = 6P. Compute via unitary: 8 units × P = 8P. If these differ, recheck grouping or arithmetic.</example>
</note>

<note1>
  <description>Use the complement rule to find the probability of an event not occurring: P(not A) = 1 – P(A). This is useful when you know the chance of an event happening and need the chance it does not.</description>
  <example>Suppose there is a 40% chance of rain. The probability it does not rain is 1 – 0.40 = 0.60, or 60%.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply the multiplication rule for independent events: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B). Use this when two events do not affect each other’s probabilities.</description>
  <example>If the chance of drawing a red card from a deck is 0.50 and the chance of flipping heads on a fair coin is 0.50, then the chance of both happening is 0.50 × 0.50 = 0.25.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Use the law of total probability to combine multiple scenarios: P(A) = Σ P(S_i) × P(A|S_i), where S_i are mutually exclusive scenarios. This handles cases with overlapping or alternative conditions.</description>
  <example>Imagine two scenarios: Scenario 1 has a 0.30 chance and within it event A has a 0.70 chance; Scenario 2 has a 0.70 chance and within it event A has a 0.20 chance. Then P(A) = 0.30×0.70 + 0.70×0.20 = 0.21 + 0.14 = 0.35.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Model sequential decisions with a decision tree: list each decision branch, assign probabilities, and multiply along branches to find combined probabilities. This clarifies complex multi-step processes.</description>
  <example>Decide whether to take umbrella (0.60) or not (0.40). If you take it, rain chance is 0.20; if you don’t, rain chance is 0.50. The tree branches show 0.60×0.20 + 0.40×0.50 = 0.12 + 0.20 = 0.32.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Check for independence and conditional dependencies: if events are not independent, use P(A|B) instead of P(A)×P(B). Misapplying the multiplication rule can lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>Event A is “it rains” and event B is “you carry an umbrella.” If carrying an umbrella reduces rain chance to 0.10, then P(rain|umbrella) = 0.10, not 0.50×0.50 = 0.25.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
    <description>Convert time units by multiplying or dividing by the appropriate factor. For example, to convert minutes to seconds, multiply by 60; to convert hours to minutes, multiply by 60.</description>
    <example>Convert 2 hours into minutes: 2 × 60 = 120 minutes.</example>
  </note2>
  <note2>
    <description>Compute total duration by multiplying the number of rounds by the duration per round. This gives the overall time span for repeated events.</description>
    <example>If each round lasts 5 minutes and there are 4 rounds, total time = 4 × 5 = 20 minutes.</example>
  </note3>
  <note3>
    <description>Use the rate–time–quantity formula: quantity = rate × time. This applies whenever you know how many units occur per unit time and the total time.</description>
    <example>If a machine produces 10 items per minute and runs for 15 minutes, total items = 10 × 15 = 150.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>Check unit consistency: ensure all time units match before multiplying. Convert all durations to the same unit before applying the rate formula.</description>

  </note6>
  <note7>
    <description>Verify by dimensional analysis: the units of the result should match the expected units. For example, punches per minute × minutes yields punches.</description>

  </note7>

Define Variables: Assign symbols to unknown quantities (e.g., let \( c \) = cupcakes, \( b \) = brownies, \( m \) = muffins).
Translate Phrases: Convert statements like “four times as many” or “3 less than” into algebraic expressions (e.g., \( b = 4c - 3 \)).
Set Up Equations: Use total counts or per-person distributions to form equations (e.g., \( c + b + m = \text{total treats} \)).
Solve the System: Use substitution or elimination to find each variable.
Check Consistency: Ensure all variables are nonnegative integers and satisfy the original conditions.
Validate: Plug the solution back into the problem statement to confirm it meets all requirements.

3.1. Use the division algorithm: For any total T and number of parts n, compute quotient q = T ÷ n and remainder r = T mod n. This yields q items per part with r leftover.
3.2. Distribute remainder evenly: If r ≠ 0, assign one extra item to each of the first r recipients. This ensures fair distribution when T is not divisible by n.
3.3. Check consistency: Verify that n × q + r = T. This confirms the division and remainder steps are correct.
3.4. Apply to repeated items: When items come in groups of size g, first compute total T = g × k, then divide by n. This handles grouped resources in a single step.
3.5. Use modular arithmetic shortcuts: Compute T mod n directly to find remainder without full division, then adjust quotient accordingly. This can simplify mental math.

<note1>
  <description>When combining two or more quantities, add them to form a single total. This is useful whenever items are merged or accumulated.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have A items in one container and B items in another. The total number of items is A + B.</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>When a quantity is removed from a total, subtract the removed amount to find the remaining total. This models taking away or using items.</description>
  <example>If you start with T items and use U of them, the remaining count is T – U.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>When a final total is known and some parts are given, set up an equation by adding the known parts and an unknown part, then solve for the unknown. This is a standard approach for “total minus parts” problems.</description>
  <example>Let X be the unknown part, and you know Y and Z are other parts. If the total is T, then X + Y + Z = T, so X = T – (Y + Z).</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Always check that your solution is nonnegative and makes sense in context. Negative or fractional results may indicate a modeling error or misinterpretation of the problem.</description>
  <example>If you find X = –2 in a counting problem, revisit the setup because a negative count is impossible.</example>
</note5>

 <note2>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the unit rate formula: distance = (distance per unit fuel) × (total fuel). This works whenever you know how far you go per unit of fuel and want the total distance for a given fuel amount.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a car travels 20 miles per gallon and you have 10 gallons, then distance = 20 × 10 = 200 miles.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute the fuel efficiency (miles per gallon) by dividing the total distance driven by the total fuel consumed: efficiency = distance ÷ fuel. This gives the rate at which the vehicle uses fuel.</description>
  <example>Suppose you drive 150 miles using 5 gallons; then efficiency = 150 ÷ 5 = 30 miles per gallon.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When given a tank capacity and efficiency, multiply them to find the maximum range: range = capacity × efficiency. This directly yields the farthest distance you can go on a full tank.</description>
  <example>If your tank holds 12 gallons and your car is 25 miles per gallon, then range = 12 × 25 = 300 miles.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check units consistency: ensure distance and fuel are in compatible units (e.g., miles and gallons) before multiplying. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If you measure distance in kilometers but fuel in gallons, convert kilometers to miles or gallons to liters before applying the formula.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of real-world factors like varying driving conditions, which can affect efficiency. Use the computed efficiency as an estimate, not an exact value.</description>
  <example>A car might average 30 mpg on the highway but only 20 mpg in city traffic; plan trips accordingly rather than relying solely on the average.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the complement rule: if a fraction f of a total T has a property, then (1–f)·T have the opposite property. This avoids subtracting from the whole directly.</description>
  <example>Suppose 2/5 of 100 items are defective. Then 3/5 of 100 are non-defective, so 3/5·100=60 non-defective items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When given a count of items with a feature, subtract that count from the total to find those without it. This is a direct complement approach.</description>
  <example>Out of 80 shirts, 24 have pockets. Then 80–24=56 shirts have no pockets.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>For two categories, compute the difference between the counts of items lacking a feature in each category. This yields how many more (or fewer) items lack the feature in one category than the other.</description>
  <example>Category A has 40 items with no label, and category B has 30 items with no label. Then B has 30–40=–10 fewer items with no label than A.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that your computed counts are non-negative and that the subtraction of counts yields a meaningful difference. This guards against sign errors or impossible results.</description>
  <example>If you find 15 items with no feature in group X and 20 in group Y, then 20–15=5 is valid. If you got 20–15=–5, recheck your counts or logic.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>When combining multiple steps, perform each calculation in sequence and carry intermediate results to the next step. This reduces errors and keeps the workflow clear.</description>
  <example>First compute non-defective items: 3/5·100=60. Then compute non-defective in another batch: 4/7·70=40. Finally, find the difference: 60–40=20.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a total time T is used for one activity, subtract that time from T to find the remaining time. This is the first step in any multi-activity time allocation problem.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have T total hours and you spend t₁ hours on activity A. Then the remaining time is T – t₁, which you can use for subsequent activities.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction f of a remaining quantity R, compute f × R. This is useful when an activity takes a fixed fraction of the leftover time.</description>
  <example>If you have R hours left and you decide to spend f = 1/3 of that time on activity B, then time spent on B is (1/3) × R.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>After allocating time to several activities, sum all allocated times and subtract from the total to find the remaining time. This ensures you account for every hour.</description>
  <example>Let t₁, t₂, t₃ be times spent on three activities. The leftover time is T – (t₁ + t₂ + t₃), which can be used for any final activity.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>To convert a time allocation t into a percentage of the total T, use (t / T) × 100%. This gives the proportion of the total time spent on that activity.</description>
  <example>If you spend t hours on activity C out of T total hours, then the percentage is ((t / T) × 100)%.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the sum of all allocated times does not exceed the total. If it does, re-evaluate the fractions or times to avoid over-allocation.</description>
  <example>After computing t₁ + t₂ + t₃, verify that t₁ + t₂ + t₃ ≤ T. If the sum exceeds T, adjust one or more fractions to keep the total within bounds.</example>

  <description>Always verify by checking a small case or by summing subtotals. This guards against arithmetic or conceptual errors.</description>
