<note1>
  <description>Translate each comparative statement into an algebraic equation by assigning a variable to one quantity and expressing others in terms of it. This creates a system of linear equations that models the relationships.</description>
  <example>Let x be the number of items in group A. If group B has 5 more than A, write y = x + 5. If group C has 3 fewer than B, write z = y – 3. These three equations represent the relationships.</example>
</note1>
 <note2>
  <description>Use substitution to reduce the system: solve one equation for one variable and substitute into the others. This turns a multi-variable system into a single-variable equation.</description>
  <example>From y = x + 5, substitute into z = y – 3 to get z = (x + 5) – 3 = x + 2. Now the system is x + y + z = total, with y and z both expressed in terms of x.</example>
</note2>
 <note3>
  <description>Combine like terms and solve the resulting single-variable equation. This yields the value of the chosen variable, which can then be back-substituted.</description>
  <example>With x + (x + 5) + (x + 2) = total, combine to get 3x + 7 = total. Then solve 3x = total – 7, so x = (total – 7)/3.</example>
</note3>
 <note4>
  <description>Verify the solution by substituting back into all original equations. This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic or sign errors.</description>
  <example>After finding x, compute y = x + 5 and z = x + 2, then check that x + y + z equals the given total. If it does, the solution is correct.</example>
</note4>
 <note5>
  <description>Check for integer or domain constraints: ensure the solution is a whole number and meets any non-negativity or minimum requirements.</description>
  <example>If x = (total – 7)/3 must be an integer, confirm (total – 7) is divisible by 3. If not, re-examine the setup or constraints for errors.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the distributive property to combine like terms: a·x + a·y = a·(x + y). This simplifies expressions by factoring out common multipliers.</description>
  <example>Compute 5·3 + 5·7 by factoring: 5·(3 + 7) = 5·10 = 50.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the commutative and associative laws to reorder and regroup terms: a + b + c = b + a + c and (a + b) + c = a + (b + c). This helps in choosing the easiest order for addition.</description>
  <example>For 12 + 8 + 5, regroup as (12 + 8) + 5 = 20 + 5 = 25.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use rounding to estimate totals: round each quantity to a nearby convenient number, sum them, then adjust by the difference. This gives a quick check on exact results.</description>
  <example>Estimate 19 + 23 + 32 by rounding to 20 + 20 + 30 = 70, then correct by subtracting the overestimation: (19–20)+(23–20)+(32–30) = –1+3+2 = +4, so 70 + 4 = 74.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Perform a unit check: ensure all quantities are in the same unit before adding. Convert units if necessary (e.g., dollars to cents) to avoid errors.</description>
  <example>Adding 2 items at $1.50 each and 3 items at 50¢ each: convert 50¢ to $0.50, then compute 2·1.50 + 3·0.50 = 3.00 + 1.50 = $4.50.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by reverse calculation: subtract the total from the initial amount to recover the individual parts. This confirms that no term was omitted or miscomputed.</description>
  <example>If you start with $100 and spend $45, check by computing 100 – 45 = 55 to ensure the remaining amount is correct.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a rate changes by a percentage, compute the new rate as original × (1 ± percentage). Use “+” for an increase and “–” for a decrease.</description>
  <example>Original rate R. If it increases by p%, new rate = R × (1 + p/100). If it decreases by p%, new rate = R × (1 – p/100).</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>For a fixed number of periods, multiply the rate by the period count to get total cost. This applies to any uniform rate over equal intervals.</description>
  <example>Rate R per period over n periods: total = R × n. For instance, if R = 100 and n = 6, total = 100 × 6 = 600.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When two different rates apply to two equal-length segments, split the total into two parts: (rate₁ × segment₁) + (rate₂ × segment₂).</description>
  <example>Segment length = n/2. If rate₁ = R and rate₂ = R × (1 – p/100), total = R × (n/2) + [R × (1 – p/100)] × (n/2).</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Factor common terms to simplify expressions. If both parts share a factor, pull it out to reduce arithmetic complexity.</description>
  <example>From R × (n/2) + R × (1 – p/100) × (n/2), factor (n/2) × R to get (n/2) × R × [1 + (1 – p/100)].</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure rates and periods match (e.g., dollars per month, months). Misalignment leads to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If rate is in dollars per month and period is in years, convert years to months (12 months) before multiplying.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert daily consumption to total per period by multiplying per-person rate by the number of people and the number of meals per day. This gives a single daily consumption rate for the entire group.</description>
  <example>For 5 people each consuming 0.2 kg per meal twice a day, daily consumption = 5 × 0.2 kg/meal × 2 meals/day = 2 kg/day.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total consumption over a multi-day period by multiplying the daily rate by the number of days. This yields the total amount consumed in that interval.</description>
  <example>If daily consumption is 2 kg/day, then over 7 days it is 2 kg/day × 7 days = 14 kg.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the formula “time = total supply ÷ daily consumption” to find how many days (or weeks) a supply lasts. Ensure units match before dividing.</description>
  <example>With a 14 kg supply and 2 kg/day consumption, time = 14 kg ÷ 2 kg/day = 7 days.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Convert days into weeks by dividing by 7. This is useful when the question asks for weeks rather than days.</description>
  <example>7 days ÷ 7 days/week = 1 week.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the computed time is nonnegative and that the supply is at least as large as the consumption rate. If not, the supply will run out before the period ends.</description>
  <example>If daily consumption is 3 kg/day and supply is 10 kg, time = 10 ÷ 3 ≈ 3.33 days, which is valid; if supply were 2 kg, time = 2 ÷ 3 ≈ 0.67 days, still valid but supply is exhausted before the first full day.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Use the weighted average formula: total = (count₁ × value₁) + (count₂ × value₂). This applies whenever you have two groups with different quantities and values.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 5 items at price A and 3 items at price B. Total cost = 5·A + 3·B.</example>
</note1>
 <note2>
  <description>Break the problem into distinct cases based on group membership. Compute each group’s contribution separately before summing.</description>
  <example>For 4 red balls worth R and 6 blue balls worth B, compute red total = 4·R, blue total = 6·B, then add them.</example>
</note2>
 <note3>
  <description>Apply the distributive property to factor out common terms: a·x + a·y = a·(x + y). This simplifies expressions when multiple terms share a factor.</description>
  <example>Given 7·M + 7·N, factor to 7·(M + N) to reduce arithmetic steps.</example>
</note3>
 <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that the sum of group counts equals the total count. This guards against miscounting or missing cases.</description>
  <example>If you have 8 items in group A and 4 in group B, confirm 8 + 4 = 12 matches the stated total.</example>
</note4>
 <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by estimating: round values to simpler numbers and compute a rough total. Compare this to your exact result to catch large errors.</description>
  <example>For 8·8 + 4·16, estimate 8·8 ≈ 64 and 4·16 ≈ 64, so total ≈ 128. If your exact sum is far from 128, recheck your work.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert each coin’s value to its base unit (e.g. cents) before summing. This ensures all amounts use the same unit for accurate totals.</description>
  <example>For 4 quarters and 2 dimes, convert to cents: 4×25 + 2×10 = 100 + 20 = 120 cents.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify sums: a·x + b·x = (a + b)·x. This reduces multiple terms into one multiplication.</description>
  <example>Instead of 3×25 + 2×25, compute (3 + 2)×25 = 5×25 = 125 cents.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Perform subtraction in one step: total − cost = remaining. This avoids intermediate sums and reduces error.</description>
  <example>With 120 cents and a 75-cent purchase, compute 120 − 75 = 45 cents left.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for integer results: ensure the result of any division or subtraction is a whole number. Non-integer results indicate a modeling or arithmetic error.</description>
  <example>When dividing 120 by 25, verify 120 ÷ 25 = 4.8 is not an integer, signaling a need to recheck coin counts or unit conversion.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a quick mental estimate to verify the final answer. Round values to nearby convenient numbers to catch large errors.</description>
  <example>Estimate 120 − 75 ≈ 120 − 80 = 40, then refine to 45. If the estimate is far off, re-examine the calculation.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the addition principle: when combining quantities, sum them directly. This works because addition is commutative and associative, so the order of grouping does not affect the total.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have A items, then receive B more, and later receive C more. The total is A + B + C. For instance, if A = 5, B = 3, C = 7, then total = 5 + 3 + 7 = 15.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the subtraction principle: when removing or using items, subtract the amount removed from the current total. This ensures you account for all changes in a single step.</description>
  <example>If you start with T items and give away D, the remaining count is T – D. For example, if T = 20 and D = 4, then remaining = 20 – 4 = 16.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the order of operations: perform additions and subtractions in sequence, from left to right. This prevents errors when multiple operations occur in a single expression.</description>
  <example>Given an expression like A + B – C + D, compute A + B first, then subtract C, and finally add D. For instance, if A = 10, B = 4, C = 3, D = 2, then (10 + 4) – 3 + 2 = 13.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use a running total variable to track changes step by step. This helps keep track of intermediate results and reduces the chance of mixing up final and intermediate values.</description>
  <example>Let T = initial amount. After adding X, set T = T + X. After subtracting Y, set T = T – Y. For example, if T = 8, X = 5, Y = 2, then T = 8 + 5 = 13, then T = 13 – 2 = 11.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by reversing operations: add back any subtractions and subtract any additions to see if you return to the original amount. This check ensures consistency in your calculations.</description>
  <example>If you end with R after operations, add back all subtractions and subtract all additions. For instance, if R = 12, you subtracted 3 and added 5, then 12 + 3 – 5 = 10, which should match the original total.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentage increases or decreases into multipliers by adding or subtracting the rate (e.g., 10% increase = 1 + 0.10 = 1.10). This lets you compute new amounts directly from the original.</description>
  <example>For a 15% increase on X, multiply X by 1.15 to get the new value. For a 5% decrease, multiply by 0.95.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the simple interest formula A = P(1 + r·t) when interest is applied once or at a fixed rate over time. Here P is principal, r is rate per period, and t is number of periods.</description>
  <example>If you borrow P and the rate is r per period for t periods, then A = P(1 + r·t) gives the total amount to repay.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute remaining balance after equal periodic payments by subtracting the total paid from the initial amount plus any accrued interest. This avoids recalculating each period.</description>
  <example>With initial amount A, total paid = monthly payment × n, so remaining = A + accrued_interest – (payment × n).</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency: ensure the total payments cover or exceed the final amount. If not, the problem may have an error or missing data.</description>
  <example>If total payments are less than the computed final amount, the balance cannot be negative; instead, it equals the difference between the two.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a stepwise approach: first compute the final amount after interest, then subtract each payment one by one to track the balance. This helps catch arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>Start with A, subtract payment1 to get B, subtract payment2 to get C, and so on, until you reach the 15th month.</example>
</note1>

Step 1: <note1>
  <description>When multiple groups remove the same quantity from a total, compute the total removal by multiplying the number of groups by the removal per group, then subtract from the original total. This avoids adding each removal separately.</description>
  <example>Start with T items. If k groups each remove r items, total removed = k·r, so remaining = T – (k·r).</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a remaining quantity, multiply the remaining amount by the fraction. This directly gives the portion removed or kept.</description>
  <example>After removing some items, you have R left. If f of these run away, the number that run = f·R.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>After each removal or fraction operation, update the remaining total before applying the next step. This ensures sequential operations are applied to the correct base.</description>
  <example>First remove k·r from T to get R₁. Then remove f·R₁ to get R₂. Always use the updated R₁ for the next fraction.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Use the complement of a fraction to find what remains after a fraction is removed: remaining = (1 – f)·R. This is often simpler than computing the removed portion first.</description>
  <example>If f of R run away, then (1 – f)·R stay. For instance, if 3/4 run, 1/4 remain.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always verify that each step yields a non-negative result and that the final answer is an integer when dealing with discrete items. This guards against arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>Check that R₁ ≥ 0 and R₂ = R₁ – f·R₁ ≥ 0. If R₂ is not an integer, re-examine the fraction or rounding assumptions.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert percentage rates into decimal form by dividing by 100. This allows direct multiplication with quantities to find commissions or discounts.</description>
  <example>For a 15% rate, compute 15/100 = 0.15. Then multiply 0.15 by the quantity to get the commission.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply the unit-rate method: multiply each item’s unit price by its unit commission rate to get the per-unit commission, then multiply by the number of units.</description>
  <example>If an item costs $P and the commission rate is r, then per-unit commission = P × r. For n units, total = n × (P × r).</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Use the weighted-average approach: compute the total commission as the sum of each category’s commission, i.e. Σ (quantity_i × price_i × rate_i).</description>
  <example>For two categories with quantities n₁, n₂; prices P₁, P₂; and rates r₁, r₂, total = n₁·P₁·r₁ + n₂·P₂·r₂.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by estimating: round quantities and rates to simple numbers, compute a rough total, then compare to the exact result to catch arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>Round 8 copies to 10, $5 to $5, 12 copies to 10, $15 to $15, and 12% to 10%. Estimate total ≈10×5×0.10 + 10×15×0.10 = 5 + 15 = $20, then verify the exact calculation.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When two quantities are in a fixed ratio, introduce a single variable for the smaller quantity and express the larger as a multiple of it. This reduces the number of unknowns and simplifies equations.</description>
  <example>Suppose A is twice B. Let B = x, then A = 2x. If A + B = 12, substitute to get 2x + x = 12, so x = 4 and A = 8.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate each payment or cost statement into an equation by assigning a variable to each rate and multiplying by the number of occurrences. Sum these equations to form a linear system.</description>
  <example>If worker earns r₁ per job and r₂ per task, and does n₁ jobs and n₂ tasks, then total = r₁·n₁ + r₂·n₂. For instance, if r₁ = 5, n₁ = 3, r₂ = 2, n₂ = 4, total = 15 + 8 = 23.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the total revenue or cost constraint to solve for the unknown rate or variable. Substitute the expressions from ratio and payment equations into the total equation and solve algebraically.</description>
  <example>Given total = 100 and expressions A = 3x, B = 4x, C = 5x, set 3x + 4x + 5x = 100, so 12x = 100 and x = 100/12.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>After finding the rate or variable, compute the desired component by substituting back into its expression. This yields the final amount for that category.</description>
  <example>If x = 100/12 and the lemonade sales amount is 2x, then lemonade sales = 2·(100/12) = 100/6 ≈ 16.67.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your solution by checking that all individual amounts satisfy their original ratio and payment conditions, and that their sum matches the total given. This ensures no arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>With x = 100/12, check A = 3x = 300/12, B = 4x = 400/12, C = 5x = 500/12. Sum = 1200/12 = 100, matching the total, and ratios A:B:C = 3:4:5 hold.</example>

BLEM:
  <note1>
    <description>When combining items with different weights and calorie densities, compute total calories by multiplying each item’s weight by its calorie density and summing the results. This applies to any mixture of substances with known per-unit values.</description>
    <example>Suppose you have 2 units of A at 100 cal/unit and 3 units of B at 50 cal/unit. Total calories = 2×100 + 3×50 = 200 + 150 = 350 cal.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>Equal weights of two items mean their weights are the same. If one item’s weight is given as W, the other’s weight is also W, simplifying the calculation of combined quantities.</description>
    <example>If you mix equal amounts of ingredient X and ingredient Y, and X weighs 4 units, then Y also weighs 4 units, so you can directly use 4 units for both in further calculations.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Always convert all quantities to the same units before multiplying by densities. Mixing units (e.g., ounces vs. grams) without conversion leads to incorrect totals.</description>
    <example>If one ingredient is given in ounces and another in grams, convert both to ounces (or both to grams) so that the multiplication step yields consistent results.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>Check for unit consistency: ensure that the unit of density matches the unit of quantity. For instance, if density is given per gram, the quantity must be in grams.</description>
    <example>If density is 80 cal/gram and quantity is 200 grams, multiply directly: 200×80 = 16,000 cal. If quantity were given in ounces, convert first.</example>
  </note5>
  <note6>
    <description>After computing totals, verify by estimating: round densities and weights to simple numbers to get a rough total, then compare to your exact result to catch arithmetic errors.</description>
    <example>For 3 units at 110 cal/unit and 2 units at 50 cal/unit, estimate 3×100 + 2×50 = 300 + 100 = 400 cal. If your exact answer is 410 cal, it’s close and likely correct.</example>
  </note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total work by multiplying rate by time: Work = Rate × Time. This applies whenever you know how much is done per unit time and the duration.</description>
  <example>For a task requiring 120 units at a rate of 8 units/day, total work is 120 = 8 × 15 days.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Find time needed by dividing total work by rate: Time = Work ÷ Rate. Use this to determine how long a constant-rate process will take.</description>
  <example>With 120 units and a rate of 8 units/day, time = 120 ÷ 8 = 15 days.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Calculate remaining time by subtracting completed time from deadline: Remaining = Deadline – Completed. This helps assess how much time is left.</description>
  <example>If deadline is 20 days and you’ve worked 15 days, remaining = 20 – 15 = 5 days.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check feasibility by comparing total time to deadline: If Time ≥ Deadline, the task is on time; if Time > Deadline, it’s late. This ensures you meet requirements.</description>
  <example>With 15 days needed and a 20-day deadline, since 15 ≤ 20, the task is on time.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use proportional reasoning: If rate changes, adjust time proportionally: NewTime = (OriginalTime × NewRate) ÷ OldRate. This scales tasks when rates vary.</description>
  <example>Original rate 8 units/day for 15 days gives 120 units. If rate drops to 6 units/day, new time = (15 × 6) ÷ 8 = 11.25 days.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentage increases to multipliers by adding the percentage rate to 100%. For a p% increase, use factor = 1 + p/100. This converts a percentage change into a single multiplication factor.</description>
  <example>Suppose an item costs X and you need a 20% increase. Compute factor = 1 + 20/100 = 1.20, then new cost = X × 1.20.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When one quantity is a fixed percentage more than another, set up the relation Y = (1 + p/100)·X. This directly links the two amounts without extra steps.</description>
  <example>If supplies cost X and travel costs 30% more, then travel cost = (1 + 30/100)·X = 1.30·X.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the unitary method: find the value of one unit first, then scale to the desired quantity. This is especially useful when dealing with percentages or ratios.</description>
  <example>If 100 units cost X, then 1 unit costs X/100. For 150 units, cost = (X/100) × 150 = 1.50·X.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that your multiplier is applied to the correct base amount. Mixing up the base can lead to incorrect percentage calculations.</description>
  <example>Do not compute a 20% increase on a quantity that is already increased by 20%. First apply the increase to the original, then apply any further percentage changes to the new total.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by reversing the operation: if you increased by p%, then decreasing by p% on the result should return you to the original amount (within rounding).</description>
  <example>If you found travel cost = 1.20·X, then compute (1.20·X) × (1 – 20/100) = 1.20·X × 0.80 = 0.96·X, which is not X. Adjust the multiplier or check the problem statement.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total cost by adding principal and interest: Total = Principal × (1 + Interest Rate). This applies when a single item or sum of items incurs a fixed percentage fee.</description>
  <example>For one item costing P with a 5% fee, Total = P × 1.05. If P = 100, Total = 100 × 1.05 = 105.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert percentage to decimal by dividing by 100: Rate_decimal = Rate_percent ÷ 100. This is essential for accurate multiplication in interest or discount calculations.</description>
  <example>For a 4% rate, Rate_decimal = 4 ÷ 100 = 0.04. Then 0.04 × 100 = 4, matching the original percentage.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the simple interest formula for multiple items: Total = Number_of_items × Principal × (1 + Rate_decimal). This scales the single-item calculation to any quantity.</description>
  <example>With 5 items at P = 80 and 3% rate, Total = 5 × 80 × 1.03 = 400 × 1.03 = 412.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Divide total cost by the number of installments to find monthly payment: Monthly = Total ÷ Number_of_months. Ensure the total includes all fees before dividing.</description>
  <example>If Total = 412 over 4 months, Monthly = 412 ÷ 4 = 103.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by reversing the process: Multiply monthly payment by months and add any remaining principal to check against original total. This catches arithmetic or rounding errors.</description>
  <example>For 103 per month over 4 months: 103 × 4 = 412. If original principal was 400, the 12 extra accounts for the 3% fee.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When combining items of different types, compute the total by multiplying each type’s quantity by its per-item count and then summing. This gives the overall total before any removals.</description>
  <example>For 3 items of type A each yielding 5 units and 2 items of type B each yielding 4 units, total = 3×5 + 2×4 = 15 + 8 = 23 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>After finding the total, subtract the consumed or removed amount to get the remainder. This direct subtraction applies whenever you know both the total and the amount taken.</description>
  <example>If you have 23 units and consume 10, then remainder = 23 − 10 = 13 units.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions like a×m + b×n. Factor common terms or combine like terms to reduce arithmetic complexity.</description>
  <example>Instead of computing 3×5 + 2×5 separately, factor 5: (3 + 2)×5 = 5×5 = 25, which is faster than 15 + 10.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always verify your result by reversing the steps: add back the removed amount to the remainder to see if you recover the original total. This check catches arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>If remainder is 13 and you removed 10, check 13 + 10 = 23, which matches the initial total of 23.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Watch for off-by-one errors when counting discrete items. Ensure you count each item exactly once and avoid double-counting or omitting any.</description>
  <example>When slicing 4 apples into 6 pieces each, count 4×6 = 24 pieces, not 4×5 or 4×7, to avoid miscounting.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert time and distance units to a consistent system before computing rates. Use the relation time = distance / speed or distance = speed × time to ensure all quantities share the same units.</description>
  <example>Suppose a vehicle travels at 60 km/h. To find how far it goes in 2 hours, convert 2 hours to hours (already in hours) and compute distance = 60 km/h × 2 h = 120 km. If you had 2 minutes, convert to hours (2/60 h) before multiplying.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Compute the rate of change by dividing the change in one quantity by the change in another. For a leak, rate = volume of water / distance rowed. This gives the constant rate at which the boat accumulates water per unit distance.</description>
  <example>If a container loses 5 L of liquid over 20 m of travel, the leak rate is 5 L / 20 m = 0.25 L/m. This rate can then be used to predict how much liquid will be lost over any other distance.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Use direct proportionality when two quantities vary at a constant rate. If Q₁ corresponds to D₁, then for any D₂, Q₂ = (Q₁ / D₁) × D₂. This avoids re-deriving the rate each time.</description>
  <example>Given that 0.25 L of water accumulates per meter, to find the amount for 50 m, compute Q₂ = (0.25 L/m) × 50 m = 12.5 L. This method scales directly without recalculating the rate.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Apply the unitary method by finding the value for one unit and then scaling up. First determine the rate per single unit, then multiply by the total number of units. This is especially useful for rates expressed per unit distance or time.</description>
  <example>If a machine produces 12 widgets in 4 hours, its rate is 12/4 = 3 widgets/hour. To find output in 10 hours, compute 3 widgets/hour × 10 hours = 30 widgets.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Verify your result by checking units and plausibility. Ensure that the computed quantity has the correct unit (e.g., liters, meters, hours) and that it is reasonable given the context. A unit mismatch or implausibly large/small result indicates an error.</description>
  <example>After calculating 12.5 L of water for 50 m, confirm that liters and meters are consistent and that 12.5 L is a plausible amount for a small boat over that distance. If the result were 1250 L, you would re-examine your rate or conversion steps.</example>
</note5>

Step 1: Represent the initial depth as a variable, say D₁, to capture the starting measurement.  
Step 2: Model any increase or decrease as an arithmetic operation on D₁ (e.g., D₂ = D₁ + Δ).  
Step 3: Apply a fraction or ratio to the intermediate result to get the final depth (e.g., D₃ = k·D₂).  
Step 4: Simplify the expression by combining like terms and reducing fractions.  
Step 5: Verify the result by substituting back into the original relationships.

<note1>
  <description>Simple interest is calculated as I = P × r × t, where P is the principal, r is the annual interest rate, and t is the time in years. Use this when interest accrues only on the original amount.</description>
  <example>For a principal of P, an annual rate of r, and a time of t years, the interest is I = P × r × t. For instance, if P = 100, r = 0.05, t = 2, then I = 100 × 0.05 × 2 = 10.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Convert a percentage rate to a decimal by dividing by 100. This is essential for accurate interest and rate calculations.</description>
  <example>A 3% rate becomes 0.03 in decimal form. If you need to apply 3% to a principal P, compute P × 0.03 instead of P × 3%.</example>
</note1>
<note3>
  <description>When payments are made periodically, compute the remaining principal after each payment by subtracting the payment from the current principal. This updates the principal for subsequent interest calculations.</description>
  <example>Start with principal P. After a payment of A, the new principal is P − A. If P = 200 and A = 50, then the updated principal is 150.</example>
</note1>
<note4>
  <description>For a final lump-sum payment, add any accrued interest to the remaining principal. This ensures the total owed is fully settled.</description>
  <example>If the remaining principal is P and the interest for the final period is I, then the final payment is P + I. For example, if P = 150 and I = 10, the final payment is 160.</example>
</note1>
<note5>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all periodic payments plus the final lump-sum equals the original principal plus total interest. This check prevents miscalculations.</description>
  <example>Suppose periodic payments sum to S and the final payment is F. If the original principal was P and total interest was I, then S + F should equal P + I. For instance, if P + I = 260, and S + F = 260, the calculation is correct.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying quantity by unit price for each item, then summing. This applies whenever you have multiple items with different prices and quantities.</description>
  <example>For 4 pens at $2 each and 3 notebooks at $5 each, total = 4×2 + 3×5 = 8 + 15 = $23.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify sums of products: a×b + a×c = a×(b + c). This can reduce arithmetic steps when quantities share a common factor.</description>
  <example>Instead of 5×3 + 5×7, compute 5×(3 + 7) = 5×10 = 50.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Find the difference between two totals by subtracting the smaller total from the larger. This directly gives how much more one group spent than another.</description>
  <example>If Team A spent $120 and Team B spent $90, the difference = 120 – 90 = $30.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for unit consistency: ensure all quantities and prices use the same unit (e.g., dollars, cents) before adding or subtracting. Mismatched units lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>Don’t add $2.50 and 25¢ directly; convert 25¢ to $0.25, then sum: 2.50 + 0.25 = $2.75.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by recomputing or using an alternative method (e.g., reverse subtraction or cross-checking totals). This helps catch arithmetic or unit errors.</description>
  <example>After finding a total of $100, recompute by grouping items differently or subtracting the smaller group from the larger to confirm the same result.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “double” another, represent it as 2×(original). This captures the direct proportional relationship.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a team plays x games on one day, then on the next day they play 2×x games, ensuring the doubling is explicit in the model.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate each verbal statement into an algebraic expression by assigning a variable to each unknown quantity. This creates a clear framework for manipulation.</description>
  <example>Let m be the number of matches on Monday, f on Friday, and s on Saturday. Then s = 2×m, and you can express total matches as m + f + s.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum all the algebraic expressions to form the total. This aggregates individual contributions into one expression for further simplification or evaluation.</description>
  <example>With m + f + s, substitute s = 2×m to get m + f + 2×m = 3×m + f, which is the total matches in one week.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use substitution to replace one variable with its expression in terms of another. This reduces the number of variables and simplifies the expression.</description>
  <example>Given s = 2×m, replace s in the sum m + f + s to obtain m + f + 2×m = 3×m + f, streamlining the total.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>After forming the total expression, check for consistency by plugging in simple values (e.g., m = 1) to ensure the model behaves as expected.</description>
  <example>If m = 1 and f = 2, then total = 3×1 + 2 = 5, matching the verbal description of “double” and “sum.”</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When two quantities are in a fixed ratio a:b, assign them as a·x and b·x. This parameterizes the relationship and simplifies solving for x.</description>
  <example>For a ratio 2:5, let the pieces be 2x and 5x. If their sum is 14, then 2x+5x=14 gives x=2, so the pieces are 4 and 10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate “sum of parts equals total” into an equation: a·x + b·x = T. This captures the constraint that the pieces combine to the given total.</description>
  <example>With pieces 3x and 7x summing to 50, write 3x+7x=50, so 10x=50 and x=5, yielding pieces 15 and 35.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>After finding x, compute each part by multiplying x by its ratio coefficient. This ensures you recover the actual lengths or values.</description>
  <example>If x=4 and the ratio is 1:3, the parts are 1·4=4 and 3·4=12, matching the ratio and total 16.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the computed parts satisfy both the ratio and the total. This guards against algebraic or arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>For ratio 2:3 and total 25, you get x=5, parts 10 and 15. Verify 10+15=25 and 10:15=2:3.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of misreading “k times longer” vs. “k times as long.” The latter means one is k·(other), while the former can imply an additive difference.</description>
  <example>“3 times as long” means 3·x, whereas “3 feet longer” would be x+3. Mixing them leads to incorrect equations.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When a problem states that one quantity is a fraction of another, introduce variables for each quantity and express the relationship as an equation. For example, if A is 1/2 of B, write A = (1/2)·B. This sets up a clear algebraic link between the unknowns.</description>
  <example>Suppose two containers hold liquids in a ratio of 1:3. Let the first container hold x units and the second hold 3x units. This immediately encodes the “three times as much” relationship in algebraic form.</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>When multiple quantities are related by ratios or fractions, sum their expressions to form a total equation. If A = (1/2)·B and C = 2·A, then A + B + C = (1/2)B + B + 2·((1/2)B) = (1/2 + 1 + 1)B = (5/2)B. This consolidates all parts into one equation in terms of B.</description>
  <example>Imagine three piles of coins where pile 1 is half of pile 2, and pile 3 is twice pile 1. If the total coins are T, then T = (1/2)·P2 + P2 + 2·((1/2)·P2) = (5/2)·P2, giving a single equation in P2.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Use the total sum to solve for the base variable. From the equation (5/2)·B = T, isolate B by multiplying both sides by 2/5, yielding B = (2/5)·T. This step finds the value of the primary variable in terms of the total.</description>
  <example>Given (5/2)·P2 = T, multiply both sides by 2/5 to get P2 = (2/5)·T. This directly expresses the second quantity in terms of the total.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Once the base variable is known, compute any other quantity by substituting back into its defining relation. For instance, if C = 2·A and A = (1/2)·B, then C = 2·((1/2)·B) = B. This ensures consistency and avoids redundant calculations.</description>
  <example>After finding P2 = (2/5)·T, compute P3 = 2·P1 and P1 = (1/2)·P2, so P3 = 2·((1/2)·P2) = P2 = (2/5)·T. This yields P3 directly from the total.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Always verify that all parts sum to the given total and that each ratio or fraction is satisfied. Substituting back into the original relationships confirms the solution’s correctness and catches any algebraic mistakes.</description>
  <example>Check that P1 + P2 + P3 = (1/2)·P2 + P2 + 2·P1 = (5/2)·P2 = T. Since P2 = (2/5)·T, the sum indeed equals T, confirming the solution is consistent.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a total is split into two parts, the missing part equals the total minus the known part. This applies whenever you know the whole and one component. It works because addition is commutative and subtraction is its inverse.</description>
  <example>Suppose a container holds T items and you remove A items. The remaining items are T – A. For instance, if T = 100 and A = 45, then the leftover is 100 – 45 = 55.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When two disjoint subsets sum to a known total, the third subset equals the overall total minus the sum of those two. This is useful for partitioning data into three groups. It relies on the fact that the sum of all parts equals the whole.</description>
  <example>Imagine a survey of N people, where Group A has a responses and Group B has b responses. The remaining group C has N – (a + b) responses. For example, if N = 200, a = 80, b = 50, then c = 200 – (80 + 50) = 70.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all computed parts equals the original total. This check prevents arithmetic mistakes and ensures consistency. It works because the parts collectively reconstruct the whole.</description>
  <example>After finding parts x, y, and z, confirm x + y + z = T. For instance, if x = 30, y = 40, z = 50, then 30 + 40 + 50 = 120. If the total T was 120, the calculation is correct.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Watch for overlapping or non-disjoint subsets, as they can lead to double-counting. Ensure each element belongs to exactly one subset when applying subtraction. This avoids inflating or underestimating totals.</description>
  <example>If two groups share M elements, subtracting their sizes directly would remove those shared elements twice. Instead, use the inclusion-exclusion principle: |A ∪ B| = |A| + |B| – |A ∩ B|.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use algebraic variables to model the problem: let x, y, z represent unknown quantities, write equations based on given sums, and solve the system. This systematic approach clarifies relationships and reduces errors. It works for any linear partitioning problem.</description>
  <example>Let x, y, z be the counts on three days. Given x + y = S₁ and y + z = S₂, and total T = x + y + z, solve for z by noting z = T – (x + y) = T – S₁, then back-substitute to find x and y if needed.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When mixing two solutions, the total volume is the sum of each solution’s volume, and the total amount of solute is the sum of each solution’s solute amount. This holds regardless of the solute’s concentration.</description>
  <example>Suppose you mix 5 L of solution A (10% solute) with 3 L of solution B (20% solute). Total volume = 5 + 3 = 8 L. Total solute = 0.10·5 + 0.20·3 = 0.5 + 0.6 = 1.1 L.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>For a solution of concentration c (as a fraction), the amount of solute in V liters is c·V. This linear relation lets you compute solute amounts directly from volume and concentration.</description>
  <example>Given 10 L of a solution with 30% solute, the solute amount is 0.30·10 = 3 L. If you double the volume to 20 L, the solute becomes 0.30·20 = 6 L.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When you remove a portion of a solution, the removed solute amount is (removed volume)·(original concentration). This ensures you correctly account for solute loss when subtracting volume.</description>
  <example>You have 12 L of a 25% solute solution and spill 2 L. Solute removed = 0.25·2 = 0.5 L. Remaining solute = 0.25·12 – 0.5 = 3 – 0.5 = 2.5 L.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>After any addition or removal, the new concentration is (total solute)/(total volume). Use this to find the final concentration of the mixture.</description>
  <example>After mixing 8 L of 15% solute and 12 L of 25% solute, total solute = 0.15·8 + 0.25·12 = 1.2 + 3 = 4.2 L. Total volume = 20 L. New concentration = 4.2/20 = 21%.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the final volume matches the stated total. If it doesn’t, re-examine addition/removal steps to ensure no volume was miscounted.</description>
  <example>You mix 7 L of solution A and 5 L of solution B, then remove 1 L. Expected final volume = 7 + 5 – 1 = 11 L. If you later find 10 L, you must revisit the removal step.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentage statements into decimal multipliers by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply fractions of a quantity directly.</description>
  <example>“x% of a quantity” becomes x/100 × quantity. For instance, 40% of Q is 0.40 × Q.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply successive percentage multipliers by multiplying the decimals. The overall effect is the product of each fraction.</description>
  <example>If 60% of a resource is used and then 30% of that is allocated, the total fraction is 0.60 × 0.30 = 0.18, or 18% of the original.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the complement rule: if a percentage p is used, the remainder is 100% – p. This is useful for finding unused or non-target portions.</description>
  <example>After using 70% of a resource, the leftover is 100% – 70% = 30% of the original.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a percentage of a percentage is asked, multiply the two decimals. This avoids adding percentages directly.</description>
  <example>“20% of 50%” is 0.20 × 0.50 = 0.10, or 10% of the whole.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that your final percentage is ≤100%. If it exceeds, re-examine the multiplication or complement steps for errors.</description>
  <example>Multiplying 0.80 × 0.75 gives 0.60, which is ≤100%, so the result is valid. If it were 0.85 × 0.75 = 0.6375, still ≤100%, but if it were 0.85 × 1.20 = 1.02, you’d know something’s wrong.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the weighted average formula: total cost = (number₁ × price₁) + (number₂ × price₂). This applies whenever you have two groups with different quantities and unit prices.</description>
  <example>For 10 items at $3 each and 15 items at $5 each, total = 10×3 + 15×5 = 30 + 75 = 105.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Break the problem into two parts: compute each group’s subtotal separately, then sum them. This clarifies the calculation and reduces errors.</description>
  <example>Group A: 8 units at $4 → subtotal = 8×4 = 32. Group B: 12 units at $6 → subtotal = 12×6 = 72. Total = 32 + 72 = 104.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Check unit consistency: ensure all quantities and prices use the same units (e.g., items vs. dollars). Mixing units leads to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one group is in “pieces” and another in “units,” convert both to the same unit before multiplying by price.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property: total = (number₁ + number₂) × average_price, where average_price = (price₁ + price₂)/2. This can simplify when prices are close.</description>
  <example>For 10 at $3 and 15 at $5, average_price = (3+5)/2 = 4. Total = (10+15)×4 = 25×4 = 100. (Note: this is an approximation; exact = 105.)</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check: compare the total to the sum of extremes (all at the lower price vs. all at the higher price). The computed total should lie between these two extremes.</description>
  <example>For 10 at $3 and 15 at $5, all at $3 gives 25×3 = 75, all at $5 gives 25×5 = 125. The computed 105 lies between 75 and 125, so it’s plausible.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a total is given, compute it by multiplying the total by the fraction. This applies whenever a part is described as a fraction of the whole.</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, if one third are selected, the count is T × (1/3). For instance, if T = 12, then selected = 12 × (1/3) = 4.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a fraction, multiply the two fractions. This is useful when a subset of a subset is described.</description>
  <example>If one half of a group is chosen, and then one third of that chosen group is further selected, the final fraction is (1/2) × (1/3) = 1/6 of the original group.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always simplify fractions before multiplying to reduce arithmetic complexity. Simplification can turn a complex product into a simpler one.</description>
  <example>Instead of computing (2/5) × (3/4), note that 2 and 4 share a factor 2, so (2/5) × (3/4) = (1/5) × (3/2) = 3/10.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check that the computed part does not exceed the total. If a fraction is greater than 1, it indicates an error in interpretation or setup.</description>
  <example>If you calculate 5/4 of a total of 20, you get 25, which exceeds 20. This signals a mistake in the fraction or total.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a variable for the total to keep expressions general. This helps in applying the same method to different totals without re-deriving the steps.</description>
  <example>Let T be the total. If one quarter are selected, the count is T × (1/4). If then one half of that is chosen, it becomes T × (1/4) × (1/2) = T/8.</example>
</note5>

Define variables for total jellyfish (T) and large jellyfish (L = T/6). Translate “a quarter of the large change color” into L/4 = 8. Solve L = 32, then T = 6·L = 192. Check that 32/4 = 8 and that 32/6 of T are large.

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute the total by multiplying each category’s count by its value, then summing. This aggregates all contributions before averaging.</description>
  <example>For 4 items at value A and 2 items at value B, total = 4·A + 2·B. This sum represents the combined total of all items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Count the total number of items by summing all category counts. This gives the denominator for the average.</description>
  <example>With 4 items in one group and 2 in another, total items = 4 + 2. This count is used to divide the total sum.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the average formula: average = (sum of all values) ÷ (number of items). This yields the mean of the dataset.</description>
  <example>Using total = 4·A + 2·B and total items = 6, average = (4·A + 2·B) ÷ 6. This gives the mean value of all items.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for weighted average: when categories have different counts, the average is a weighted mean, not a simple arithmetic mean.</description>
  <example>Equal counts would give (A + B) ÷ 2, but unequal counts give (4·A + 2·B) ÷ 6, reflecting each category’s influence.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by cross-multiplying: if you multiply the computed average by the total count, you should recover the original total sum.</description>
  <example>Compute avg = (4·A + 2·B) ÷ 6, then check 6·avg = 4·A + 2·B. If both sides match, the calculation is correct.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is described as “a more than b,” translate it to the algebraic expression a + b. This handles phrases like “7 more than” or “5 less than” by directly adding or subtracting the given amounts.</description>
  <example>Suppose one person reads x pages and another reads y pages. If the first reads 3 more than the second, represent that as (x = y + 3). This ensures you capture the exact relationship in your equations.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “a times b,” translate it to the product a·b. This applies to phrases like “twice as many” or “three times as many,” converting them into multiplication in your model.</description>
  <example>If one person reads twice as many pages as another, and the other reads y pages, write x = 2·y. This captures the proportional relationship directly in your equations.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “a times b plus c,” translate it to a·b + c. This handles phrases like “twice as many plus 5” by combining multiplication and addition in one step.</description>
  <example>If one person reads twice as many pages as another plus 5 extra pages, and the other reads y pages, write x = 2·y + 5. This ensures you include both the proportional and additional parts in your model.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “a times b minus c,” translate it to a·b – c. This applies to phrases like “three times as many minus 4,” converting them into subtraction in your equations.</description>
  <example>If one person reads three times as many pages as another minus 4 pages, and the other reads y pages, write x = 3·y – 4. This captures the proportional reduction directly in your model.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>After forming equations, solve for the unknowns by substitution or elimination. Then compute the required difference or ratio by subtracting or dividing the solved values.</description>
  <example>Given x = y + 3 and x = 2·y, substitute to get y + 3 = 2·y, solve y = 3, then x = 6. Finally, find the difference x – y = 3.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a problem states “half of a quantity,” compute it by dividing the quantity by 2. This applies to any scenario where a value is split into two equal parts.</description>
  <example>For a quantity Q, half of Q is Q/2. For instance, if Q = 10, then half of Q is 10/2 = 5.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a problem says “a number more than” another, add the specified amount to the base value. This handles any additive relationship.</description>
  <example>If a base value is B and you need B plus M, compute B + M. For example, if B = 7 and M = 4, then B + M = 11.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a problem involves “a number less than” another, subtract the specified amount from the base value. This handles any subtractive relationship.</description>
  <example>If a base value is B and you need B minus M, compute B – M. For example, if B = 12 and M = 5, then B – M = 7.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a problem asks for the total of two quantities, add them together. This is the fundamental principle of summing parts to form a whole.</description>
  <example>For quantities A and B, the total is A + B. For instance, if A = 6 and B = 9, then A + B = 15.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify your result by re-reading the problem and checking that each step matches the wording. This helps catch misinterpretations or arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>After computing X = (Q/2) + M and Y = Q + X, restate the problem: “half of Q plus M equals X, and Q plus X equals total.” Confirm each step aligns with the original description.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use unit rates to convert between quantities and units. Divide total units by the number of items to find how much of each unit is needed per item.</description>
  <example>For 3 small masks using 3 yards, each small mask uses 3/3=1 yard. For 3 large masks using 4.5 yards, each large mask uses 4.5/3=1.5 yards.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total material for a batch by multiplying the unit rate by the number of items. This scales linearly with quantity.</description>
  <example>With 1 yard per small mask, 15 small masks require 15×1=15 yards. With 1.5 yards per large mask, 6 large masks require 6×1.5=9 yards.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum the material requirements of each category to get the total. This works because material needs are additive.</description>
  <example>Adding 15 yards for small masks and 9 yards for large masks gives 15+9=24 yards total.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that the unit rates match across similar items. Inconsistent rates indicate a modeling error.</description>
  <example>If small and large masks were both supposed to use the same material per mask, their unit rates should be equal; otherwise, re-examine the data.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a ratio table to organize and compare different batch sizes. This helps ensure proportional scaling.</description>
  <example>Set up a table with rows for small and large masks, columns for number of items and material, then fill in known values and scale up to the desired batch.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When a quantity changes by a fixed amount, represent the new total as the original plus that change. This models simple additions or subtractions in word problems.</description>
  <example>Starting with N items, if you add M more, the new count is N + M. For instance, if you have 5 apples and buy 3, you have 5 + 3 = 8 apples.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “twice as many” as another, express it as 2 × (the other quantity). This captures multiplicative relationships.</description>
  <example>If there are X chairs in one room and the next room has twice as many, then the second room has 2 × X chairs. For example, if X = 4, then 2 × 4 = 8 chairs.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>When items are removed, subtract the removal count from the current total. This models simple subtractions in word problems.</description>
  <example>With Y items, if you remove Z, the remaining count is Y – Z. For instance, if you have 10 books and give away 3, you have 10 – 3 = 7 books.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Break a multi-step problem into sequential steps, updating the quantity after each change. This ensures you account for all additions and subtractions in order.</description>
  <example>Start with A items, add B, then remove C: total = A + B – C. For example, if A = 6, B = 2, C = 1, then 6 + 2 – 1 = 7 items.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>After modeling each step, verify that the final expression matches the problem’s description. This check prevents misinterpretation of relationships.</description>
  <example>If the problem says “after adding and then removing,” ensure your expression is of the form (original + addition) – removal. For instance, if original = 5, addition = 3, removal = 2, then 5 + 3 – 2 = 6, which matches the verbal description.</example>
</note6>
Break the total into separate categories by multiplying each quantity by its unit price, then sum the results. 这个方法适用于任何有多个项目和不同单价的求和问题。

<note1>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying unit cost by quantity. Use C = (total supplies cost) ÷ (number of units produced) to find cost per unit.</description>
  <example>Suppose supplies cost $60 to make 12 units. Then cost per unit = 60 ÷ 12 = $5.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Compute total revenue by multiplying unit price by quantity sold. Use R = (price per unit) × (number of units sold).</description>
  <example>If each unit sells for $4 and 15 units are sold, then revenue = 4 × 15 = $60.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Compute profit by subtracting total cost from total revenue. Use P = R – C.</description>
  <example>With revenue of $60 and cost of $50, profit = 60 – 50 = $10.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Convert profit over time by dividing total profit by time. Use P_per_time = P ÷ (time in hours).</description>
  <example>If total profit is $100 and the operation lasts 5 hours, then profit per hour = 100 ÷ 5 = $20.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Check consistency: ensure all units (cost, price, quantity, time) are in the same system before combining. Convert if necessary.</description>
  <example>If cost is in dollars per unit but time is in minutes, convert minutes to hours before computing hourly profit.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the average formula to find total count: if the average of n items is A, then total = n × A. This works whenever you know the mean and the number of items.</description>
  <example>Suppose a class has an average of 25 students and there are 10 classes. The total number of students is 10 × 25 = 250.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the weighted average for two groups: if group A has size n₁ and group B has size n₂, and their averages are A₁ and A₂, then the overall average A = (n₁·A₁ + n₂·A₂)/(n₁ + n₂). Use this to combine different rates or contributions.</description>
  <example>Group A has 10 students with an average score of 80, and Group B has 15 students with an average score of 90. The overall average is (10·80 + 15·90)/(10 + 15) = (800 + 1350)/25 = 86.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When each item of type X contributes a units and each item of type Y contributes b units, the total contribution = nₓ·a + nᵧ·b. This is a direct application of multiplication and addition for different rates.</description>
  <example>If each student plants 1 tree and each teacher plants 2 trees, and there are 20 students and 5 teachers, the total trees = 20·1 + 5·2 = 30.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify sums: n·(a + b) = n·a + n·b. This can reduce repeated multiplication when the same multiplier applies to multiple terms.</description>
  <example>Instead of computing 10·3 + 10·7, compute 10·(3 + 7) = 10·10 = 100, which is faster and less error-prone.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all quantities are in the same units before adding or multiplying. Mismatched units can lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one rate is given per hour and another per day, convert both to the same time unit (e.g., hours) before summing their contributions.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the unitary method: multiply each quantity by its unit price to find the cost of that item, then sum all individual costs. This works for any scenario with multiple items at different rates.</description>
  <example>For 2 units at $5 each and 3 units at $7 each, compute 2×5=10 and 3×7=21, then sum to get 31.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the distributive property: group items by price to simplify multiplication. For example, (a·p₁ + b·p₁) + (c·p₂ + d·p₂) = (a+b)·p₁ + (c+d)·p₂.</description>
  <example>With 2 at $5 and 3 at $5, and 4 at $2 and 1 at $2, group as (2+3)·5 + (4+1)·2 = 5·5 + 5·2 = 25 + 10 = 35.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use a single-variable equation: let x be the total cost, then write x = q₁·p₁ + q₂·p₂ + … and solve. This is useful when you need to verify or extend the calculation.</description>
  <example>Set x = 2·5 + 3·7 + 4·2. Compute each term and sum to find x = 10 + 21 + 8 = 39.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for unit consistency: ensure all quantities and prices share the same units before multiplying. Mismatched units lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one price is per kilo and another is per pound, convert both to the same unit (e.g., convert pounds to kilos) before summing.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a quick sanity check: compare the total to the sum of the largest and smallest individual costs or to a rounded estimate. This helps catch arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>For costs 10, 21, and 8, the sum is 39. A quick check: 10 + 21 = 31, 31 + 8 = 39, confirming the total.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Define variables for each unknown quantity and express total contributions as a linear combination of these variables. This sets up the equation that models the problem.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have x items of type A and y items of type B, and each A contributes a units while each B contributes b units. The total contribution is a·x + b·y.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the given total to form a linear equation in the variables. This equation captures the sum of all contributions or counts.</description>
  <example>If the total contribution is T, then from a·x + b·y = T you get the equation a·x + b·y = T, which you can solve alongside any other constraints.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the substitution method: solve one equation for one variable and substitute into the other to reduce the system to a single-variable equation.</description>
  <example>From x + y = N, solve x = N – y, then substitute into a·x + b·y = T to get a·(N – y) + b·y = T, yielding a single equation in y.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the elimination method: multiply equations by constants so that adding or subtracting them eliminates one variable, then solve for the remaining variable.</description>
  <example>Given a·x + b·y = T and x + y = N, multiply the second by a to get a·x + a·y = a·N, then subtract from the first to eliminate x and solve for y.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check that the solution is an integer and nonnegative, and that it satisfies any additional constraints (e.g., counts must be whole numbers).</description>
  <example>After finding y = (T – a·N)/(b – a), verify that (T – a·N) is divisible by (b – a) and that y ≥ 0, then compute x = N – y.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “k times” another, represent it as k·x. This captures multiplicative relationships directly in algebraic form.</description>
  <example>For instance, if one person’s age is twice another’s, set the first age = 2·x and the second = x.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>“p% of” a quantity equals (p/100)·x. Use this to convert percentage statements into algebraic expressions.</description>
  <example>If someone is 50% younger than another, their age = x – (50/100)·x = 0.5·x.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Translate each verbal relationship into an equation. This ensures you capture all given conditions before solving.</description>
  <example>Given “A is twice B” and “C is 50% younger than A,” write A = 2B and C = 0.5A.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Sum all individual expressions to find a total. This is useful for cumulative questions like “total age” or “total cost.”</description>
  <example>With A = 2B, C = 0.5A, the total = A + B + C = 2B + B + 0.5·(2B) = 4B.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all quantities use the same unit and that the final expression matches the question’s request.</description>
  <example>Confirm that ages are in years and that the total is expressed in the same unit (years).</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any percentage to a decimal by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply by the total quantity to find the portion.</description>
  <example>For a 40% portion of 50 items, compute 40/100 = 0.40, then 0.40 × 50 = 20 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When quantities are scaled by a factor k, multiply the original count by k to get the new total. This applies to ordering, production, or any proportional change.</description>
  <example>If you have 20 units and order twice as many, compute 20 × 2 = 40 units.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute the remaining portion by subtracting the consumed portion from the total: remaining = total – (percentage × total). This works for any scenario with a known consumption rate.</description>
  <example>With 40 items and 75% eaten, compute 0.75 × 40 = 30 eaten, then 40 – 30 = 10 left.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the complement of a percentage to find the leftover directly: leftover = (1 – percentage) × total. This is a shortcut when you know the consumption rate.</description>
  <example>For 60% eaten, the leftover is (1 – 0.60) × total = 0.40 × total.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that your final count is nonnegative and does not exceed the total. This guards against arithmetic or rounding errors.</description>
  <example>If you calculate 15 left but the total was only 10, recheck your percentage or multiplication step.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the basic distance formula: distance = rate × time. This applies whenever an object moves at a constant speed. It works because distance accumulates linearly with time at a fixed rate.</description>
  <example>For a trip at 8 mph for 2 hours, compute distance = 8 × 2 = 16 miles.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Break multi-leg journeys into segments and compute each segment’s distance separately. Then sum the results to get the total. This modular approach simplifies complex routes.</description>
  <example>If a cyclist goes 5 mph for 1 hour and then 7 mph for 2 hours, compute 5 × 1 = 5 miles and 7 × 2 = 14 miles, then total = 5 + 14 = 19 miles.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Account for rest periods by excluding them from the time calculation. Only active travel time contributes to distance. This prevents overestimating total distance.</description>
  <example>If someone rides for 3 hours, rests for 1 hour, and then rides for 4 more hours, total travel time = 3 + 4 = 7 hours, not 12.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check units consistency: ensure rate is in distance/time units and time is in matching time units. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results. Always convert if necessary.</description>
  <example>If speed is given in km/h and time in minutes, convert minutes to hours (e.g., 30 min = 0.5 h) before multiplying.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use the average speed formula when multiple segments have different rates: average speed = total distance ÷ total time. This gives a single rate for the entire journey.</description>
  <example>For a 10-mile trip at 5 mph and a 20-mile trip at 10 mph, total distance = 30 miles, total time = 2 + 2 = 4 h, so average speed = 30 ÷ 4 = 7.5 mph.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is described as “k fewer than” another, represent it as Q₁ – k. This captures the difference directly in algebraic form.</description>
  <example>For instance, if A has 100 items and B has 20 fewer, then B = 100 – 20 = 80. This sets up the initial relationship for further operations.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translating “gives” or “receives” into algebra: if X gives y units to Y, then X → X – y and Y → Y + y. This models transfers clearly.</description>
  <example>Suppose X has 80 units and gives 10 to Y. Then X becomes 80 – 10 = 70, and Y becomes Y + 10. This keeps track of each party’s new count.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>After transfers, compute the new difference by subtracting the updated quantities: (Q₁_new – Q₂_new). This yields the final comparative gap.</description>
  <example>With X = 70 and Y = 80 + 10 = 90, the difference is 70 – 90 = –20, meaning Y has 20 more than X. The sign indicates which side is larger.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check for sign conventions: a negative result means the second quantity is larger, while a positive result means the first is larger. Clarify “fewer” vs. “more” in context.</description>
  <example>If the difference is –15, it means the second party has 15 more, not fewer. Thus, “fewer” apples would be the absolute value, 15.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use absolute value when the question asks for “how many fewer” or “how many more,” regardless of sign. This ensures the answer is nonnegative.</description>
  <example>From a difference of –15, the number of fewer apples is |–15| = 15. This aligns with the question’s wording of “fewer.”</example>
</note5>

<cheatsheet>
  <note1>
    <description>Compute the percentage error by dividing the observed deviation by the intended value and multiplying by 100. This gives the percent by which the actual differs from the target.</description>
    <example>For an intended value of 100 and an observed value of 110, the error is (110–100)/100×100=10%.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>Convert a percentage error into a decimal multiplier by adding or subtracting the percent (as a decimal) from 1. Use 1±p/100 to scale any intended value.</description>
    <example>A 10% overestimate corresponds to a multiplier of 1+0.10=1.10; a 10% underestimate uses 1–0.10=0.90.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Apply the multiplier to the intended value to obtain the observed value. This directly accounts for the consistent percentage shift.</description>
    <example>With a 10% overestimate multiplier 1.10, an intended 100 becomes 100×1.10=110.</example>
  </note5>
  <note6>
    <description>When the target is unknown but the observed value and error percent are known, divide the observed value by the multiplier to recover the intended value.</description>
    <example>If an observed 110 corresponds to a 10% overestimate (multiplier 1.10), then the intended value is 110/1.10=100.</example>
  </note7>
  <note8>
    <description>Always check that the computed intended or observed value makes sense in context (e.g., non-negative, within reasonable bounds) to catch sign or rounding errors.</description>
    <example>After computing an intended value of 100 from an observed 110 with a 10% overestimate, verify that 100×1.10 indeed equals 110.</example>
  </note9>
</cheatsheet>

<note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a group is selected, compute the count by multiplying the total size by the fraction. This applies to any subset defined by a proportional rule.</description>
  <example>For a group of size N, if one-third are chosen, the count is N × (1/3). For instance, if N = 12, then 12 × (1/3) = 4.</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>When multiple groups have different fractions selected, compute each separately and then sum the results to find the total number of selected items across all groups.</description>
  <example>Group A has size N₁ and one-fourth are chosen (N₁ × 1/4), Group B has size N₂ and one-fifth are chosen (N₂ × 1/5). The total selected is (N₁ × 1/4) + (N₂ × 1/5).</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>When two or more categories overlap, use the inclusion-exclusion principle: Total = (A) + (B) – (A ∩ B). This ensures double-counting of common elements is corrected.</description>
  <example>If 5 students are in both choir and drama, and 8 are in choir, 7 are in drama, then the total in at least one is 8 + 7 – 5 = 10.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>To find the number of items not in a particular subset, subtract the count of that subset from the total. This is the complement principle in set theory.</description>
  <example>Given a total of N items and k items in a subset, the number not in that subset is N – k. For example, if N = 20 and k = 6, then 20 – 6 = 14.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>When extracurricular activities or categories do not affect a primary count, treat those categories as independent and ignore their overlap or total when computing the primary subset.</description>
  <example>If the number of students in choir or drama does not change the count of students on the varsity team, you can compute the varsity team count solely from the fraction of the total and ignore any overlap or additional categories.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert total payments into a single sum by adding the advance payment to the product of the number of installments and the installment amount. This gives the total cost of each offer.</description>
  <example>For an offer with an advance of A and n installments of P each, the total cost is A + n·P. For instance, if A=100 and n=4, P=50, then total=100+4·50=300.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the formula for the sum of an arithmetic series when installments form an arithmetic progression: S = n·(first term + last term)/2. This is useful if installments increase or decrease by a constant amount.</description>
  <example>If installments are 20, 25, 30, 35, then n=4, first=20, last=35, so S=4·(20+35)/2=4·55/2=110.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compare two total costs by subtracting the smaller from the larger. This yields the cost difference between the two offers.</description>
  <example>If Offer A costs 300 and Offer B costs 250, then the difference is 300–250=50.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for hidden fees or conditions (e.g., interest, late fees) that aren’t included in the stated advance and installments. Always read the fine print to avoid miscalculations.</description>
  <example>If an offer states “no interest” but the installments are higher than the advertised price, there may be an unmentioned interest charge. Always verify.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by re-deriving the total cost using a different method (e.g., summing each installment separately) to catch arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>For installments 50, 50, 50, 50, sum=50+50+50+50=200. If you previously got 250, you know there was a mistake.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a percentage into a decimal by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply it with totals to find fractional amounts.</description>

2. <note2>
  <description>When two people share a cost equally, each pays half. For any equal split, use 1/2 or 0.5 of the total.</description>

You should compute the distance between two points by adding the two given segments (e.g., 3 miles + 4 miles = 7 miles) and ignore the break’s duration.</example>

<note2>
  <description>Apply a percentage fee by multiplying the subtotal by the fee rate (expressed as a decimal). This yields the additional charge for services like delivery.</description>
  <example>With a 15% service fee on a subtotal S, the fee is 0.15·S.</example>
</note1>
<note3>
  <description>Handle free items by excluding them from both the subtotal and any fee calculations. Only paid items contribute to the total cost.</description>
  <example>If 2 items are free, their unit prices and quantities are ignored when computing S and the service fee.</example>
</note1>
<note4>
  <description>Compute a tip by adding a fixed amount to the subtotal. This is a straightforward addition of a per-item or per-order tip.</description>
  <example>Adding a $2.00 tip to a subtotal S results in S + 2.00.</example>
</note1>
<note5>
  <description>When a discount is not applicable, treat it as zero. The final total remains the sum of subtotal, fees, and any fixed additions.</description>
  <example>If a 10% discount is invalid, the total is subtotal + service fee + tip without subtracting any discount.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all time units to a single base unit (e.g. minutes) to simplify rate calculations. This ensures consistency when adding or comparing rates over different intervals.</description>
  <example>Suppose a process takes 1 hour and 30 minutes. Convert to minutes: 1 h × 60 min/h + 30 min = 90 min. Then compute rates per minute for further analysis.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute net production rate by subtracting loss rate from generation rate. If you produce P units per time unit and lose L units per time unit, the net rate is (P – L) units per time unit.</description>
  <example>Machine makes 50 units/hour but loses 10 units/hour. Net rate = 50 – 10 = 40 units/hour. Use this net rate in further time or quantity calculations.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the linear relation Q = R × T to find time or quantity. Here Q is the total amount, R is the rate, and T is the time. Rearrange as T = Q/R or Q = R × T as needed.</description>
  <example>To reach 120 units at a net rate of 40 units/hour, compute T = 120 / 40 = 3 hours. This gives the time required to accumulate the desired quantity.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Account for periodic events by treating them as discrete intervals. If an event occurs every k units of time and has effect E, compute its total effect over T as ⌊T/k⌋ × E.</description>
  <example>A process loses 2 units every 15 minutes. Over 60 minutes, it occurs 60/15 = 4 times, so total loss = 4 × 2 = 8 units. Subtract this from the generated amount.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
