  <description>Find the final price by subtracting the discount amount from the original price. This yields the net cost after the reduction.</description>
  <example>After finding a $30 discount on a $200 item, subtract: 200 – 30 = $170, giving the final price.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Alternatively, compute the final price directly by multiplying the original price by (1 – decimal percentage). This combines both steps into one.</description>
  <example>For a 15% discount on $200, calculate 200 × (1 – 0.15) = 200 × 0.85 = $170.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the final price is less than or equal to the original price. This ensures the discount was applied correctly.</description>
  <example>If you get a final price of $210 after a 15% discount on $200, recompute to catch an error, since $210 is higher than $200.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When comparing two quantities, subtract the smaller from the larger to find the difference. This works for any two values, regardless of context.</description>
  <example>Quantity A = 100, Quantity B = 75. The difference is 100 – 75 = 25.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a total, multiply the total by the fraction. This applies whenever you need a part of a whole.</description>
  <example>Total = 100, fraction = 3/4. The part is 100 × (3/4) = 75.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always simplify fractions before performing arithmetic to reduce errors and make calculations easier. Simplification involves dividing numerator and denominator by their greatest common divisor.</description>
  <example>Fraction = 6/8. Divide both by 2 to get 3/4, then compute 100 × (3/4) = 75.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check your result by reversing the operation: if you found a part, divide that part by the fraction to see if you recover the original total. This ensures consistency.</description>
  <example>Part = 75, fraction = 3/4. Compute 75 ÷ (3/4) = 75 × (4/3) = 100, matching the original total.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>When the question asks “how much greater,” ensure you subtract in the correct order: larger – smaller. Reversing the order gives the wrong sign or magnitude.</description>
  <example>Quantity A = 100, Quantity B = 75. The correct difference is 100 – 75 = 25, not 75 – 100 = –25.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When an item has a buy-one-get-one (BOGO) deal with a fixed discount, treat each pair as two items: the first at full price and the second at the discount rate. The total cost for n items is (n/2)×(full_price + discount_price).</description>
  <example>For a BOGO 25% off on 10 items at $100 each, compute (10/2)×(100 + 0.75×100) = 5×175 = $875.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>To apply a percentage discount, convert the percentage to a decimal and multiply by the original price: sale_price = original_price × (1 – discount_rate).</description>
  <example>For a 30% discount on an item priced at $200, compute 200 × 0.70 = $140.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When multiple discounts apply sequentially, multiply the remaining rates: final_price = original_price × (1 – d1) × (1 – d2) × ….</description>
  <example>Applying a 20% discount then a 10% discount on $150 gives 150 × 0.80 × 0.90 = $108.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Always check for special conditions like “buy one get one free” or “buy one get one half off” to avoid miscounting items. Ensure you count each pair correctly before applying the discount.</description>
  <example>For a BOGO free on 8 items, treat them as 4 pairs, so 4×(full_price + 0) rather than 8×full_price.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>After computing subtotals, sum them to get the grand total. Verify that no item was omitted or double-counted in the subtotal calculations.</description>
  <example>If subtotal1 = $300 and subtotal2 = $250, then total = 300 + 250 = $550.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Identify the total requirement and the sum of existing items. The amount to purchase is the difference between the total needed and the sum of what you already have.</description>
  <example>Suppose you need T items in total and you currently have A and B items. Then the number to buy is T – (A + B).</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the subtraction principle: when you know a whole and its parts, subtract the known parts from the whole to find the missing part. This applies to any additive context.</description>
  <example>If a container holds C units and you remove D units, the remaining amount is C – D.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that the sum of purchased items and existing items equals the total requirement. This ensures no arithmetic error.</description>
  <example>After buying X more items, confirm that (A + B + X) = T to ensure you meet the requirement.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Watch for off-by-one errors when counting discrete items. Always ensure you count each item exactly once and include all required categories.</description>
  <example>If you count 10 items but one is missing, recount to avoid underestimating the total needed.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use estimation to quickly verify your answer. Round numbers to the nearest convenient value and check that the rounded difference is close to your computed result.</description>
  <example>Round T to T′, A to A′, and B to B′, then compute T′ – (A′ + B′). If this is near your exact answer, you’re likely correct.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Model each item’s cost as a variable and express the total cost as a linear combination of these variables. This sets up the equation needed to solve for unknown quantities.</description>
  <example>For two types of tickets priced at p₁ and p₂, the cost for x₁ of the first and x₂ of the second is C = p₁·x₁ + p₂·x₂. If x₁=1 and x₂=1, then C = p₁ + p₂.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the relationship between total payment, cost, and change: Total = Cost + Change. This ensures you account for all money involved in the transaction.</description>
  <example>If the cost of items is C and the change returned is R, then the amount paid is P = C + R. For instance, if C = 200 and R = 50, then P = 250.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Substitute the cost expression into the payment equation to solve for the unknown payment. This reduces the problem to a single-variable equation.</description>
  <example>Given P = (p₁ + p₂) + R, substitute the known values of p₁, p₂, and R to find P. For example, if p₁ + p₂ = 200 and R = 50, then P = 250.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always verify your solution by plugging it back into the original cost and change equations. This confirms consistency and catches arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding P = 250, check that 250 – (p₁ + p₂) = R. If p₁ + p₂ = 200 and R = 50, then 250 – 200 = 50, confirming the solution.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of sign conventions: ensure you treat change as a positive amount subtracted from the payment. Misplacing a sign can lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If the cost is C and the change is R, write P = C + R, not P = C – R. For instance, if C = 200 and R = 50, then P = 200 + 50 = 250, not 150.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all measurements to a single unit before computing area. Use the conversion factor (e.g., 12 inches = 1 foot) to avoid unit mismatches.</description>
  <example>Given a rectangle of length L inches and width W inches, convert to feet by computing L/12 and W/12, then multiply to get area in square feet.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute the area of a rectangle by multiplying its length and width. This applies to any rectangular region.</description>
  <example>For a rectangle with length L and width W, the area is A = L × W. If L and W are in the same unit, A is in square units.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When dimensions are increased by a fixed amount, use the expanded rectangle formula: (L + d) × (W + d). This accounts for the added border or margin.</description>
  <example>For a base rectangle of length L and width W, adding a border of width d yields area A = (L + d) × (W + d).</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to expand (L + d)(W + d) = LW + dL + dW + d². This separates the original area from the added border area.</description>
  <example>Expanding (L + d)(W + d) gives A = LW + d(L + W) + d², so you can compute each term separately.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and perform a sanity check: the expanded area should be larger than the original by the area of the added border.</description>
  <example>After computing A = (L + d)(W + d), verify that A – LW equals the area of the border, i.e., d(L + W) + d².</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total items needed by multiplying the number of recipients by the per-item consumption. This gives the raw demand before accounting for leftovers or existing stock.</description>
  <example>For 15 guests each eating 3 items, total needed = 15 × 3 = 45 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Adjust the raw demand by adding any leftover items or subtracting existing stock. This yields the net quantity to purchase.</description>
  <example>If raw demand is 45 items and you have 10 leftovers, net purchase = 45 – 10 = 35 items.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Convert the net quantity into full units by dividing by the size of each unit and rounding up. Use the ceiling function to ensure you buy enough units.</description>
  <example>With 35 items and packs of 10, units needed = ceil(35/10) = 4 packs.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Calculate total cost by multiplying the number of units by the unit price. This gives the final expenditure.</description>
  <example>For 4 packs at $2 each, total cost = 4 × 2 = $8.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by checking that the purchased units meet or exceed the net demand and that no fractional units are used. This ensures no under- or over-purchasing.</description>
  <example>4 packs of 10 give 40 items, which covers the 35 needed, confirming correctness.</example>
</note5>
Convert all measurements to a single unit before summing. This avoids unit mismatches and simplifies arithmetic.
Start with the initial count and apply each change in sequence, updating the total after each stop.
Convert all distances to the same unit before subtracting. Use 1 km = 1000 m to avoid unit mismatches.

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute the total width by multiplying the width of one window by the number of windows. This applies whenever you have identical items and need the combined measure.</description>
  <example>For 5 windows each 20 inches wide, total width = 5 × 20 = 100 inches.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply a scaling factor by multiplying the total quantity by the given multiplier. This is used when the requirement is a fixed multiple of the base total.</description>
  <example>If you need fabric equal to 3 times the total width of 100 inches, fabric needed = 3 × 100 = 300 inches.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions like k × (n × w). You can compute n × w first and then multiply by k, or distribute k over n and w if needed.</description>
  <example>For 4 windows each 15 inches wide, total = 4 × 15 = 60 inches; then 2 × 60 = 120 inches, or 2 × 4 × 15 = 120 inches.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check units consistency: ensure all measurements use the same unit before combining. Convert if necessary to avoid errors.</description>
  <example>If one window is given in feet and another in inches, convert feet to inches (1 foot = 12 inches) before summing.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify the result by reversing the steps: divide the final quantity by the scaling factor to recover the base total, then divide by the number of items to check individual measures.</description>
  <example>If you found 240 inches of fabric for 3 windows, divide 240 by 3 to get 80 inches per window, then multiply by 3 to confirm 240 inches.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total work by multiplying rate (items per unit time) by time (units). This gives the number of items completed in a given period.</description>
  <example>At a rate of r items/hour for t hours, total completed = r × t. For instance, at 8 items/hour for 3 hours, completed = 8 × 3 = 24 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Find remaining items by subtracting completed items from the total. This yields the number of items left unfinished.</description>
  <example>If total items = T and completed = C, then remaining = T – C. For example, if T = 50 and C = 30, remaining = 50 – 30 = 20 items.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the unitary method: determine how many items are done in one unit of time, then scale to the given time. This is useful when rates are constant.</description>
  <example>At r items/hour, in one hour completed = r. For t hours, completed = r × t. If r = 5 and t = 4, then completed = 5 × 4 = 20 items.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check feasibility by comparing total time available to time required. If required time exceeds available, the task cannot be fully completed.</description>
  <example>For rate r and total items T, required time = T / r. If available time is t, compare T / r ≤ t. For instance, if T = 60 and r = 10, required = 6 hours; if t = 5, task is impossible.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>When multiple tasks share the same rate, sum their times to get total time, then compute total completed across tasks. This aggregates work over different periods.</description>
  <example>Task A: r items/hour for t₁ hours → C₁ = r × t₁. Task B: r items/hour for t₂ hours → C₂ = r × t₂. Total completed = C₁ + C₂. If r = 7, t₁ = 2, t₂ = 3, then C₁ = 14, C₂ = 21, total = 35.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is given as a fraction of a reference, multiply the reference by that fraction to find the actual value. This works because “fraction of” means the reference times the fraction.</description>
  <example>Suppose a reference length is L and you need a segment that is 3/5 of L. Compute (3/5)·L to get the segment’s length.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When adding multiple fractional parts of the same reference, sum the fractions first, then multiply by the reference. This avoids computing each part separately and reduces arithmetic steps.</description>
  <example>If you need 1/4 + 1/3 of a reference R, compute (1/4 + 1/3)·R = (7/12)·R in one step.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always simplify fractions before multiplying to keep numbers small and reduce errors. Simplification uses the greatest common divisor of numerator and denominator.</description>
  <example>To compute (6/8)·R, simplify 6/8 to 3/4, then multiply: (3/4)·R.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check that the sum of all fractional parts does not exceed 1 (or the whole reference). If it does, the total exceeds the reference, indicating a modeling error.</description>
  <example>If you have parts 1/2 and 2/3 of R, note 1/2 + 2/3 = 7/6 > 1, so the total exceeds R and must be re-examined.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a variable for the reference to generalize the solution. This makes the method reusable for any reference value and highlights the dependency on the reference.</description>
  <example>Let R be the reference. If you need 1/4 + 1/2 of R, write (1/4 + 1/2)·R = (3/4)·R, then substitute any R to find the result.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When two quantities are stated to be equal, assign them the same variable. This simplifies comparisons and substitutions in equations.</description>
  <example>Let the weight of a red ball be R. If a blue ball weighs the same, denote its weight also as R. This lets you replace one reference with the other in further calculations.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Translate “X is k more/less than Y” into an equation: X = Y ± k. This captures relative differences in a single algebraic form.</description>
  <example>If a green box weighs 500 grams more than a yellow box, write G = Y + 500. This directly encodes the extra weight without rephrasing.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Use substitution to reduce the number of variables. Replace one variable with its expression in terms of another to solve for unknowns step by step.</description>
  <example>Given G = Y + 500 and Y = R, substitute Y into G to get G = R + 500. Now G and R share the same base variable, simplifying further steps.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>When summing multiple quantities, group like terms and constants separately. This clarifies the total and avoids arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>To find the total T = R + G + Y + C, substitute G = R + 500 and Y = R to get T = R + (R + 500) + R + C = 3R + 500 + C. Then compute numerically once R and C are known.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Always verify by plugging your final values back into the original statements. This ensures consistency and catches any algebraic mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding R = 25000, compute G = 25000 + 500 = 25500, Y = 25000, and C = 10000. Check that G = Y + 500 holds and that the sum matches the expected total.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total initial supply by multiplying the number of containers by the quantity per container. This gives the baseline amount before any adjustments.</description>
  <example>For 5 boxes each holding 12 items, total = 5 × 12 = 60 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Calculate required total by multiplying the number of recipients by the per-recipient demand. This yields the target amount needed to meet the requirement.</description>
  <example>For 30 people each needing 3 items, required = 30 × 3 = 90 items.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Find the shortfall by subtracting the initial supply from the required total. This identifies how much more is needed to reach the target.</description>
  <example>With 60 items available and 90 needed, shortfall = 90 – 60 = 30 items.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the ceiling function to round up when purchasing discrete items. Always round up to ensure you have enough, since you cannot buy a fraction of an item.</description>
  <example>For a shortfall of 30 items, you must buy ceil(30) = 30 items, not 29.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by checking that the sum of initial supply and purchased amount meets or exceeds the required total. This ensures no underestimation.</description>
  <example>60 + 30 = 90, which equals the required 90 items, confirming sufficiency.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the formula distance = speed × time to compute how far each object travels in a given time. This applies whenever an object moves at a constant speed.</description>
  <example>For an object moving at speed v for time t, its distance is v·t. For instance, if v = 50 mph and t = 2 h, then distance = 50 × 2 = 100 miles.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When two objects move in the same direction at constant speeds, their separation grows at the rate of the difference of their speeds. This is the relative speed concept.</description>
  <example>Object A at 40 mph and Object B at 60 mph in the same direction have a relative speed of 60 − 40 = 20 mph. After 3 h, their separation is 20 × 3 = 60 miles.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always convert all units to a consistent system (e.g., hours to hours, miles to miles) before applying distance or rate formulas. Mixing units leads to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If speed is given in km/h and time in minutes, convert minutes to hours (e.g., 15 min = 0.25 h) before computing distance = speed × time.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for special cases: if two objects have the same speed, their separation remains constant; if one overtakes the other, the separation initially decreases then becomes zero.</description>
  <example>Two cars at 50 mph will never gain or lose distance. If one car overtakes at 60 mph, the separation first shrinks until it reaches zero when the faster car catches up.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by plugging it back into the original scenario or by using an alternative method (e.g., drawing a timeline or using a different formula). This helps catch arithmetic or conceptual errors.</description>
  <example>After finding separation = 120 miles, recompute distance for each car and subtract. If both give 120 miles, the answer is consistent.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a route is repeated multiple times, multiply the one-way distance by the number of trips. This applies to any scenario where the same path is traveled several times.</description>
  <example>For a one-way distance of D and n round-trips, total distance = n × (2 × D). For instance, if D = 10 and n = 3, total = 3 × 20 = 60.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Break a multi-leg journey into segments and sum their distances. This is useful when a trip involves different legs with different lengths.</description>
  <example>A trip has legs of lengths L₁, L₂, and L₃. Total one-way distance = L₁ + L₂ + L₃. If L₁ = 5, L₂ = 7, L₃ = 8, then one way = 20.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the formula for a round trip: total one-way distance × 2. This simplifies calculations when the return path is identical to the outbound path.</description>
  <example>If a one-way distance is D, then round-trip distance = 2 × D. For D = 12, round-trip = 24.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>When the number of trips per day or per week is given, multiply the daily total by the number of days. This scales the daily distance to a weekly or monthly total.</description>
  <example>If daily total distance is T and there are d days, then weekly total = T × d. For T = 15 and d = 4, weekly = 60.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all distances are in the same unit before summing or multiplying. Mismatched units lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one leg is in kilometers and another in miles, convert both to the same unit (e.g., kilometers) before adding. For 2 km + 1.6 km = 3.6 km.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a total is partitioned into parts, compute the remainder by subtracting the known part from the total. This remainder represents the leftover portion to be further divided.</description>
  <example>Given a total of T items and a known part of P, the remainder is R = T – P. For instance, if T = 100 and P = 40, then R = 60.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a quantity, multiply the quantity by the fraction. This directly yields the portion corresponding to that fraction.</description>
  <example>For a remainder R and a fraction f, the portion is f × R. For example, if R = 60 and f = 2/3, then the portion is (2/3) × 60 = 40.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a remainder is split into multiple parts, ensure the sum of the fractions equals 1. This guarantees the entire remainder is accounted for.</description>
  <example>If a remainder R is split into parts f₁ and f₂, then f₁ + f₂ = 1. For instance, if f₁ = 2/3 and f₂ = 1/3, then (2/3) + (1/3) = 1, covering all of R.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>After computing a portion, verify by adding all computed parts to the known part and checking against the total. This ensures no part is missed or double-counted.</description>
  <example>Given known part P, computed parts A and B, verify P + A + B = T. For example, if P = 40, A = 40, B = 20, then 40 + 40 + 20 = 100 matches the total T = 100.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a variable for the unknown portion and set up an equation based on the total and known parts. Solve the equation to find the unknown.</description>
  <example>Let x be the unknown portion. If T = P + x, then x = T – P. For instance, if T = 100 and P = 40, then x = 100 – 40 = 60.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate verbal relationships into algebraic expressions by assigning variables to unknown quantities and expressing phrases like “less than,” “times,” or “sum” as operations on those variables.</description>
  <example>“A second item costs 5 less than twice the first item” becomes y = 2x – 5, where x is the first item’s cost and y the second.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Form a linear equation by summing all individual costs and setting the total equal to the given total amount. This models the overall expenditure.</description>
  <example>If the first item costs x and the second costs y, and the total spent is T, write x + y = T to represent the sum of both purchases.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Substitute the expression for one variable into the total equation to reduce it to a single-variable equation. This simplifies solving for the unknown.</description>
  <example>Given y = 2x – 5 and x + y = T, substitute to get x + (2x – 5) = T, yielding 3x – 5 = T.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Solve the single-variable linear equation by isolating the variable: add or subtract constants, then divide by the coefficient. This yields the value of the unknown.</description>
  <example>From 3x – 5 = T, add 5 to both sides to get 3x = T + 5, then divide by 3 to find x = (T + 5)/3.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Compute the remaining amount by subtracting the total expenditure from the given amount. This gives the change or leftover.</description>
  <example>If the total spent is S and the given amount is A, then change = A – S.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “twice the previous amount,” model it as a linear relation: new = 2 × old. This captures the doubling relationship without introducing exponents.</description>
  <example>Suppose last year’s production was P. If this year’s target is twice that, then target = 2P. If the actual production exceeds the target by D, then actual = 2P + D.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Translate “more than” or “less than” statements into algebraic additions or subtractions. Use + for “more than” and – for “less than” to reflect the intended change.</description>
  <example>If a plan calls for T items but you end up with M more, then actual = T + M. Conversely, if you end up with M fewer, then actual = T – M.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Account for losses or additions by subtracting or adding the corresponding amounts. This step corrects the raw count to the final tally.</description>
  <example>After producing A items, if L are lost, the final count is A – L. If L are added, it becomes A + L.</example>
</note3>
<note5>
  <description>Set up an equation by equating the final expression to the given total. This consolidates all relationships into a single solvable equation.</description>
  <example>Given final = 2P + D – L and knowing final = F, write 2P + D – L = F. This equation can then be solved for P.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Solve the resulting linear equation by isolating the variable. Use inverse operations (addition/subtraction, multiplication/division) to find the unknown.</description>
  <example>From 2P + D – L = F, subtract D and add L to both sides: 2P = F – D + L. Then divide by 2: P = (F – D + L)/2.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a rate given per one unit to a rate per another unit by multiplying by the appropriate conversion factor. This works because rates scale linearly with the unit size.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a printer uses 50 pages per hour, to find pages per day multiply by 24: 50 × 24 = 1200 pages/day.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a rate is given per a smaller time period, multiply by the number of those periods in the target time frame. This leverages the fact that total usage equals rate × time.</description>
  <example>If a machine uses 10 units per minute, to find usage per hour multiply by 60: 10 × 60 = 600 units/hour.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the formula Total = Rate × Time to compute overall consumption. Ensure the rate and time are in compatible units before multiplying.</description>
  <example>For example, if a car consumes 8 liters per 100 km, to find consumption for 300 km compute 8 × (300/100) = 24 liters.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>When dealing with multiple items per container, multiply the rate per container by the number of containers. This aggregates usage across all containers.</description>
  <example>If each box holds 20 items and you use 5 boxes per day, total items per day = 20 × 5 = 100 items.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check unit consistency: convert all rates and time periods to the same unit before performing calculations. This prevents errors in scaling.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a rate is given per week but you need per month, convert weeks to months (e.g., 4 weeks = 1 month) before multiplying.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a problem states “a fraction of a quantity,” multiply the original amount by that fraction to find the new amount. This works because fractions represent parts of a whole.</description>
  <example>For instance, if you have X units and you spend 1/4 of them, the spent amount is X × 1/4. If X = 20, then spent = 20 × 1/4 = 5.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Always convert worded fractions (e.g., “a third,” “half”) into their decimal or fractional form before performing arithmetic. This ensures consistency and avoids misinterpretation.</description>
  <example>“A third” is 1/3 ≈ 0.333. If you need 1/3 of 120, compute 120 × 0.333 = 40, or 120 × 1/3 = 40.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When combining multiple parts, add them directly. Ensure all parts are in the same unit before summing. This is the fundamental principle of addition in arithmetic.</description>
  <example>If you spend 80 units in one period and 20 units in another, the total is 80 + 20 = 100 units.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Watch for “remaining” or “leftover” language, which often implies subtraction. Translate “remaining” into “original minus spent” to avoid adding extra terms.</description>
  <example>If you start with 100 units and spend 30, the remaining is 100 − 30 = 70, not 100 + 30.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>After computing, perform a quick sanity check: verify that the result is reasonable relative to the original amount and that units are consistent. This helps catch arithmetic or interpretation errors.</description>
  <example>If you calculate total spending as 150 units from 100-unit budget, you know something is wrong because 150 exceeds the original budget.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all quantities to a common unit before forming equations. For example, convert dozens to individual items by multiplying by 12. This ensures consistency in unit-based comparisons.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 3 dozen widgets. Convert to units: 3 dozen × 12 = 36 widgets. Use 36 in subsequent cost or quantity calculations.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate verbal relationships into algebraic expressions. Phrases like “cost A is X less than cost B” become A = B – X. This models the problem’s conditions precisely.</description>
  <example>If the cost of 2 dozen pens is $50 less than the cost of 5 dozen pencils, write: 2·p = 5·q – 50, where p and q are unit costs.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the unit-rate formula: total cost = (number of items) × (unit cost). This links aggregate costs to individual prices and is fundamental in cost problems.</description>
  <example>For 4 dozen erasers costing $120, the unit cost is 120 ÷ (4×12) = $2.50 per eraser.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When multiple items share the same unit cost, factor out the common cost. For instance, 3 dozen items at cost c each is 36c. This simplifies equations and reduces arithmetic.</description>
  <example>Three dozen markers at $3 each: total = 36 × 3 = 108. If you need the unit cost, divide by 36 to get $3.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>After forming equations, isolate the unknown by standard algebraic steps: combine like terms, move constants, and divide. Always check for extraneous solutions.</description>
  <example>From 36c = 180, divide both sides by 36 to get c = 5. Verify by substituting back into the original relationship.</example>

<note1>
    <description>Compute the perimeter of a rectangle by summing twice its length and twice its width: P = 2·(L + W). This applies to any rectangle regardless of size.</description>
    <example>For a rectangle with sides 4 and 6, P = 2·(4 + 6) = 20.</example>
  </note1>
  <note2>
    <description>Use the distance formula D = R·T to relate distance, rate, and time. Rearrange to T = D/R when solving for time.</description>
    <example>If a walker covers 20 miles at 5 mph, then T = 20/5 = 4 hours.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>When a path is a closed loop, the total distance is the perimeter. Always convert the shape’s dimensions into the appropriate distance before applying formulas.</description>
    <example>A circular track with radius 3 yields a perimeter of 2·π·3 ≈ 18.85, so walking once around covers that distance.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Check units consistency: ensure length units match rate units (e.g., miles/hour with miles). Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
    <example>If speed is given in km/h and distance in miles, convert one before applying D = R·T.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>After computing time, verify it makes sense: if the rate is faster than the distance, time should be less than one unit; if slower, time should exceed one unit.</description>
    <example>Walking 10 miles at 2 mph gives T = 5 hours, which is reasonable since 2 mph is slower than the distance.</example>
  </note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total usage by multiplying a daily rate by the number of days. This applies whenever a constant daily consumption or production is given over a known period.</description>
  <example>For a device that uses 5 units per day over 10 days, total usage = 5 units/day × 10 days = 50 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Sum multiple usage categories by adding their individual totals. This is useful when different activities or sources contribute to a total consumption or production.</description>
  <example>If one activity uses 20 units and another uses 30 units, total usage = 20 + 30 = 50 units.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Find remaining capacity by subtracting total usage from the initial allowance. This gives the leftover resources after accounting for all uses.</description>
  <example>With an initial allowance of 100 units and total usage of 50 units, remaining = 100 – 50 = 50 units.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify multiplication over addition: a × (b + c) = a × b + a × c. This can streamline calculations when a rate is applied to a sum of categories.</description>
  <example>For a rate of 150 units/day over 30 days plus 3,000 units, total = 150 × 30 + 3,000 = 4,500 + 3,000 = 7,500 units.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify units and perform a sanity check: ensure all quantities are in the same unit and that the result is reasonable given the context.</description>
  <example>After computing 150 × 30 = 4,500 minutes, confirm that 4,500 minutes is a plausible daily usage over 30 days and that the final remaining minutes are positive.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total earnings by multiplying hourly rate by hours worked. This gives the initial amount available for spending or saving.</description>
  <example>For an hourly rate of r and hours worked of h, total earnings = r × h. For instance, if r = 100 and h = 12, then total = 100 × 12 = 1200.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Subtract fixed expenses from total earnings to find remaining funds. This step removes known costs before further allocation.</description>
  <example>Given total earnings T and expenses E, remaining = T – E. For example, if T = 1200 and E = 50, then remaining = 1200 – 50 = 1150.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Account for additional deposits by subtracting the deposit amount from the remaining funds. This ensures the deposit is deducted before any further spending.</description>
  <example>With remaining funds R and deposit D, available after deposit = R – D. For instance, if R = 1150 and D = 100, then available = 1150 – 100 = 1050.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Calculate the cost of multiple items by multiplying the unit cost by the quantity. This gives the total expenditure for that category.</description>
  <example>For a unit cost of c and quantity q, total cost = c × q. For example, if c = 10 and q = 5, then total = 10 × 5 = 50.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Determine how many items of a given price can be purchased by dividing the remaining funds by the item’s price and taking the integer part. This yields the maximum whole items that fit the budget.</description>
  <example>With remaining funds A and item price p, count = ⌊A ÷ p⌋. For instance, if A = 1050 and p = 25, then count = ⌊1050 ÷ 25⌋ = 42.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity exceeds another by a fixed amount, represent it as the base plus that amount. This models “more than” relationships algebraically.</description>
  <example>Let A be the base amount. If B is 10 more than A, then B = A + 10. If C is 5 more than B, then C = B + 5 = (A + 10) + 5 = A + 15.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate each verbal relationship into an equation. Assign a variable to each unknown and express each condition in terms of those variables.</description>
  <example>For three amounts X, Y, Z: “Y is 20 more than X” becomes Y = X + 20; “Z is 30 more than Y” becomes Z = Y + 30. This yields a system of equations.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use substitution to solve for one variable at a time. Replace each variable with its expression in terms of the base variable to find all values.</description>
  <example>From Y = X + 20 and Z = Y + 30, substitute Y into Z: Z = (X + 20) + 30 = X + 50. Now all three are expressed in terms of X.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Sum the expressions to find the total. Combine like terms to simplify the result into a single expression in the base variable.</description>
  <example>Sum X + (X + 20) + (X + 50) = 3X + 70. This gives the total in terms of X, ready for any specific value of X.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by plugging a test value into the final expression. Ensure the computed total matches the verbal description when the base variable is that test value.</description>
  <example>If X = 10, then total = 3·10 + 70 = 100. Check: Y = 10 + 20 = 30, Z = 30 + 30 = 60, and 10 + 30 + 60 = 100, confirming correctness.</example>
</note5>

problem: There are 26 countries in South America and, in each country, there are 10 cities with 10000 people living in each city.  If the whole population lives in these cities, how many people are there in South America?

age-difference: When two people’s ages differ by a constant, represent their ages as A and A ± d. This captures relative age relationships without specific numbers.
substitution: If one variable is expressed in terms of another (e.g. B = A + d), substitute that expression into other equations to reduce unknowns.
chain-relation: For a chain of age differences (A → B → C), express each in terms of the first (e.g. B = A + d₁, C = B + d₂ = A + d₁ + d₂) to find any one in terms of the first.
unit-conversion: Convert between different units of time (e.g. years to months) by multiplying or dividing by the appropriate factor.
consistency-check: After solving, verify that all age differences and relationships hold true by plugging the results back into the original statements.

<note1>
  <description>When a quantity increases by a percentage p, multiply the original amount by (1 + p/100). This converts a percentage increase into a multiplicative factor.</description>
  <example>Starting with 100 units and a 20% increase, compute 100 × (1 + 20/100) = 120 units.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When a quantity decreases by a percentage p, multiply the original amount by (1 – p/100). This converts a percentage decrease into a multiplicative factor.</description>
  <example>Starting with 100 units and a 15% decrease, compute 100 × (1 – 15/100) = 85 units.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>For two or more segments with different rates, compute each segment’s contribution separately and then sum them. This ensures each part is handled correctly before combining.</description>
  <example>If segment A yields 50 units and segment B yields 70 units, total = 50 + 70 = 120 units.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Always check that percentage-based factors lie between 0 and 2. A factor outside this range indicates an error in the percentage or sign.</description>
  <example>For a 120% increase, the factor is 2.2, which is valid. For a 120% decrease, the factor is –0.2, which is invalid; instead use 1 – 120/100 = –0.2, then take absolute value if only magnitude matters.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Use unit consistency: ensure all quantities (time, points, etc.) are in the same units before applying any operations. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If one segment is 120 minutes and another is 2 hours, convert 2 hours to 120 minutes before summing or comparing.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into algebraic equations by expressing each age in terms of a variable and a constant shift. For “age k years ago was m times age p years ago,” write (A – k) = m·(B – p).</description>
  <example>“A’s age 5 years ago was three times B’s age 2 years ago.” Let A and B be their current ages. Then (A – 5) = 3·(B – 2).</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the current age as a reference to express past or future ages. If X is the current age, then X – t is t years ago, and X + t is t years from now.</description>
  <example>“Y is currently 25.” To find Y’s age 7 years ago, compute 25 – 7 = 18. To find Y’s age 4 years from now, compute 25 + 4 = 29.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Form a linear equation by substituting the expressions from notes 1 and 2 into the given relationship, then solve for the unknown variable using standard algebraic steps.</description>
  <example>From (A – 5) = 3·(B – 2), substitute A = 25: (25 – 5) = 3·(B – 2) ⇒ 20 = 3B – 6 ⇒ 3B = 26 ⇒ B = 26/3.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check the solution by substituting back into the original age expressions to ensure consistency and that no arithmetic errors occurred.</description>
  <example>With B = 26/3, verify (25 – 5) = 3·(26/3 – 2) ⇒ 20 = 3·(26/3 – 6/3) ⇒ 20 = 3·(20/3) ⇒ 20 = 20, confirming correctness.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Compute a future age by adding the desired number of years to the solved current age, ensuring the result is an integer if required.</description>
  <example>If B = 26/3, then B’s age in 8 years is (26/3) + 8 = (26/3 + 24/3) = 50/3, which is approximately 16.67. If the problem expects an integer, re-examine assumptions.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the unit rate formula: total cost ÷ total quantity = cost per unit. This gives the price of one item, which is essential for scaling or comparing costs.</description>
  <example>For instance, if 1000 items cost $5000, then cost per item = 5000 ÷ 1000 = $5. This unit rate can then be used to find the cost of any number of items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the inverse proportionality: total quantity = total cost ÷ cost per unit. This directly computes how many items you can buy with a given budget.</description>
  <example>With a budget of $2700000 and a unit cost of $5, the total number of items = 2700000 ÷ 5 = 540000 items.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When distributing a total quantity among groups, divide the total by the number of groups: per-group quantity = total quantity ÷ number of groups. This ensures an equal share.</description>
  <example>If 540000 items are to be split among 30 schools, each school gets 540000 ÷ 30 = 18000 items.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check for integer results when dividing quantities. If a division yields a non-integer, consider rounding or re-evaluating the model to ensure practicality.</description>
  <example>Dividing 540000 by 30 gives exactly 18000, so no rounding is needed. If it had been 540001 ÷ 30, you’d get 18000.033…, which might require adjusting the budget or group count.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by multiplying back: per-group quantity × number of groups × cost per unit should equal the original total cost. This consistency check catches arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>18000 items per school × 30 schools × $5 per item = 2700000, matching the initial budget, confirming the solution is correct.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity exceeds another by a fixed amount, represent the larger as the smaller plus that difference. This models “more than” relationships algebraically.</description>
  <example>Suppose Team A has 5 more members than Team B. If Team B has x members, then Team A has x + 5 members.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate word phrases into algebraic expressions: “more than” becomes addition, “less than” becomes subtraction, “times” becomes multiplication, and “divided by” becomes division.</description>
  <example>“Three times the number of apples minus two” becomes 3·a – 2, where a is the number of apples.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine like terms by adding or subtracting coefficients of the same variable. This simplifies expressions before solving or further manipulation.</description>
  <example>Given 4x + 2x – 5, combine 4x and 2x to get 6x – 5.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to expand or factor expressions: a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c, and (a + b)·c = a·c + b·c. This helps simplify and solve equations.</description>
  <example>Expand 3·(y + 4) to get 3y + 12, or factor 6y + 12 as 6·(y + 2).</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>After forming an equation, isolate the variable by performing inverse operations (addition/subtraction, multiplication/division) on both sides to solve for the unknown.</description>
  <example>For 2x + 3 = 11, subtract 3 to get 2x = 8, then divide by 2 to find x = 4.</example>
</note1>

Define variables for each person’s quantity, then translate each relationship into an equation. Use substitution or elimination to solve the system. Always check that your solution satisfies all original conditions.

<note1>
  <description>Identify the constant rate of change in a linear scenario by dividing the total change in quantity by the corresponding change in time. This rate is constant when the relationship is linear.</description>
  <example>Suppose a savings account grows by $50 each month. The rate of change is 50 dollars per month, found by dividing the total increase by the number of months.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the linear equation Q = r·t + Q₀ to model a quantity Q that changes at a constant rate r over time t, starting from an initial amount Q₀. This equation applies whenever the change is uniform.</description>
  <example>If a tank fills at 2 liters per minute and starts empty, then after t minutes the amount of water is Q = 2·t + 0. This formula predicts the volume at any time.</example>
</note1>
<note3>
  <description>To find the time needed to reach a target quantity, set Q = Q_target in the linear equation and solve for t: t = (Q_target – Q₀) / r. This isolates the unknown time directly.</description>
  <example>With a rate of 3 units per hour and an initial stock of 10 units, to reach 50 units solve t = (50 – 10) / 3 = 40 / 3 hours.</example>
</note1>
<note4>
  <description>Always check that the rate r and the initial amount Q₀ are consistent with the problem’s context. Ensure units match and that the rate is positive for growth scenarios.</description>
  <example>If a machine produces 10 widgets per hour but the problem states it produces 10 widgets per day, convert to hours (10/24 per hour) before using in the equation.</example>
</note1>
<note5>
  <description>After computing the time, verify by plugging the result back into the linear equation to confirm it yields the target quantity. This step catches arithmetic or unit errors.</description>
  <example>After finding t = 40/3 hours for a rate of 3 units/hour, check Q = 3·(40/3) + 0 = 40 units, matching the target.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
    <description>Translate verbal age relationships into algebraic equations by assigning a variable to the unknown age and expressing past or future ages as that variable minus or plus a constant. This sets up the equation for solving.</description>
    <example>“A person is k times as old as they were m years ago.” Let x be the current age; then “k·(x–m)=x.”</example>
  </note2>
  <note2>
    <description>Use the general formula for “k times as old as” relationships: k·(x–m)=x, where x is the current age, m is the time difference, and k is the multiplier. This captures any “k times” statement in one equation.</description>
    <example>“A person is 3 times as old as they were 5 years ago.” Write 3·(x–5)=x to model the relationship.</example>
  </note3>
  <note3>
    <description>Solve the resulting linear equation by expanding, collecting like terms, and isolating the variable. This standard method applies to any first-degree equation.</description>
    <example>From 3·(x–5)=x, expand to 3x–15=x, then 2x=15, so x=7.5.</example>
  </note4>
  <note4>
    <description>After finding the current age, compute any future or past age by adding or subtracting the desired time interval. This step converts the solution into the required future or past age.</description>
    <example>If x=7.5 is the current age, then in t years the age is x+t; for instance, in 4 years it is 7.5+4=11.5.</example>
  </note5>
  <note5>
    <description>Always check that the solution is consistent with the original verbal statement and that ages are nonnegative. This ensures the answer makes sense in context.</description>
    <example>Verify 3·(7.5–5)=3·2.5=7.5 matches the current age, and confirm 7.5+4=11.5 is a valid future age.</example>
