1. <note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a total is taken, multiply the fraction by the total to find the count. This works because “fraction of total” = (fraction) × (total).</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, taking p/q of them yields (p/q)·T items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When two fractions of the same total are added, convert them to a common denominator or add directly if they share the same denominator. The sum of fractions equals the sum of their numerators over the common denominator.</description>
  <example>Adding p/q of T and r/q of T gives (p + r)/q of T, so the total count is ((p + r)/q)·T.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>To find a multiple of a previous count, multiply the original count by the multiplier. This applies whenever a quantity is scaled by a factor k.</description>
  <example>If a count is C, then k times that count is k·C.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When combining counts from different days or steps, sum all individual counts. This is the basic principle of additive aggregation in discrete problems.</description>
  <example>Given counts C₁, C₂, and C₃, the total is C₁ + C₂ + C₃.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the final total does not exceed the original total or any given constraints. This ensures consistency and catches overcounting.</description>
  <example>If the sum of counts exceeds T, re-examine each step for arithmetic or logical errors.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a total quantity is split equally among n parts, each part receives the total divided by n. This applies to any equal distribution problem.</description>
  <example>Suppose 60 items are shared equally among 5 containers. Each container gets 60 ÷ 5 = 12 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Half of a quantity is found by multiplying the quantity by 1/2. This is a special case of fraction multiplication.</description>
  <example>Half of 20 units is 20 × 1/2 = 10 units.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>When two quantities are combined, add them to get the new total. Then apply any further distribution or calculation to that sum.</description>
  <example>Combining 15 units and 25 units yields 40 units. If you then split these 40 units into 4 groups, each group has 40 ÷ 4 = 10 units.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>After distributing items into multiple groups, to find the total in a subset of groups, multiply the per-group count by the number of groups in the subset.</description>
  <example>If each of 10 boxes holds 7 items, then 4 boxes hold 4 × 7 = 28 items.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify your result by reversing the steps: reconstruct the original quantities from your final answer to ensure consistency.</description>
  <example>If you conclude 28 items are in 4 boxes, check by dividing 28 by 4 to see if you recover 7 items per box, matching the initial distribution.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total output by multiplying rate (units per time) by total time (hours or days). This gives the number of items produced over the given period.</description>
  <example>Machine A produces 10 units/hour and runs for 8 hours. Total output = 10 units/hour × 8 hours = 80 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert daily or monthly time into hours by multiplying by the number of hours per day and days per month. This ensures all time units are consistent before computing output.</description>
  <example>Machine B runs 24 hours/day for 30 days. Total hours = 24 hours/day × 30 days = 720 hours.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Calculate revenue by multiplying total output by unit price. This gives the total income generated from selling all items.</description>
  <example>Each item sells for $5 and 80 items are produced. Revenue = 80 items × $5/item = $400.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Find the difference in revenue between two machines by subtracting the smaller revenue from the larger. This quantifies how much more one machine earns than the other.</description>
  <example>Machine A earns $400 and Machine B earns $300. Difference = $400 – $300 = $100.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use unitary method to find per-hour or per-day revenue: divide total revenue by total hours or days. This helps compare machines with different run times.</description>
  <example>Machine A earns $400 in 8 hours. Per-hour revenue = $400 ÷ 8 hours = $50/hour.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all fractional and decimal quantities to a common form (fractions or decimals) before combining. This ensures consistency and avoids arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>Given “1/8” and “0.125,” recognize that 0.125 = 1/8, so both are expressed as 1/8. Then you can add them directly as fractions.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to handle “more than” phrases: if A eats x and B eats x + y, then B’s share = x + y. This clarifies relationships between quantities.</description>
  <example>“Sister ate 0.125 more than Doxa” means sister’s share = Doxa’s share + 0.125. If Doxa’s share is 1/8, then sister’s share = 1/8 + 0.125.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum all individual shares by adding their common form. For fractions, find a common denominator; for decimals, align decimal points.</description>
  <example>Adding 1/8, 1/8, and 1/8 gives 3/8. Alternatively, adding 0.125, 0.125, and 0.125 gives 0.375, which equals 3/8.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Verify the total does not exceed the whole (1 or 100%). If it does, re-examine each conversion or addition step for mistakes.</description>
  <example>If you get 1.25 (125%) of the apple, check that you correctly converted and added all shares. A total over 1 indicates an error.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>When the problem asks for a count of pieces, multiply the total fraction by the total number of pieces. This scales the fractional result to the actual count.</description>
  <example>If the total eaten is 3/8 of the apple and there are 8 slices, then slices eaten = (3/8) × 8 = 3 slices.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100, then multiply by the base quantity to find a percentage of that quantity. This works because “percent” means “per hundred.”</description>
  <example>Find 25% of 80. Convert 25% to 0.25, then compute 0.25 × 80 = 20.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute a percentage decrease by multiplying the original amount by (1 – p/100), where p is the percentage. This gives the reduced value directly.</description>
  <example>Original amount is 120, decrease by 15%. Compute 120 × (1 – 0.15) = 120 × 0.85 = 102.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When one quantity is a multiple of another, multiply the base quantity by the factor. This scales the base to the desired multiple.</description>
  <example>If A = 50 and B is 3 times A, then B = 3 × 50 = 150.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that all computed values are nonnegative and make sense in context. Negative or zero results may indicate an error in setup or interpretation.</description>
  <example>After finding a decrease, ensure the result is ≥ 0. If you get –10 from a decrease, recheck the percentage or base value.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use unit consistency: ensure all quantities are in the same units before combining or comparing. Mixing units (e.g., hours vs. minutes) leads to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If one rate is in “per hour” and another in “per minute,” convert one to match the other before adding or comparing.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying unit price by quantity. This applies whenever you know the price per item and the number of items purchased.</description>
  <example>For n items at price p each, total cost = n × p. For instance, if you buy 5 widgets at $20 each, total cost = 5 × 20 = $100.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Find total revenue from individual high-value items by multiplying each item’s value by its count. Sum these products to get the total revenue from those items.</description>
  <example>If you have 2 special cards worth $1000 each and 3 cards worth $500 each, total revenue = 2 × 1000 + 3 × 500 = $2000 + $1500 = $3500.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the average formula to find total value of a group: total = average × count. This is useful when you know the average value of a batch of items and the number of items.</description>
  <example>For 10 cards with an average value of $75, total value = 10 × 75 = $750.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Compute profit by subtracting total cost from total revenue. Ensure both totals are in the same currency before subtracting.</description>
  <example>If total cost is $1200 and total revenue is $1500, profit = 1500 − 1200 = $300.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check for unit consistency and avoid mixing different units (e.g., dollars vs. cents). Always convert all values to the same unit before performing arithmetic.</description>
  <example>If one cost is given in dollars and another in cents, convert cents to dollars (e.g., 50 cents = $0.50) before adding or subtracting.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When a journey is split into segments with different speeds, compute each segment’s time as distance divided by speed. This works because time = distance/speed for uniform motion.</description>
  <example>For a 10 km trip split into 4 km at 5 km/h and 6 km at 3 km/h, times are 4/5=0.8 h and 6/3=2 h.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the average speed formula v_avg = total distance / total time when speeds vary. This gives the overall rate for the entire journey.</description>
  <example>With 10 km at 5 km/h and 10 km at 3 km/h, total time is 2+3.33=5.33 h, so v_avg = 20/5.33 ≈ 3.75 km/h.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When equal distances are traveled at two speeds v₁ and v₂, the average speed is 2v₁v₂/(v₁+v₂). This is a special case of the harmonic mean for two rates.</description>
  <example>Equal 5 km at 10 km/h and 15 km/h gives v_avg = 2·10·15/(10+15) = 300/25 = 12 km/h.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: distances and speeds must share the same units before dividing. Convert if necessary to avoid errors.</description>
  <example>If speed is given in m/s and distance in km, convert distance to meters or speed to km/h before computing time.</example>
</note6>
<note7>
  <description>Verify your result by plugging the computed time back into the original speed–distance relation. This ensures no arithmetic or conceptual mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding total time t, check that distance = speed × time holds for each segment and the overall journey.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total quantity by multiplying rate by time for each segment, then summing. This applies whenever you have a constant rate over different intervals.</description>
  <example>For segment A: rate = r₁, time = t₁ → quantity = r₁·t₁. For segment B: rate = r₂, time = t₂ → quantity = r₂·t₂. Total quantity = r₁·t₁ + r₂·t₂.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert time units consistently before multiplying by rate. Ensure hours, minutes, or seconds align so that rate units match the time units.</description>
  <example>If a rate is given per hour but time is in minutes, convert minutes to hours by dividing by 60. Then multiply the converted time by the hourly rate.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the unitary method: find the value per single unit, then multiply by the total number of units. This is useful for pricing, distance, or any rate problem.</description>
  <example>Given price per item = p, total items = n, then total cost = p·n. For instance, if each item costs $p and you have n items, multiply to get the total.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>When rates or prices change over time, treat each change as a separate segment. Compute each segment’s contribution independently, then sum all contributions.</description>
  <example>Segment 1: rate = r₁, time = t₁ → revenue = r₁·t₁. Segment 2: rate = r₂, time = t₂ → revenue = r₂·t₂. Total revenue = r₁·t₁ + r₂·t₂.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and perform a sanity check on the result. Ensure that the final unit matches the expected unit (e.g., dollars for money) and that the magnitude is reasonable.</description>
  <example>After computing total revenue, verify that the unit is dollars and that the amount is within a plausible range given the rates and times provided.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into algebraic ratios: if one quantity is k times another, set it as k·x. This models “twice as many” or “three times as many” relationships.</description>
  <example>“Person A reads k times as many pages as Person B.” Let B’s pages = x, then A’s pages = k·x.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert fractional parts into decimals or percentages for easier arithmetic: a/b of a total T becomes (a/b)·T. This simplifies reading a fraction of a quantity.</description>
  <example>“Read a/b of T pages.” Compute (a/b)·T to get the exact number of pages read.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Handle “times more” or “times as many” by multiplying the base amount by the factor: if you read m times more than x, total = m·x. This avoids confusion between “more than” and “as many as.”</description>
  <example>“Read m times more than x pages.” Total = m·x, not x + m·x.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Combine multiple reading segments by summing their expressions: if you read x₁ then x₂, total = x₁ + x₂. This aggregates different parts of the reading.</description>
  <example>“First read x₁ pages, then read x₂ pages.” Total pages = x₁ + x₂.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a single variable for the unknown and express all related quantities in terms of it. Then solve the resulting equation. This reduces complexity and ensures consistency.</description>
  <example>Let x be the number of pages read by one person. Express the other’s pages as k·x, set up an equation, and solve for x.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute the total area of a rectangle by multiplying its length by its width. This applies to any rectangular region, including those with added margins.</description>
  <example>For a rectangle of length L and width W, the area is A = L × W. If L = 4 and W = 6, then A = 4 × 6 = 24.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a shape is enlarged uniformly by adding the same margin m to each side, its new dimensions are (original length + 2m) and (original width + 2m). This accounts for margins on both sides.</description>
  <example>Original dimensions are L = 5 and W = 7, with margin m = 1. New dimensions are (5 + 2·1) = 7 and (7 + 2·1) = 9.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to expand expressions like (a + b)(c + d) = ac + ad + bc + bd. This is useful for expanding the product of two sums, such as new dimensions.</description>
  <example>Expand (x + 2)(y + 3): = x·y + x·3 + 2·y + 2·3 = xy + 3x + 2y + 6.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Combine like terms to simplify polynomial expressions. Terms with the same variable and exponent can be added or subtracted to reduce complexity.</description>
  <example>Given 3x + 5x + 2y + 4y, combine like terms: (3x + 5x) + (2y + 4y) = 8x + 6y.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify your result by checking units and plugging in simple values. This helps catch arithmetic or algebraic mistakes.</description>
  <example>If you compute A = (L + 2m)(W + 2m), test with m = 0 to see if A = L·W. If A ≠ L·W, re-examine the expansion.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute a percentage increase by multiplying the base amount by (1 + rate/100). This applies whenever a quantity is raised by a certain percentage.</description>
  <example>For a base price P and a 20% markup, the new price is P × 1.20. If P = 100, then the increased price is 100 × 1.20 = 120.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When multiple items or services are purchased, sum their individual costs to get the total. This is the fundamental principle of additive aggregation.</description>
  <example>If two tickets cost T each and a hotel stays cost H per day for D days, the total is 2·T + D·H. For T = 500, H = 150, D = 3, the total is 2·500 + 3·150 = 1000 + 450 = 1450.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions like a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c. This helps in combining and factoring terms efficiently.</description>
  <example>Given 2·(T + H·D), rewrite as 2·T + 2·(H·D). If T = 500, H = 150, D = 3, then 2·(500 + 150·3) = 2·(500 + 450) = 2·950 = 1900.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check unit consistency: ensure all costs and quantities share the same units before summing. Mismatched units lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one cost is in dollars and another in cents, convert cents to dollars (e.g., 50 cents = 0.50 dollars) before adding. For instance, 500 + 0.50 = 500.50.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by estimating or rounding values to see if the final result is reasonable. This helps catch arithmetic or conceptual errors.</description>
  <example>For T = 500, H = 150, D = 3, approximate 2·500 = 1000 and 3·150 = 450, so total ≈ 1450. If your detailed calculation yields a much larger or smaller number, re-examine your steps.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When two quantities are in a ratio a:b, assign them as a·k and b·k for some constant k. This captures the proportional relationship without knowing the actual values.</description>
  <example>For a ratio of 3:5, set the quantities to 3k and 5k. If k=4, the values are 12 and 20, maintaining the 3:5 ratio.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the sum of the ratio parts (a+b) to relate the total to the constant k: (a+b)·k = total. Solve for k by dividing the known total by (a+b).</description>
  <example>With a ratio 3:5 and total 80, compute k = 80 ÷ (3+5) = 10, so the quantities are 30 and 50.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Translate any future or past condition into an equation by adding or subtracting the time shift from the current value. For “n years later,” use current + n; for “n years ago,” use current – n.</description>
  <example>If a person is currently 25, then in 5 years they will be 25 + 5 = 30, and 5 years ago they were 25 – 5 = 20.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the computed k is positive and that the resulting values satisfy any given constraints (e.g., integer, nonnegative). This guards against invalid or extraneous solutions.</description>
  <example>From k = 80 ÷ 8 = 10, verify k>0 and that 3k=30 and 5k=50 are valid ages. If k were negative, it would imply negative ages, which is invalid.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>After finding the current value, apply any additional operations (e.g., multiplication by a factor) before finalizing the answer. This ensures you account for all problem conditions.</description>
  <example>If the current age is 30 and the problem asks for “twice that age,” compute 2·30 = 60 before presenting the final result.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a fixed amount more than another, express it as Q₂ = Q₁ + d. This linear relation captures the “more than” condition in algebraic form.</description>
  <example>Suppose one person has x dollars and another has y dollars, and y is 10 more than x. Then write y = x + 10 to model the relationship.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When one quantity is a multiple of another, express it as Q₃ = k·Q₂. This captures “twice,” “three times,” etc., in a single parameter k.</description>
  <example>If a third person’s share is twice the second person’s share, set Q₃ = 2·Q₂. This directly encodes the “twice” condition.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum all parts to the total: Q₁ + Q₂ + Q₃ = T. This equation ties the individual expressions to the overall total.</description>
  <example>Given Q₁, Q₂ = x + 10, and Q₃ = 2·Q₂, write Q₁ + (x + 10) + 2(x + 10) = T to represent the total amount T.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Substitute the relations into the sum equation to form a single-variable linear equation. This reduces the system to one unknown.</description>
  <example>From Q₁ + (x + 10) + 2(x + 10) = T, expand and combine like terms to get Q₁ + 3x + 30 = T, then solve for Q₁ in terms of x.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use the resulting linear equation to solve for the unknown share. Then back-substitute to find the other shares.</description>
  <example>After finding x from the linear equation, compute Q₁ = x, Q₂ = x + 10, and Q₃ = 2(x + 10) to obtain all three shares.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert fractional costs into a single unit by multiplying each fraction by the total unit cost. This yields the cost per unit in that unit. Use this when costs are given as fractions of a known total.</description>
  <example>Suppose a material costs 2/5 of a $100 unit. Multiply 2/5 × $100 = $40 per unit. This single-unit cost can then be scaled for any quantity.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total revenue by multiplying the price per item by the total number of items sold. This gives the overall income before subtracting costs.</description>
  <example>If each item sells for $2 and 50 items are sold, then total revenue = 50 × $2 = $100.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Find total cost by summing individual cost components. If costs are given per unit, multiply each by its quantity before adding. This ensures all expenses are accounted for.</description>
  <example>For 10 units, if one cost is $3 per unit and another is $2 per unit, total cost = 10 × $3 + 10 × $2 = $50.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the profit formula: Profit = Revenue – Total Cost. Rearrange to solve for any unknown: Revenue = Profit + Cost, or Cost = Revenue – Profit.</description>
  <example>If revenue is $200 and profit is $50, then total cost = $200 – $50 = $150.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check consistency by verifying that all units (dollars, items, units) align and that no component is omitted. This prevents arithmetic errors and ensures the model is complete.</description>
  <example>Ensure you convert all costs to the same currency before summing, and confirm that the number of items sold matches the revenue calculation.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert mixed numbers to improper fractions or decimals before performing arithmetic. This ensures consistency and avoids errors in addition or multiplication.</description>
  <example>Convert 2 3/4 to an improper fraction: multiply the whole part by the denominator and add the numerator, then place over the original denominator. For 2 3/4, compute (2×4+3)/4 = 11/4.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When multiplying a fraction by a whole number, rewrite the whole number as a fraction over 1. Then multiply numerators and denominators separately.</description>
  <example>Compute (3/5)×8 by writing 8 as 8/1, giving (3×8)/(5×1) = 24/5.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When adding or subtracting fractions, first convert them to a common denominator. Then add or subtract the numerators and keep the common denominator.</description>
  <example>Compute 1/3 + 2/5 by finding a common denominator (15): rewrite as 5/15 + 6/15 = 11/15.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>After performing arithmetic with fractions, simplify the result by dividing numerator and denominator by their greatest common divisor.</description>
  <example>Given 14/21, divide both by 7 to simplify to 2/3.</example>
</note6>
<note7>
  <description>Always check that your final answer is in simplest form and that it makes sense in context (e.g., a fraction between 0 and 1 for a part of a whole).</description>
  <example>If you calculate 7/14, simplify to 1/2. Then verify that 1/2 is a valid fraction representing a part of a whole.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all time units to a single unit before summing. Use the relation 1 hour = 60 minutes to change minutes into hours or vice versa.</description>
  <example>Given a task takes 45 minutes, convert to hours by computing 45 ÷ 60 = 0.75 hours.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total time for identical tasks by multiplying the time per task by the number of tasks. This applies to any repetitive work.</description>
  <example>If one task takes 0.75 hours and you need 8 of them, total time = 0.75 × 8 = 6 hours.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When tasks have different durations, sum their totals separately and then add. This ensures each task’s time is accounted for correctly.</description>
  <example>For 5 tasks at 0.75 hours each and 3 tasks at 1.25 hours each, compute 5×0.75 + 3×1.25 = 3.75 + 3.75 = 7.5 hours.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify sums: a·x + a·y = a·(x + y). This can reduce arithmetic steps when multiple tasks share the same duration.</description>
  <example>Instead of 0.75×5 + 0.75×3, compute 0.75×(5 + 3) = 0.75×8 = 6 hours.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check unit consistency and perform a sanity check on the final result. Ensure the total time is reasonable given the number of tasks and their durations.</description>
  <example>After finding 7.5 hours for 8 tasks at 0.75 hours each, verify 8×0.75 = 6 hours, so the result is plausible.</example>
</note5>
Define variables for each unknown quantity and translate each statement into an equation. Use clear notation (e.g., let x = total potatoes, y = scoops eaten) to avoid confusion.

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the basic distance–rate–time relation: time = distance ÷ speed. This formula applies whenever you know two of the three quantities and need the third.</description>
  <example>For a segment of 120 miles at 60 mph, compute time = 120 ÷ 60 = 2 hours.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a route has multiple segments, compute each segment’s time separately and then sum them. This ensures you account for every part of the journey.</description>
  <example>If one leg is 80 miles at 40 mph (time = 2 h) and the next is 100 miles at 50 mph (time = 2 h), total time = 2 + 2 = 4 h.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always convert all units to a consistent system before applying formulas. Mismatched units (e.g., miles vs. kilometers) will yield incorrect results.</description>
  <example>Ensure both distance and speed are in miles and mph; if speed is given in km/h, convert distance to km or vice versa before dividing.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for detours or extra distances by adding them to the original route before computing time. Omitting extra segments leads to underestimating total travel time.</description>
  <example>If a direct route is 150 miles but a detour adds 20 miles, total distance = 170 miles. Then time = 170 ÷ speed.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by estimating: if the computed time is too small or too large compared to a rough estimate, recheck your calculations and unit conversions.</description>
  <example>For 200 miles at 50 mph, a quick estimate is 4 h. If you get 3.5 h, re-examine the distance or speed values.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as a multiple of another, express it as a product: if A is k times B, then A = k·B. This converts verbal relationships into algebraic form.</description>
  <example>Suppose a class has twice as many red balls as blue balls. If B is the number of blue balls, then the number of red balls is 2·B.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>For a fraction of a quantity, multiply the whole by the fraction: if C is f of B, then C = f·B. This handles “one-tenth,” “one-third,” etc., directly.</description>
  <example>If a box contains one-fifth of its total items as green marbles and the total items are T, then green marbles = (1/5)·T.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When combining parts, sum their expressions: total = A + B + C. Ensure each part is expressed in terms of the same base variable.</description>
  <example>Given red = 2·B, blue = B, and green = (1/5)·B, the total count is 2·B + B + (1/5)·B.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>After forming the sum, factor out the common variable: total = (sum of coefficients)·B. This simplifies the expression before substitution.</description>
  <example>From 2·B + B + (1/5)·B, factor B to get (2 + 1 + 1/5)·B = (16/5)·B.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Substitute the known value of the base variable into the factored expression to compute the total. This yields the final numeric result.</description>
  <example>If B = 30, then total = (16/5)·30 = 96.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When a total quantity is split into parts, use the relation “part₁ + part₂ + … + partₖ = total.” This helps find unknown parts when some are known.</description>
  <example>Suppose a collection of N items is divided into two groups, and one group has size x. Then the other group has size N – x. For instance, if N = 100 and one group is 40, the other is 60.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into algebraic equations. Phrases like “twice as many” become “part₁ = 2·part₂,” and “half as many” becomes “part₁ = 0.5·part₂.”</description>
  <example>If in one year you sold twice as many items as in another, and you sold y items in the second year, then in the first year you sold 2y items. For example, if y = 30, then the first year’s sales = 60.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Use the unitary method to find total revenue: multiply the number of items sold by the price per item. This applies whenever you know both quantity and unit price.</description>
  <example>If each item sells for p dollars and you sell q items, then total revenue = p·q. For instance, if p = 10 and q = 50, revenue = 500.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>When given a total and some known parts, subtract the known parts from the total to find the remaining unknown part. This is a direct application of subtraction in partition problems.</description>
  <example>If a total of T items remain after selling some, and you know you sold S items, then the remaining items = T – S. For example, if T = 200 and S = 120, remaining = 80.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always check that your solution satisfies all original conditions, including non-negativity and integer constraints. This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding x = 30 for a number of items, verify that x ≥ 0 and that any derived quantities (like 2x or T – x) are also non-negative and integers. If not, re-examine your setup.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentage statements into decimal form by dividing by 100. This lets you work with decimals in equations instead of percentages.</description>
  <example>“0.2 hundredth” means 0.2% = 0.2 ÷ 100 = 0.002. Use 0.002 in subsequent calculations.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate “times as old” or “times as many” into multiplication. If A is k times B, then A = k·B.</description>
  <example>“A is 3 times as old as B” becomes A = 3·B. If A = 12, then B = 12 ÷ 3 = 4.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the difference of two quantities to find the base unit. If A = k·B and A – B = D, then B = D ÷ (k – 1).</description>
  <example>“A is 4 times B, and A – B = 15” gives B = 15 ÷ (4 – 1) = 5, so A = 4·5 = 20.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check your answer by substituting back into the original relationships. This catches arithmetic or setup errors.</description>
  <example>If you find B = 5 and A = 20, verify 20 = 4·5 and 20 – 5 = 15, confirming the solution.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Watch for units and context. Age problems often use years, so ensure all quantities are in the same unit before solving.</description>
  <example>If one age is given in months and another in years, convert both to years (or months) before forming equations.</example>
</note5>
Define variables for each stage of the process. Use a single variable to represent the initial quantity and express subsequent amounts in terms of that variable.

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply directly with totals. For example, “p% of T” becomes (p/100)×T.</description>
  <example>“30% of 500” is (30/100)×500 = 150.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity repeats over a period, multiply its monthly (or per-period) rate by the number of periods. If R is per period and there are n periods, total = R×n.</description>
  <example>If a group needs 20 items each month and you have 3 months, total = 20×3 = 60 items.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum individual contributions by adding their decimal or fractional values. This aggregates different needs into one total. Total = sum of all parts.</description>
  <example>Group A needs 0.2 of 1000, Group B needs 0.4 of 1000, and Group C needs 100. Total = 0.2×1000 + 0.4×1000 + 100 = 200 + 400 + 100 = 700.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to factor out common multipliers: a×(b + c) = a×b + a×c. This simplifies expressions with repeated factors.</description>
  <example>0.2×1000 + 0.4×1000 = (0.2 + 0.4)×1000 = 0.6×1000 = 600.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and time scales match. If rates are per month but the period is in months, multiply directly; if rates are per year but period is in months, convert first.</description>
  <example>If a rate is 50 items/month and you need 6 months, total = 50×6 = 300 items. If the rate were 120 items/year, convert to 120/12 = 10 items/month first.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a problem states “half of N,” compute N/2. This applies whenever you need to find one of two equal parts of a total.</description>
  <example>For a total of 20 items, half is 20/2 = 10 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a remaining quantity, multiply the remaining amount by the fraction. This is useful when some items are removed or already accounted for.</description>
  <example>From 10 remaining items, one-third of them is 10 × (1/3) = 10/3 ≈ 3.33 items.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>After allocating portions, the rest is the total minus the sum of allocated parts. This ensures all items are accounted for.</description>
  <example>If 10 items are split into 4 and 3, the remaining is 10 − (4 + 3) = 3 items.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the sum of all fractional parts equals the original total. This prevents over- or under-allocation.</description>
  <example>For 10 items split into 4, 3, and 3, 4 + 3 + 3 = 10, confirming no items are missing or extra.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>When dealing with mixed fractions, convert to improper fractions or decimals for easier arithmetic, then convert back to mixed form if needed.</description>
  <example>10/3 as a mixed number is 3 1/3, which can be used in further calculations.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate verbal relationships into algebraic expressions by assigning variables to each quantity and expressing each statement as an equation. This ensures clarity and consistency in modeling the problem.</description>
  <example>Let A, H, and Z represent the current ages of three people. If A is three times H, write A = 3·H. If H is half of Z, write H = ½·Z. These equations form the basis for further manipulation.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use substitution to reduce multiple equations to a single variable. Replace one variable in another equation with its expression to solve for the primary unknown.</description>
  <example>Given A = 3·H and H = ½·Z, substitute H into the first equation to get A = 3·(½·Z) = 1.5·Z. Now the problem is reduced to two variables, A and Z, linked by a single equation.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the average formula for future values: average = (sum of current values + sum of increments) / number of items. This accounts for each quantity’s growth over time.</description>
  <example>For three people, the average in three years is (A + H + Z + 3·A + 3·H + 3·Z) / 3 = (4A + 4H + 4Z) / 3. This directly incorporates the three-year increment for each person.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check consistency by verifying that all derived expressions satisfy the original relationships. This guards against algebraic or arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>After finding A = 1.5·Z and H = 0.5·Z, substitute back into A = 3·H to confirm 1.5·Z = 3·(0.5·Z). If both sides match, the solution is consistent.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check on the final result by estimating or plugging in simple values. This helps catch gross misinterpretations or miscalculations.</description>
  <example>Assume Z = 10, then H = 5 and A = 15. The average in three years is (15+5+10 + 3·15+3·5+3·10)/3 = (15+5+10+45+15+30)/3 = 120/3 = 40. This rough check aligns with the algebraic result.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When items have different weights, compute the total weight by summing each individual weight. This applies whenever you need the combined mass of multiple objects.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have three boxes weighing 10 kg, 15 kg, and 20 kg. The total weight is 10 + 15 + 20 = 45 kg.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Convert a per-unit cost into a per-weight cost by multiplying the unit cost by the weight per unit. This lets you price items based on their mass rather than count.</description>
  <example>If one kilogram of apples costs $2 and each apple weighs 0.2 kg, then the cost per apple is 2 × 0.2 = $0.40.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Use the unitary method: find the cost of one item, then multiply by the total number of items. This is a general approach for any linear pricing scenario.</description>
  <example>If one widget costs $5 and you have 12 widgets, the total cost is 5 × 12 = $60.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Apply the distributive property to simplify sums: a × (b + c + d) = a·b + a·c + a·d. This can make mental arithmetic or algebraic manipulation easier.</description>
  <example>To compute 0.50 × (56.5 + 46.5 + 26.5), first sum the weights: 56.5 + 46.5 + 26.5 = 129.5, then multiply: 0.50 × 129.5 = 64.75.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all weights are in the same unit before summing, and that the cost rate matches the weight unit. Mismatched units lead to errors.</description>
  <example>If weights are given in grams but the cost is per kilogram, convert grams to kilograms (divide by 1000) before multiplying by the cost rate.</example>
</note5>

Use the multiplication rule: to find a fraction of a quantity, multiply the fraction by the total.  
 Use the addition rule: to combine two quantities, add them directly.  
 Use the subtraction rule: to remove items, subtract the removed count from the original.  
 Use the unit conversion rule: convert between units (e.g., dozen to individual items) before combining.  
 Use the verification rule: recompute the final count by reversing steps to ensure consistency.

<note1>
    <description>Convert units by multiplying or dividing by the appropriate factor to express quantities in a single unit. This ensures consistency when comparing or combining different measurements.</description>
    <example>Convert 5 dozens of eggs into individual eggs by multiplying 5 × 12 = 60 eggs. Then convert 1.5 per 3 eggs into a per-egg rate by dividing 1.5 ÷ 3 = 0.5 per egg.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>Compute total cost by multiplying the unit cost by the total quantity. This gives the overall expense before any selling or profit calculations.</description>
    <example>If each dozen costs $2.40 and you buy 5 dozens, total cost = 5 × 2.40 = $12.00.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Compute total revenue by multiplying the unit selling price by the total quantity sold. This gives the overall income from sales.</description>
    <example>If you sell 60 eggs at $0.50 each, total revenue = 60 × 0.50 = $30.00.</example>
  </note5>
  <note6>
    <description>Calculate profit by subtracting total cost from total revenue. This yields the net gain or loss from the transaction.</description>
    <example>With total revenue of $30.00 and total cost of $12.00, profit = 30.00 – 12.00 = $18.00.</example>
  </note7>
  <note8>
    <description>Always verify unit consistency and perform a sanity check: ensure the selling price per unit is higher than the buying price per unit to confirm a profit.</description>
    <example>Check that the per-egg selling price (0.50) exceeds the per-egg buying price (2.40 ÷ 12 = 0.20) before finalizing the profit calculation.</example>
  </note9>

recursive_rel
<note1>
  <description>Model the spread as a recursive relation: let Iₙ be the number of infected on day n, then Iₙ₊₁ = Iₙ + (infection_rate × Iₙ × (total − Iₙ)). This captures new infections each day.</description>
  <example>With 100 total and rate 0.2, Iₙ₊₁ = Iₙ + 0.2·Iₙ·(100 − Iₙ). If Iₙ = 20, then Iₙ₊₁ = 20 + 0.2·20·80 = 20 + 320 = 340, but capped at 100.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the binomial expansion for small total populations: if each infected person infects k others, then after n days the total infected is ∑_{i=0}^n C(n, i)·(initial)^i·(1−initial)^(n−i)·k^i. This gives an exact count.</description>
  <example>For initial=1, k=2, n=3: total = C(3,0)·1^0·9^3·2^0 + C(3,1)·1^1·9^2·2^1 + C(3,2)·1^2·9^1·2^2 + C(3,3)·1^3·9^0·2^3 = 729 + 3·81·2 + 3·9·4 + 8 = 729 + 486 + 108 + 8 = 1331.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Apply the logistic growth approximation: Iₙ ≈ I₀·(1 + r)^n when r·I₀ ≪ 1. This simplifies the recursion to an exponential form, valid for small infection rates.</description>
  <example>If I₀=5 and r=0.1, then I₃ ≈ 5·(1.1)^3 ≈ 5·1.331 = 6.655, so about 7 infected after three days.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Watch for overcounting: when each infected person infects multiple others, ensure no one is counted twice. Use set operations or inclusion-exclusion if overlaps occur.</description>
  <example>If two infected people each infect the same three people, count those three only once, not twice, to avoid double counting.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Check boundary conditions: infections cannot exceed the total population. After each step, cap the result at the total to prevent negative or oversized counts.</description>
  <example>If Iₙ = 105 but total = 100, set Iₙ₊₁ = 100 to reflect that no more than 100 can be infected.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a ratio of two quantities is given as a:b, the total parts are a + b. To find each quantity, multiply the total by (a/(a + b)) and (b/(a + b)).</description>
  <example>For a ratio 2:5, total parts = 2 + 5 = 7. If the total is T, then the first quantity = (2/7)·T and the second = (5/7)·T.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity is described as a fraction of another, compute it by multiplying the base quantity by that fraction. This avoids misreading “half of” or “one-third of.”</description>
  <example>If the base is B and you need half of it, compute (1/2)·B. If you need one-third, compute (1/3)·B.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always check that the computed values satisfy the original ratio by dividing them and simplifying. This catches arithmetic or setup errors.</description>
  <example>After finding quantities X and Y, compute X/Y. If the ratio is 2:5, then X/Y should simplify to 2/5.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a problem involves multiple steps (e.g., finding one quantity then using it to find another), label intermediate results clearly to avoid confusion.</description>
  <example>First compute W = (1/2)·T. Then use W in the ratio formula to find P = (a/(a + b))·W.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of wordings like “half of” or “one-third of” that can be misinterpreted. Always rephrase in algebraic form (e.g., (1/2)·X) before proceeding.</description>
  <example>“Half of 90” is (1/2)·90 = 45, not 90/2 = 45, but if the wording is unclear, rephrase to avoid mistakes.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “half of” another, compute it by multiplying the total by 1/2. This applies whenever a fraction of a whole is involved.</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, half of them is T × 1/2. For instance, if T = 20, then half is 10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a part of a quantity based on an age or ratio, multiply the total by the fraction corresponding to that age or ratio. This works for any proportional relationship.</description>
  <example>If a person is A years old and you need A/5 of a total N, compute N × (A/5). For example, if N = 50 and A = 10, then 10/5 of 50 is 50 × (10/5) = 100.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When multiple parts are taken from the same total, sum them and subtract from the total to find the remainder. This ensures all parts are accounted for.</description>
  <example>From a total of T, if parts P₁ and P₂ are removed, the leftover is T − (P₁ + P₂). For instance, if T = 100, P₁ = 30, P₂ = 20, then leftover = 100 − (30 + 20) = 50.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all parts does not exceed the total. If it does, re-examine the fractions or ratios used. This prevents logical inconsistencies.</description>
  <example>If you compute P₁ = T × 0.4 and P₂ = T × 0.6, check that 0.4 + 0.6 = 1. If the sum is greater than 1, the parts cannot both be valid fractions of the total.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a variable for the total and express each part in terms of that variable. This clarifies relationships and simplifies algebraic manipulation.</description>
  <example>Let T be the total. If one part is k₁ of T and another is k₂ of T, write P₁ = k₁·T and P₂ = k₂·T. Then the remainder is T − (k₁·T + k₂·T) = (1 − k₁ − k₂)·T.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a problem states one quantity is a multiple of another, express it as “multiple × base.” This converts verbal relationships into algebraic form.</description>
  <example>“Micah’s distance is k times Amber’s.” If Amber runs d, then Micah runs k·d.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Sum all individual parts to form a linear equation: total = part₁ + part₂ + … + partₙ. This captures the overall relationship.</description>
  <example>“Total distance is T, Amber runs d, Micah runs k·d, and Ahito runs x.” Then T = d + k·d + x.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Isolate the unknown by moving known terms to the other side: x = T – (sum of known parts). This solves for the missing part directly.</description>
  <example>From T = d + k·d + x, subtract d + k·d to get x = T – d – k·d.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check units and consistency: ensure all distances are in the same unit before adding. Mismatched units lead to errors.</description>
  <example>If distances are given in miles and kilometers, convert all to miles (or kilometers) before summing.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by substitution: plug the found value back into the original equation to confirm it satisfies the total and all relationships.</description>
  <example>After finding x, check that d + k·d + x equals the given total T.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When adding or subtracting decimals, align the decimal points vertically and pad with zeros so each number has the same number of digits after the decimal. This ensures correct place-value addition or subtraction.</description>
  <example>To compute 12.3 + 4.56, rewrite as 12.30 + 4.56, then add column-wise: 0.30 + 0.56 = 0.86, 2 + 4 = 6, 1 + 0 = 1, yielding 16.86.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to multiply a sum by a constant: a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c. This simplifies multi-term multiplication into separate products.</description>
  <example>Compute 5·(3.2 + 1.8) by first multiplying 5·3.2 = 16 and 5·1.8 = 9, then adding to get 25.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When multiplying decimals, count the total number of decimal places in the factors and place the decimal in the product so that it has the same total. This avoids misplacement.</description>
  <example>For 2.5 × 0.4, there are two decimal places in total. Multiply 25 × 4 = 100, then place the decimal two places from the right to get 1.00.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check for rounding errors by estimating the result using rounded values. A rough check helps catch misplaced decimals or arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>To estimate 12.3 × 4.5, round to 12 × 5 = 60. If the exact result is 55.35, the estimate is close, indicating the calculation is likely correct.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>After performing decimal operations, verify by reversing the operation (e.g., divide the product by one factor to see if you recover the other factor). This confirms consistency.</description>
  <example>If you find 16.86 as the sum of two numbers, divide by one addend: 16.86 ÷ 12.3 ≈ 1.37, then add 1.37 to 12.3 to see if you get 13.67, confirming the original addition.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert daily consumption to weekly by multiplying by 7. This applies whenever you need a period’s total from a per-day rate.</description>
  <example>For a device using 5 kWh/day, weekly usage = 5 kWh/day × 7 days = 35 kWh/week.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying total consumption by unit price. This formula works for any rate-based expense.</description>
  <example>If a device uses 35 kWh/week and costs $0.20/kWh, then cost = 35 kWh × $0.20/kWh = $7.00/week.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Find the difference in costs by subtracting the original cost from the new cost. This isolates the impact of a change.</description>
  <example>Original cost = $7.00/week, new cost = $8.00/week; difference = $8.00 – $7.00 = $1.00/week.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions: a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c. This helps break down complex multiplications.</description>
  <example>For 7 days at 5 kWh/day plus 0.2 kWh/day, total = 7×5 + 7×0.2 = 35 + 1.4 = 36.4 kWh/week.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and perform a sanity check on the result. Ensure all quantities are in the same units before combining.</description>
  <example>Verify kWh/day × days/week = kWh/week, then multiply by cost/kWh to get cost/week. If the result seems too large or small, recheck unit alignment.</example>

Reverse the process by adding the total loss to the final weight.
  <note1>
    <description>When a quantity changes by a constant rate over time, the initial value equals the final value plus the total change. Use: initial = final + (rate × time).</description>
    <example>Suppose a tank loses 2 liters per hour for 5 hours and ends with 10 liters. The initial amount is 10 + (2 × 5) = 20 liters.</example>
  </note1>
  <note2>
    <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure the rate’s unit matches the time unit, and the final value is in the same unit as the rate’s effect.</description>
    <example>If a car’s speed is given in miles per hour but time is in minutes, convert minutes to hours before multiplying to avoid unit mismatches.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>Use a simple linear equation: let x be the unknown, write “x + (rate × time) = final,” then solve for x.</description>
    <example>For a deposit of P dollars that grows at 3% per year for 2 years to reach $100, set P + 0.03P·2 = 100 and solve for P.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Verify by plugging the found initial value back into the rate equation to ensure it yields the given final value.</description>
    <example>If you find an initial amount of 20 liters and a rate of 2 L/h for 5 h, compute 20 + (2 × 5) = 30 L; if this matches the stated final, the solution is correct.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>Be cautious of negative rates: a negative rate indicates a decrease, so the initial value will be larger than the final value.</description>
    <example>If a balance decreases by $50 per month for 4 months to reach $200, the initial balance is 200 + (–50 × 4) = 200 – 200 = 0.</example>
  </note5>

Define Variables: Assign symbols to each person’s age (e.g., J for Jean, M for Mark, K for Jan) to translate words into algebraic expressions.
Translate Phrases: Convert statements like “two years ago” or “half of” into algebraic terms (e.g., J – 2, M – 2, K/2).
Set Up Equations: Form linear equations from relationships (e.g., J = M + 2, M – 2 = (K/2) + 5).
Solve the System: Use substitution or elimination to find each variable.
Check Consistency: Verify each solution satisfies all original statements and any domain constraints (e.g., ages ≥ 0).

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any decimal or mixed number into an exact fraction to avoid rounding errors. Multiply the whole part by the denominator and add the numerator, then simplify.</description>
  <example>For “2.1 times ten,” write 2.1 = 21/10, then multiply by 10 to get 210/10 = 21. This ensures precise counting.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the complement principle: if a subset of size k is known, the rest is total minus k. This avoids recounting the remainder.</description>
  <example>Given total T and subset size k, the other items = T – k. For instance, if T = 21 and k = 7, the rest = 21 – 7 = 14.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the weighted sum formula: total contribution = (count₁ × value₁) + (count₂ × value₂). This generalizes to any number of categories.</description>
  <example>With 7 items of value 2 and 14 items of value 4, total = 7×2 + 14×4 = 14 + 56 = 70.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check consistency by verifying that counts sum to the total and that no category is double-counted. This guards against arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>Ensure 7 + 14 = 21 matches the total, and confirm each item’s category is assigned exactly once.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a variable for the total to generalize the solution. Express counts and sums in terms of T, then substitute the specific value at the end.</description>
  <example>Let T be the total. If k items have value v₁ and the rest have v₂, total = k·v₁ + (T – k)·v₂. Substitute T = 21, k = 7, v₁ = 2, v₂ = 4 to get 70.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert fractional parts of a whole into decimals or simplified fractions to simplify arithmetic. For example, “half of one hundred” becomes 0.5×100 or 50, and “4/5 of one hundred” becomes 0.8×100 or 80.</description>
  <example>Half of 200 is 0.5×200=100, and 3/4 of 200 is 0.75×200=150.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “twice as many” or “k more,” express it algebraically: if A has x, then B has 2x or x+k. This avoids manual counting and scales easily.</description>
  <example>If A has 30 items, then B has 2×30=60 items, and if C has 10 more than A, then C has 30+10=40 items.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to combine like terms: a·x + b·x = (a+b)·x. This consolidates sums of identical units into one term.</description>
  <example>For 50 silver and 80 gold, total = 50+80 = (1)·(50+80) = 130 units.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check units and types of quantities before adding. Mixing different categories (e.g., silver vs. gold) requires separate totals or clear labeling.</description>
  <example>If you have 50 silver and 80 gold, you cannot add them directly; instead, report “50 silver, 80 gold” or compute each category’s sum separately.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by reversing the steps or using an alternative method. For instance, subtract the computed total from the original sum to ensure consistency.</description>
  <example>If you found total = 130, check by adding each person’s share: 50+80+60+40 = 230, then confirm 230 matches the sum of all parts.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert all measurements to a single unit before performing arithmetic. Use standard prefixes (e.g., “thousand” = 1000, “hundred” = 100) to avoid unit mismatches.</description>
  <example>Convert 3.5 thousand units to base units: 3.5 × 1000 = 3500. Then convert 2 hundred units to base units: 2 × 100 = 200. Now both are in the same unit for addition or subtraction.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Compute total distance by multiplying the number of sessions by the distance per session. This gives the overall distance covered in one period.</description>
  <example>If you walk 4 times a day and cover 150 units each time, total daily distance = 4 × 150 = 600 units.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Find the remaining distance by subtracting the distance already covered from the total goal. This identifies how much more is needed.</description>
  <example>With a goal of 2000 units and 600 units already covered, remaining = 2000 − 600 = 1400 units.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Divide the remaining distance by the number of sessions to determine the required per-session distance. This ensures the goal is met in the given time frame.</description>
  <example>For 1400 units remaining over 4 sessions, each session must cover 1400 ÷ 4 = 350 units.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Check your result by recomputing total distance: (new per-session distance × sessions) + (previous per-session distance × sessions) = total goal. This verifies no arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>If new per-session is 350 and old is 150 over 4 sessions, total = (350 × 4) + (150 × 4) = 1400 + 600 = 2000 units, matching the goal.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute the perimeter of a rectangle by summing twice its length and twice its width: P = 2·(L + W). This gives the total linear distance around the shape.</description>
  <example>For a rectangle with length L and width W, calculate P = 2·(L + W). For instance, if L = 4 and W = 3, then P = 2·(4 + 3) = 14.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert any fractional or decimal measurement to a common unit before arithmetic. Multiply by the appropriate factor to eliminate decimals or fractions.</description>
  <example>If a length is 15.5 feet, multiply by 2 to convert to half-feet: 15.5·2 = 31 half-feet. This ensures consistent units when summing or multiplying.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the unit-rate method: if you need R items per unit length, multiply the total length by R. This scales the requirement directly.</description>
  <example>Given R = 2 slats per foot and a total length of 31 half-feet, compute total slats = 2·31 = 62. This applies to any rate per unit.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always round up when dealing with discrete items (e.g., slats) to ensure you have enough. Use the ceiling function: ceil(total_required).</description>
  <example>If the calculation yields 61.7 slats, apply ceil(61.7) = 62 to guarantee you have at least 62 slats for the fence.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by reversing the steps: divide the total items by the rate to recover the length, then check consistency with the original dimensions.</description>
  <example>Divide 62 slats by 2 slats per foot to get 31 half-feet, then convert back to feet: 31/2 = 15.5 feet, matching the original length.</example>
</note1>

Use Bayes’ Theorem: P(A|B)=P(B|A)·P(A)/P(B). It lets you invert conditional probabilities.
Use the Law of Total Probability: P(B)=P(B|A)·P(A)+P(B|¬A)·P(¬A). It computes P(B) by summing over all cases.
Convert percentages to decimals before multiplying. Forgetting this leads to off-by-one errors.
Check that P(A)+P(¬A)=1. If not, re-express one event in terms of the other.
Always verify that P(B|A) and P(B|¬A) are consistent with the given conditions.

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100, then multiply by the total to find a fractional part. This works because “percent” means “per hundred.”</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, to find p% of them, compute (p/100)×T. For instance, 25% of T is (25/100)×T = 0.25×T.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a subset of a subset is required, multiply the two fractions (or decimals) representing each selection. This is valid because each step scales the original quantity.</description>
  <example>If A is a fraction f of T, and B is a fraction g of A, then B = f×g×T. For example, if 0.3 of T are A, and 0.5 of A are B, then B = 0.3×0.5×T.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the complement rule: if a fraction f of items are selected, then the remaining fraction is 1–f. This helps find the size of the complement subset.</description>
  <example>From a total T, if 0.4 are selected, then 0.6 remain. Thus, the complement subset size is 0.6×T.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the final result is nonnegative and does not exceed the total. This guards against arithmetic mistakes or misinterpretation of fractions.</description>
  <example>After computing 0.2×T = 20, verify 20 ≥ 0 and 20 ≤ T. If T = 100, 20 is valid; if T = 15, 20 would be invalid and indicates a mistake.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>When dealing with multiple sequential selections, perform each multiplication in order. The order of multiplication does not affect the final product.</description>
  <example>To find 0.2 of 0.3 of T, compute (0.2×0.3)×T = 0.06×T. You can also compute 0.3×T first, then take 0.2 of that result.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When adding or subtracting decimal numbers, align the decimal points and add zeros to equalize the number of digits after the decimal. This ensures each place value is correctly combined.</description>
  <example>To add 12.3 and 4.56, rewrite 12.3 as 12.30. Then add: 12.30 + 4.56 = 16.86.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute a player’s new total by adding their score to their previous total. This is a straightforward application of addition in sequential scoring problems.</description>
  <example>If a player has 50 points and scores 15 points, their new total is 50 + 15 = 65 points.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Find the difference between two totals by subtracting the smaller from the larger. This gives the margin or lead in comparison problems.</description>
  <example>Player A has 70 points and Player B has 55 points; the difference is 70 – 55 = 15 points.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the commutative and associative properties of addition to reorder or group terms for easier mental calculation. This can simplify multi-step sums.</description>
  <example>To add 12 + 8 + 7, group as (12 + 8) + 7 = 20 + 7 = 27, rather than 12 + (8 + 7) = 12 + 15 = 27.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify your result by performing the inverse operation (e.g., subtract the added amount from the new total to see if you return to the original). This helps catch arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>If you added 10 to 30 to get 40, check by subtracting: 40 – 10 = 30, confirming the addition was correct.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Sum all individual counts to get the total. This is the first step in any average or total-count problem.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have counts a, b, c, d. Compute S = a + b + c + d to find the overall total.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert percentages or fractions into decimal form before arithmetic. This ensures consistency when adding or multiplying.</description>
  <example>“1/5 of one hundred” becomes 0.20 × 100 = 20, and “1.2 times one hundred” becomes 1.20 × 100 = 120.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the average formula: average = total sum ÷ number of items. This gives the mean value across all observations.</description>
  <example>With total S and n days, compute A = S ÷ n to find the average count per day.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for zero or missing data by treating them as zero in the sum. Omitting zeros can skew the average.</description>
  <example>If on one day the count is zero, include 0 in the sum S; otherwise, the average would be higher than it should be.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify the result by multiplying the computed average by the number of items. The product should match the original total.</description>
  <example>After finding A, compute A × n. If it equals S, the average calculation is correct.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “a certain amount less than the sum of two other quantities,” compute the sum first, then subtract the specified amount. This ensures you correctly model the relationship before any further operations.</description>
  <example>Suppose two segments have lengths A and B, and a third segment is C less than A + B. Compute S = A + B, then the third segment is S – C.</example>
</note2>
  <description>When a problem involves multiple trips or cycles, multiply the total distance of one cycle by the number of cycles to get the overall distance. This linear scaling is valid whenever each cycle is identical.</description>
  <example>If one round trip covers D miles and you make N identical round trips, the total distance is N × D.</example>
</note3>
  <description>To find how many identical cycles fit into a larger total distance, divide the total distance by the cycle distance. This gives the count of full cycles before any remainder.</description>
  <example>Given a total distance T and a cycle distance C, the number of full cycles is T ÷ C (integer division).</example>
</note4>
  <description>When a service or maintenance interval is given, divide the total distance by that interval to determine how many intervals occur. This directly yields the number of service events.</description>
  <example>If a vehicle travels T miles and requires service every I miles, the number of service events is T ÷ I.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Always check for integer division and remainder when counting discrete events. If the remainder exceeds zero, it indicates an additional event beyond the full cycles.</description>
  <example>Dividing T by I yields Q full intervals and R miles left. If R ≥ I, then Q + 1 service events are needed.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert mixed units to a single unit by multiplying the fractional part by the total count. For example, “3/10 of ten dozen” becomes (3/10)×(10×12) eggs.</description>
  <example>Compute 2/5 of 15 items: (2/5)×15 = 6 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert a decimal multiplier to a fraction to simplify arithmetic. For instance, 0.4 = 2/5, so “0.4 times ten” becomes (2/5)×10.</description>
  <example>Find 0.4 of 20: rewrite 0.4 as 2/5, then (2/5)×20 = 8.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When distributing a total quantity equally among n recipients, divide the total by n. Ensure the result is an integer if whole items are required.</description>
  <example>Divide 12 items among 4 people: 12 ÷ 4 = 3 items per person.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check divisibility by ensuring the numerator of the fraction times the total is divisible by the denominator. This prevents fractional recipients.</description>
  <example>With 12 items and 4 recipients, 12 ÷ 4 = 3 is integer, so each gets 3; if 13 items, 13 ÷ 4 = 3.25, which is not integer.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use cross-multiplication to verify that a fraction equals a decimal. For a/b = d, check a = b×d to confirm consistency.</description>
  <example>Verify 3/5 = 0.6: compute 5×0.6 = 3, matching the numerator, so the fraction and decimal are equivalent.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as a fraction or percentage of another, convert it to a decimal or fraction and multiply. This applies whenever a problem states “a times b” or “p% of b.”</description>
  <example>Suppose a segment is 0.4 of another segment of length L. Compute its length as 0.4 × L. If L = 100, the segment is 0.4 × 100 = 40.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Sum a constant rate over a number of days by multiplying the daily rate by the number of days. This is useful for uniform daily travel or production rates.</description>
  <example>If a machine produces 20 units per day for 5 days, total production is 20 × 5 = 100 units.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When some days have zero or missing data, include zero in the sum. Omitting zero days can lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>Over 7 days, if you travel 100 km on 5 days and 0 km on 2 days, total is 100 + 0 + 0 = 100 km, not 100 + 0 = 100 km.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Break a multi-stage problem into sequential steps: compute each stage’s total separately, then combine. This prevents mixing up different phases.</description>
  <example>Stage 1: 3 days at 50 km/day gives 150 km. Stage 2: 2 days at 30 km/day gives 60 km. Total = 150 + 60 = 210 km.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all computed segments equals the final total. This check catches arithmetic or conceptual errors.</description>
  <example>If you compute segments of 120, 80, and 0 km, sum = 200 km. If the problem states total should be 200 km, the solution is consistent.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a multiple of another, express it as a variable times a constant. For example, if A is k times B, write A = k·B. This simplifies relationships and avoids ad-hoc reasoning.</description>
  <example>Suppose X is three times Y. Represent X = 3·Y. If Y = 5, then X = 3·5 = 15, directly giving the relationship without extra steps.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a total, multiply the total by the fraction. For instance, to get 1/4 of N, compute (1/4)·N. This applies to any fraction of any quantity.</description>
  <example>Let N = 20. To find 1/4 of N, calculate (1/4)·20 = 5. This method works for any fraction f of any total T: f·T.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a second action is described as a multiple of a first action, express it as a variable times the first result. If action B is m times action A, write B = m·A. This keeps the chain of operations clear.</description>
  <example>First, A = 10. Then B is twice A, so B = 2·10 = 20. If later A changes, you can immediately update B by recalculating m·A.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>After removing or giving away parts, subtract those parts from the original total. If you remove R from T, the remainder is T – R. This is the standard subtraction for “leftover” problems.</description>
  <example>Start with T = 30. If you remove R = 8, the remainder is 30 – 8 = 22. This applies regardless of the initial total or removed amount.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify that all given conditions are satisfied by plugging your final expression back into the original relationships. This check catches algebraic or arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding X = 12 and Y = 4, check if X is twice Y: 12 = 2·4? Yes. Then check any fraction or multiple conditions to ensure consistency.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Convert all quantities into a single unit before combining them. This ensures consistency when adding or comparing different types of items.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 1.6 times ten test tubes and 7/10 of ten beakers. First compute 1.6×10=16 test tubes and 7/10×10=7 beakers, then add them to get 23 items.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Translate verbal phrases into algebraic expressions. Phrases like “half as many” become multiplication by 1/2, and “two more than” become addition of 2.</description>
  <example>If Igor was supposed to gather 16 test tubes but only got half as many, write that as (1/2)×16=8 test tubes. If he had two more than the requested number of Petri dishes (14), write 14+2=16.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Set up an equation for the total number of items. Sum the actual counts of each type and equate it to the given total.</description>
  <example>Let x be the number of beakers lost. The actual counts are 8 test tubes, 16 beakers, and 14 Petri dishes. The total is 8+16+(14−x). If the total is 2.9×10=29, write 8+16+(14−x)=29.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Solve the resulting linear equation for the unknown. Combine like terms and isolate the variable.</description>
  <example>From 8+16+(14−x)=29, combine constants: 38−x=29. Then solve x=38−29=9.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Check your solution by substituting back into the original conditions. Ensure all counts and totals match the problem’s wording.</description>
  <example>With x=9, actual beakers=14−9=5. Total=8+16+5=29, which matches 2.9×10. Also, test that 8 is half of 16 and 16 is two more than 14.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert mixed numbers to improper fractions by multiplying the whole number by the denominator and adding the numerator, then place the result over the original denominator. This simplifies arithmetic operations.</description>
  <example>Convert 2 3/4 to an improper fraction: (2×4 + 3)/4 = 11/4.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When multiplying a fraction by a whole number, rewrite the whole number as a fraction over 1 and multiply numerators and denominators. This avoids confusion with mixed numbers.</description>
  <example>Compute (3/5) × 7 by writing 7 as 7/1, then (3×7)/(5×1) = 21/5.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to break a multiplication into simpler parts: a×(b + c) = a×b + a×c. This can make mental or written calculations easier.</description>
  <example>Compute 4×(6 + 2) by doing 4×6 + 4×2 = 24 + 8 = 32.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>After multiplying fractions, simplify the result by dividing numerator and denominator by their greatest common divisor (GCD). This yields the fraction in lowest terms.</description>
  <example>Simplify 14/21 by dividing both by 7, giving 2/3.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and context: ensure the final answer’s units match the problem’s requirements (e.g., minutes, pages, distance). This prevents misinterpretation.</description>
  <example>If a rate is given in pages per minute, multiplying by minutes should yield pages, not minutes.</example>

Work with rates: convert time per task into tasks per unit time by taking the reciprocal.
 Use the formula: number of tasks = rate × time.
 Compare totals by subtracting the two results to find the difference.
 Always check that units (time and rate) are consistent before multiplying.
 Remember that a higher rate means more tasks completed in the same time.
Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100. For example, 0.47% becomes 0.0047, and 0.52% becomes 0.0052. This step ensures all values are in the same unit before further calculations.

1. <note1>
  <description>When two quantities are in a ratio a:b, assign them as a·x and b·x. This converts a ratio into a linear model with a single variable x.</description>
  <example>For a ratio 3:5, let the pieces be 3x and 5x. If their sum is 16, then 3x+5x=16 gives 8x=16, so x=2 and the pieces are 6 and 10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate “one piece is k times the other” into the equation L = k·S. This directly relates the two lengths without extra steps.</description>
  <example>If a longer segment is 4 times a shorter one, write L = 4S. Then any further condition (e.g. sum) can be applied to L and S.</example>
</note3>
3. <description>Use the total length constraint to form a linear equation: a·x + b·x = T, where a and b are ratio parts, x is the common factor, and T is the total. Solve for x.</description>
  <example>With ratio 2:3 and total 50, write 2x+3x=50, so 5x=50 and x=10. The pieces are 20 and 30.</example>
</note4>
4. <description>After finding x, compute each piece by multiplying x by its ratio part. Always verify by checking the sum or other given condition.</description>
  <example>From x=10 in 2:3 ratio, pieces are 2·10=20 and 3·10=30. Check 20+30=50 to confirm correctness.</example>
</note5>
5. <description>Watch for sign or scale errors: ensure the ratio multiplier is positive and that the total length is nonnegative. A negative x indicates an invalid setup.</description>
  <example>If you get x=−5 from 2x+3x=50, discard it since lengths cannot be negative. Re-examine the ratio or total for consistency.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any mixed number into an improper fraction by multiplying the whole number by the denominator and adding the numerator. This makes arithmetic operations straightforward.</description>
  <example>For a mixed number a b/c, compute (a·c + b)/c. For instance, 2 3/4 becomes (2·4 + 3)/4 = 11/4.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When dividing a fraction by a whole number, multiply the fraction by the reciprocal of that whole number. This transforms the division into a multiplication problem.</description>
  <example>To compute (p/q) ÷ n, rewrite it as (p/q) × (1/n). For example, (11/4) ÷ 3 = (11/4) × (1/3) = 11/12.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always simplify the resulting fraction by dividing numerator and denominator by their greatest common divisor (GCD). This yields the fraction in lowest terms.</description>
  <example>Given 11/12, check GCD(11,12)=1, so the fraction is already in simplest form. If you had 14/21, GCD(14,21)=7, so 14/21 simplifies to 2/3.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Verify your result by multiplying the quotient by the original divisor. The product should equal the original fraction or mixed number.</description>
  <example>After finding 11/12 as the share, multiply by 3: (11/12) × 3 = 33/12 = 2 9/12 = 2 3/4, which matches the original 2 3/4 split.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
