  <description>Check for integer or whole-number results before finalizing. If the simplified quotient is an integer, ensure it makes sense in context (e.g., no remainder when splitting equally).</description>
  <example>If you divide 15/5, you get 3, which is an integer. Confirm that 3 is a valid share in the scenario, ensuring no leftover amount.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When quantities scale by a factor k, the total cost scales by k if unit price remains constant. Use Total₁ = k·Total₂ when unit price is the same.</description>
  <example>Suppose you buy 5 widgets at $10 each, so cost = 5·10 = 50. If you then buy 3 times as many (15 widgets) at the same price, total cost = 3·50 = 150.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When unit price scales by a factor m, the total cost scales by m if quantity remains constant. Use Total₁ = m·Total₂ when quantity is the same.</description>
  <example>With 5 widgets at $10 each, cost = 50. If each widget now costs 2 times as much (20 each), then total cost = 2·50 = 100 for the same 5 widgets.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine scaling factors for both quantity and unit price: Total₂ = (k·quantity)·(m·unit_price) = k·m·(quantity·unit_price). This gives a direct multiplier k·m.</description>
  <example>Starting with 5 widgets at $10 each (50), if you buy 3 times as many (k=3) and each costs 2 times as much (m=2), then new total = 3·2·50 = 300.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the unit price formula: unit_price = total_cost / quantity. This lets you find one unknown when the other two are known.</description>
  <example>If 5 widgets cost 50, then unit_price = 50/5 = 10. If you later buy 10 widgets at the same price, total cost = 10·10 = 100.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check consistency: if you scale quantity by k and price by m, the new total should equal k·m times the original total. This guards against arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>Original cost = 50. Scaling quantity by 3 and price by 2 gives new cost = 3·2·50 = 300. Verify by computing 3·5 widgets at 2·10 each = 15·20 = 300.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Identify the total number of identical items needed by multiplying the count per person by the number of people. This gives the total quantity before any per-item resource requirements.</description>
  <example>For 3 people each needing 1 item, total items = 3 × 1 = 3.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Convert any per-item resource requirement into a single unit (e.g., per person) by dividing by the number of people if the requirement is per group. This ensures consistency when summing across individuals.</description>
  <example>If each person needs 4 units of resource and there are 3 people, per-person resource = 4 ÷ 3 ≈ 1.333.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Sum the per-item resource requirements for all items to get the total resource needed per person. This step aggregates all individual needs into one total.</description>
  <example>For items requiring 2, 5, and 3 units respectively, total per person = 2 + 5 + 3 = 10 units.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Compute the overall total resource by multiplying the per-person total by the number of people. This yields the grand total before any rounding or adjustments.</description>
  <example>With 10 units per person and 3 people, total = 10 × 3 = 30 units.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Apply any rounding or adjustment rules (e.g., round up to the nearest whole unit) to ensure you have enough resources. Always check that the final amount meets or exceeds the exact requirement.</description>
  <example>If the computed total is 30.7 units and you must buy whole units, round up to 31 units.</example>
</note5>

Define variables for each person’s score and translate the “4.5 times of ten points” into a total equation. Use the given differences to form linear equations. Solve the system by substitution or elimination. Check that the solution satisfies all original conditions.

1. <note1>
  <description>When a stack of paper is printed on both sides, each sheet contributes two pages. Thus, the total number of pages equals twice the number of sheets.</description>
  <example>For a stack of 5 sheets, each printed on both sides, the total pages = 2 × 5 = 10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert thickness measurements by using the given ratio: if 1/10 of a unit corresponds to a certain number of pages, then 1 unit corresponds to 10 times that number.</description>
  <example>If 1/10 of a unit is 20 pages, then 1 unit is 20 × 10 = 200 pages.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute the number of sheets from thickness by dividing the total thickness by the thickness per sheet (derived from the ratio).</description>
  <example>If each sheet is 0.05 units thick and the book is 1.5 units thick, then sheets = 1.5 ÷ 0.05 = 30.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Account for double-sided printing by multiplying the sheet count by 2 to get the total pages.</description>
  <example>With 30 sheets and double-sided printing, total pages = 30 × 2 = 60.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure thickness units match the ratio’s units before performing division or multiplication.</description>
  <example>If the ratio is pages per 1/10 of a unit, convert the book’s thickness to the same unit before applying the ratio.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert verbal phrases into algebraic expressions by identifying key words: “times” means multiplication, “sum” means addition, “difference” means subtraction, and “twice” means multiplying by 2. This ensures you translate the problem’s language into a solvable equation.</description>
  <example>“A number is three times another” becomes x = 3·y. “The sum of two numbers is 10” becomes x + y = 10. “Twice a number” becomes 2·x.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use age relationships to form equations: if A is k times B’s age, write A = k·B; if A is m years older than B, write A = B + m. These linear relations capture the problem’s age constraints.</description>
  <example>“Person X is 4 times as old as Y” gives X = 4·Y. “Person Z is 5 years older than W” gives Z = W + 5.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a person’s age is given relative to a past event, express their current age as (event age) + (time elapsed). This handles “when someone was” or “at the time of” statements.</description>
  <example>If “Person P was 20 when Q was born,” and Q is now 10, then P’s current age is 20 + 10 = 30.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>For future ages, add the number of years to the current age: future age = current age + years. This is essential when the problem asks “in n years” or “after m years.”</description>
  <example>If someone is currently 15, then in 7 years they will be 15 + 7 = 22.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check your solution by substituting back into the original relationships. This verifies that all verbal conditions are satisfied and catches algebraic mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding ages A, B, and C, plug them into A = k·B and A + B = total to ensure both equations hold true.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute a percentage of a total by multiplying the total by the percentage in decimal form. This applies whenever you need a portion of a whole.</description>
  <example>Given a total T and a percentage p, the portion is T × (p/100). For instance, if T = 1000 and p = 25%, the portion is 1000 × 0.25 = 250.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a problem involves multiple sequential percentage operations, apply each percentage step in order. Do not assume the result of one step is the new total for the next.</description>
  <example>Start with T = 1000. First take 30%: 1000 × 0.30 = 300. Then take 20% of the remaining: (1000 − 300) × 0.20 = 700 × 0.20 = 140. The final result is 140, not 1000 × 0.30 × 0.20.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the complement rule: if you need the remaining amount after removing a percentage p, compute 100% − p and multiply by the original total. This simplifies one-step “remaining” calculations.</description>
  <example>For T = 1000 and p = 40%, the remaining is 1000 × (1 − 0.40) = 1000 × 0.60 = 600.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that your final result is nonnegative and does not exceed the original total. This guards against arithmetic or sign errors in percentage calculations.</description>
  <example>If you compute a leftover of 1000 × 0.15 = 150, verify 150 ≥ 0 and 150 ≤ 1000. If you instead get −50, re-examine your steps.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>When a percentage is applied to a result of a previous operation, treat that result as the new total. This ensures each percentage step is correctly contextualized.</description>
  <example>Start with T = 1000. First remove 20%: 1000 × 0.80 = 800. Then apply 10% of the remaining: 800 × 0.10 = 80. The final leftover is 80.</example>
</note5>
Define variables for each unknown quantity and assign them clear names. This helps organize relationships and prevents confusion.

1. <note1>
  <description>When one rate is a fixed amount less than another, subtract that fixed amount from the higher rate to find the lower rate. This works because rate differences are additive in linear contexts.</description>
  <example>Worker A picks R quarts/hour, Worker B picks R minus D quarts/hour. Then B’s rate = R – D. For instance, if A picks 10 quarts/hour and D = 3, B picks 7 quarts/hour.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a rate that is a multiple of another, multiply the base rate by the given factor. This applies whenever one quantity scales linearly with another.</description>
  <example>Worker C picks M times the rate of Worker B. If B’s rate is R, then C’s rate = M × R. For example, if B picks 7 quarts/hour and M = 2, C picks 14 quarts/hour.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a rate is reduced by a fixed amount, subtract that amount from the original rate. This is a direct subtraction in linear rate problems.</description>
  <example>Worker D picks R minus F quarts/hour. If R = 14 and F = 2.5, then D’s rate = 11.5 quarts/hour. Always ensure the units match.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Sum individual rates to get the total rate. In rate problems, rates add because they represent independent contributions.</description>
  <example>Given rates R₁, R₂, R₃, R₄, the total rate = R₁ + R₂ + R₃ + R₄. For instance, if they are 10, 7, 14, and 11.5 quarts/hour, the total is 42.5 quarts/hour.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that all rates use the same time unit before summing. Mismatched units lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one rate is in quarts/hour and another in quarts/minute, convert them to the same unit (e.g., minutes) before adding. For example, 10 quarts/hour = 10/60 quarts/minute.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert periodic costs to a common time unit by multiplying by the number of periods in that unit. For example, if a cost is given per week, multiply by the number of weeks in a month (or year) to get the monthly (or yearly) cost.</description>
  <example>Suppose an item costs $C per week and there are W weeks in a month. Then the monthly cost is C × W. If W = 4, and C = 10, the monthly cost is 10 × 4 = 40.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When costs are given in different units, convert all to the same unit before summing. Use the appropriate conversion factor (e.g., weeks to months, days to hours) to align units.</description>
  <example>Cost A is $A per week and cost B is $B per month. If there are W weeks in a month, convert A to monthly by A × W, then add to B: (A × W) + B.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum all individual monthly costs to get the total monthly expense. This linear aggregation works for any number of recurring costs.</description>
  <example>If you have three monthly costs C₁, C₂, and C₃, the total monthly cost is C₁ + C₂ + C₃. For instance, if C₁ = 50, C₂ = 30, C₃ = 20, the total is 50 + 30 + 20 = 100.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Scale the total monthly cost to a longer period by multiplying by the number of months in that period. For annual totals, multiply by 12.</description>
  <example>If the monthly total is M, then the yearly total is M × 12. For example, if M = 100, the annual cost is 100 × 12 = 1200.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use unit consistency checks: ensure all costs are in the same unit before summing, and verify that the final answer’s unit matches the requested time frame (e.g., dollars per year).</description>
  <example>After converting all costs to dollars per month, sum them to get dollars per month. Then multiply by 12 to get dollars per year. If you forget to multiply by 12, you’ll get the wrong annual figure.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>When a total quantity is scaled by a factor, multiply the original count by that factor to get the new total. This applies whenever you have a base amount and a multiplier.</description>
  <example>Suppose you start with 10 items and the problem states you have 1.2 times that amount. Compute 10 × 1.2 = 12 to find the new total.</example>
</note2>
  <description>When a portion of a total is selected, multiply the total by the fraction to find the count of that portion. This works for any fraction of a whole.</description>
  <example>If you have 12 items and 3/10 of them are chosen, compute 12 × (3/10) = 3.6, then round or interpret as needed to get the number of selected items.</example>
</note3>
  <description>After removing items, subtract the removed count from the original portion to find the remaining count. This is used to update quantities after taking or giving away items.</description>
  <example>From 3 shaken items, if 1 is taken, compute 3 − 1 = 2 to find the remaining shaken items.</example>
</note4>
  <description>Compute the probability of an event by dividing the number of favorable outcomes by the total number of possible outcomes. This gives a fraction representing the chance of the event.</description>
  <example>If there are 2 favorable shaken items out of 12 total items, the probability is 2/12, which simplifies to 1/6.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Convert a probability fraction to a percentage by multiplying by 100. This expresses the probability in a more intuitive scale of 0% to 100%.</description>
  <example>Given a probability of 1/6, compute (1/6) × 100 ≈ 16.67% to express it as a percentage.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert mixed numbers to improper fractions by multiplying the whole number by the denominator and adding the numerator, then place the result over the original denominator. This simplifies multiplication and division of mixed quantities.</description>
  <example>Convert 2 3/4 to an improper fraction: (2×4 + 3)/4 = 11/4. Now 11/4 × 5/6 = (11×5)/(4×6) = 55/24.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When multiplying fractions, multiply numerators together and denominators together, then simplify by canceling common factors. This reduces arithmetic complexity and yields the simplest form.</description>
  <example>Compute (3/7) × (14/9): (3×14)/(7×9) = 42/63. Cancel 21: 42/63 = 2/3.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to break a complex multiplication into simpler parts: a×(b + c) = a×b + a×c. This is especially useful when one factor is a sum or when you can compute partial products more easily.</description>
  <example>Compute 12×(5 + 7) by distributing: 12×5 + 12×7 = 60 + 84 = 144.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When adding or subtracting fractions, first convert them to a common denominator, then add or subtract numerators. Always simplify the result to its lowest terms.</description>
  <example>Compute 2/3 + 1/4: common denominator 12 gives (2×4)/(3×4) + (1×3)/(4×3) = 8/12 + 3/12 = 11/12.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>For percentage problems, convert the percentage to a decimal or fraction and multiply by the total. To find a percentage of a quantity, use (percent/100)×total.</description>
  <example>Find 25% of 80: 25/100 × 80 = 0.25 × 80 = 20.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all monetary values to the same unit before computing per-unit cost. Use the conversion factor (e.g. 1 dollar = 100 cents) to avoid unit mismatches.</description>
  <example>Suppose an item costs $X and you want its cost in cents. Multiply X by 100 to get the cost in cents. For instance, if X = 2.50, then 2.50 × 100 = 250 cents.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply discounts by subtracting the discount amount from the original price. This gives the sale price before any further per-unit calculations.</description>
  <example>If an item originally costs P and there is a discount of D, then the sale price is P − D. For example, if P = 18.50 and D = 3.50, then the sale price is 18.50 − 3.50 = 15.00.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute the per-unit cost by dividing the total cost by the number of units. This yields the cost per individual item.</description>
  <example>Given a total cost of C and N units, the cost per unit is C ÷ N. For instance, if C = 15.00 and N = 30, then each unit costs 15.00 ÷ 30 = 0.50.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the unitary method: first find the cost for one unit, then scale up or down as needed. This approach simplifies multi-step problems.</description>
  <example>Start with total cost T and total units N. Compute unit cost = T ÷ N. If you need the cost for M units, multiply unit cost by M. For example, if T = 15.00, N = 30, and M = 15, then unit cost = 0.50 and cost for 15 units = 0.50 × 15 = 7.50.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that your final answer is in the required unit. If the problem asks for cents, ensure you convert from dollars or vice versa.</description>
  <example>After finding a cost in dollars, multiply by 100 to convert to cents. For example, if the cost per unit is 0.50 dollars, then 0.50 × 100 = 50 cents.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100, then multiply by the total count to get the exact number of items. This works because “p% of N” equals (p/100)×N.</description>
  <example>To find 25% of 200 items, compute 0.25×200=50 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the unit-rate method: multiply the number of items by the number of units per item to get total units. This applies whenever each item contributes a fixed number of units.</description>
  <example>If each of 50 cars needs 4 wheels, then total wheels = 50×4=200 wheels.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When combining multiple types of items, sum their individual totals to get the grand total. This is valid because totals are additive.</description>
  <example>For 50 cars (200 wheels) and 30 motorcycles (60 wheels), total wheels = 200+60=260 wheels.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Compute leftover units by subtracting the total used from the available supply. This gives the remainder after consumption.</description>
  <example>With 260 wheels used and 250 wheels available, leftover = 250−260=−10 (indicating shortage).</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that all quantities are in the same unit system before adding or subtracting. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If you have 100 wheels and 50 units of another measure, convert both to wheels or both to units before combining.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a problem states “half of N,” compute N/2. This applies to any fraction of a total quantity.</description>
  <example>For a total of 20 items, half is 20/2 = 10 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the ratio “A is k times B” to write A = k·B. This converts comparative statements into algebraic equations.</description>
  <example>If one group has twice as many items as another, set A = 2·B.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When “A is half of B,” write A = B/2. This is the inverse of the “k times” rule and is useful for reciprocal comparisons.</description>
  <example>If one group has half as many items as another, set A = B/2.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Translate “total combined” into an equation: Total = A + B + C + … . Sum all individual quantities to find the overall total.</description>
  <example>For groups A, B, and C with counts a, b, c, the total is a + b + c.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check consistency: substitute your expressions back into the original ratio or fraction statements to ensure no contradictions.</description>
  <example>After finding A = 2·B and A = B/2, verify that both cannot hold simultaneously by checking the values.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any average or rate into a total by multiplying the average by the number of periods or units. This is useful when you need the actual sum before comparing or further operations.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a class has an average score of 85 over 5 tests, the total score is 85 × 5 = 425.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When one quantity is a fraction of another, multiply the base quantity by that fraction to find the smaller quantity. This directly gives the comparative value without extra steps.</description>
  <example>If a factory produces 200 units per day and a competitor produces 3/5 of that, the competitor’s daily output is 200 × (3/5) = 120 units.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>To find how much one quantity exceeds another, subtract the smaller from the larger. This difference indicates the gap between the two values.</description>
  <example>Given two lengths of 150 cm and 90 cm, the difference is 150 – 90 = 60 cm.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always simplify fractions before performing arithmetic to reduce errors and make calculations clearer. Simplification can turn complex fractions into more manageable forms.</description>
  <example>Before multiplying 12/18 by 9, simplify 12/18 to 2/3, then compute (2/3) × 9 = 6.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>After computing a difference or ratio, verify by reversing the steps or using an alternative method. This check helps catch mistakes in multiplication, subtraction, or fraction manipulation.</description>
  <example>If you found a difference of 20 between two values, add that difference back to the smaller value to see if you recover the larger one.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate percentage or fraction statements into multiplication by the given factor. For “p% more than A,” compute A + p%·A = A·(1 + p/100). For “q times A,” compute A·q.</description>
  <example>“A quantity is 25% more than X.” Compute X + 0.25·X = 1.25·X. “A quantity is twice Y.” Compute 2·Y.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Handle “one hundred more” by adding 100 to the base quantity. This is a simple additive adjustment when the problem states “one hundred more than A.”</description>
  <example>“B is one hundred more than A.” Compute B = A + 100. If A = 50, then B = 150.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute a fraction of a quantity by multiplying by the fraction. For “r times A,” use A·r. For “half of A,” use A·(1/2). For “one-third of A,” use A·(1/3), etc.</description>
  <example>“C is half of A.” Compute C = A·(1/2). If A = 80, then C = 40. “D is one-third of A.” Compute D = A·(1/3).</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Sum multiple quantities by adding them directly. Ensure all quantities are in the same unit before summing. This is the fundamental step in “total” or “sum” problems.</description>
  <example>Given quantities P, Q, and R, compute total = P + Q + R. If P = 10, Q = 20, R = 30, then total = 60.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that each computed value matches the problem’s wording. Ensure no misinterpretation of “more than,” “times,” or “fraction” statements.</description>
  <example>After computing B = 1.25·A and C = A·(1/2), re-read the problem to confirm “0.12 times of one hundred more than A” was correctly interpreted as 1.25·A, not 0.12·(A+100).</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “more than” another, translate it into addition. If A is B more than C, then A = C + B. This handles all “more than” or “less than” statements in word problems.</description>
  <example>Suppose one segment is 3 units longer than another segment of length x. Then the first segment’s length is x + 3.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “twice” another, translate it into multiplication. If D is twice E, then D = 2·E. This applies to any “double,” “half,” or “k times” statements.</description>
  <example>If a second segment is twice the length of the first segment of length y, then its length is 2·y.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine like terms by adding or subtracting variables and constants. When you have expressions like (x + a) + (x + b), simplify to 2x + (a + b). This reduces complexity before solving.</description>
  <example>Given two segments of lengths x + 2 and x + 5, their combined length is (x + 2) + (x + 5) = 2x + 7.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Set up an equation by equating the expression for one quantity to the expression for another. If M is described as equal to N, write M = N. This creates a solvable equation.</description>
  <example>If the total length of two segments (2x + 7) is said to equal a third segment (3x – 1), write 2x + 7 = 3x – 1.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Solve the resulting linear equation by isolating the variable. Use inverse operations: add or subtract to move constants, then divide or multiply to solve for the variable. Always check for extraneous solutions.</description>
  <example>From 2x + 7 = 3x – 1, subtract 2x to get 7 = x – 1, then add 1 to get x = 8.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>When two workers have different speeds, express each speed as a fraction of a common unit (e.g., units per hour). This allows direct comparison and combination of their outputs.</description>
  <example>Worker A completes 3 units/hour, Worker B completes 2 units/hour. Represent A’s speed as 3/1 and B’s as 2/1 to compare and combine their rates.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>If one worker’s output is a fraction of another’s, set up a ratio to find the unknown fraction. Use the relation “Worker A = k × Worker B” to solve for k or the other worker’s output.</description>
  <example>Worker A processes twice as many units as Worker B. If B processes 5 units, then A processes 2 × 5 = 10 units.</example>
</note3>
  <note3>
  <description>When tasks are distributed over multiple days, multiply the daily output by the number of days to get the total. This applies to any repetitive schedule.</description>
  <example>If a worker processes 8 units per day and works 5 days, total units = 8 × 5 = 40.</example>
</note4>
  <note4>
  <description>For combined output, add individual rates (or outputs) to get the total rate. Then multiply by the total time to find the total output.</description>
  <example>Worker A: 4 units/hour, Worker B: 6 units/hour. Combined rate = 4 + 6 = 10 units/hour. Over 3 hours, total = 10 × 3 = 30 units.</example>
</note5>
  <note6>
  <description>Always check that units are consistent before adding or multiplying. Convert all rates to the same time or quantity unit before combining.</description>
  <example>One worker’s rate is 5 units/hour, another’s is 3 units/minute. Convert 3 units/minute to 18 units/hour (3 × 60) before adding to 5 units/hour.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all monetary values to the same unit (e.g., cents) before performing arithmetic to avoid decimal misalignment. This ensures consistency in addition, subtraction, and multiplication.</description>
  <example>Convert $12.50 to 1250 cents and $300.50 to 30050 cents. Then compute 1250 × d + 1250 = 30050 without worrying about decimal points.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Model the total savings as a linear equation: initial_amount + (daily_rate × days) = target. This captures the relationship between the starting balance, daily earnings, and the goal.</description>
  <example>Let d be days. Then 1250 + 1250·d = 30050. This equation directly represents the problem’s savings scenario.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Isolate the variable by subtracting the initial amount from both sides and then dividing by the daily rate. This yields the number of days required to reach the target.</description>
  <example>From 1250 + 1250·d = 30050, subtract 1250 to get 1250·d = 28800, then divide by 1250 to find d = 28800 ÷ 1250.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for integer solutions when counting days. If the result is not an integer, interpret it as either a partial day (if allowed) or round up to the next whole day.</description>
  <example>If d = 28800 ÷ 1250 = 23.04, and partial days are acceptable, use 23.04. If only whole days count, round up to 24 days.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify the solution by substituting back into the original equation. This confirms that the computed days indeed meet or exceed the target amount.</description>
  <example>Compute 1250 + 1250·24 = 1250 + 30000 = 31250 cents, which exceeds 30050 cents, confirming the solution is correct.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “half of ten,” “one-fifth of ten,” or “0.4 times ten,” convert it to a fraction or decimal of the base unit (10) before multiplying. This ensures consistency in unit handling.</description>
  <example>“One-fifth of ten” means (1/5)×10 = 2 units. If you then multiply by a rate, use 2 directly instead of 10.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>For a fixed monthly purchase over a period of n months, multiply the monthly amount by n. This applies to any constant rate over a continuous time span.</description>
  <example>If you buy 3 items each month for 6 months, total = 3×6 = 18 items.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>When a rate changes mid-period, split the period into segments and compute each segment separately. Sum the results to get the total.</description>
  <example>If you buy 2 items/month for 4 months then 5 items/month for 3 months, total = (2×4) + (5×3) = 8 + 15 = 23 items.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>When adding or subtracting quantities with different units, convert all to a common unit before combining. This prevents unit mismatches in totals.</description>
  <example>If you have 5 units of type A and 3 units of type B, and you need a total in type A, convert 3B to A (e.g., 3B = 1.5A) then add: 5 + 1.5 = 6.5A.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>After computing totals, perform a sanity check by estimating or using a simpler model. This helps catch arithmetic or unit errors.</description>
  <example>If you expect to buy around 10 items per year for 3 years, estimate 10×3 = 30. If your detailed calculation is far from 30, recheck your steps.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any fractional or decimal quantity into a single unit (e.g. “one hundred” or “one”) to simplify comparisons and arithmetic. Multiply or divide by the unit’s value to work with whole numbers.</description>
  <example>Suppose a shelf holds 1/10 of one hundred items. Convert to items by computing (1/10)×100=10 items. Then compare this to other shelf capacities in the same unit.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use multiplication and division to express relationships like “twice as many” or “5 fewer.” If A holds x items, then B holds 2x or x–5 items, respectively. This lets you write all capacities in terms of a single variable.</description>
  <example>Given a middle shelf holds x items, the bottom shelf holds 2x items, and the top shelf holds (2x)–5 items. You can then sum these expressions to find total capacity per bookcase.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum the capacities of all shelves in one bookcase to get the total capacity per unit. This is the total capacity you’ll divide into when distributing items.</description>
  <example>If a bookcase has shelves holding x, 2x, and (2x)–5 items, then total capacity = x + 2x + (2x–5) = 5x–5 items per bookcase.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Compute the total number of items by converting any fractional or decimal total into the same unit. Multiply the unit value by the given factor to get a whole number count.</description>
  <example>If you have 1.1 times one hundred items, convert to items by computing 1.1×100=110 items. This is the total you’ll distribute across bookcases.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Divide the total items by the capacity per bookcase to find the number of bookcases needed. If the result is not an integer, round up to ensure all items fit.</description>
  <example>With 110 items and capacity 5x–5 per bookcase, compute 110 ÷ (5x–5). If x=10, capacity=45, so 110÷45≈2.44, so you need 3 bookcases.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>Identify repeating patterns in pricing: when items alternate between two prices, group them into fixed-size blocks to simplify total cost calculation.</description>
  <example>For 10 items with prices P and Q alternating, group into 5 pairs. Compute cost per pair as P + Q, then multiply by 5.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the arithmetic series formula for evenly spaced terms: sum = n/2 × (first term + last term), where n is the number of terms.</description>
  <example>To sum prices P, 0.6P, P, 0.6P, … over 8 terms, treat as an arithmetic series with first term P, last term 0.6P, and n=8, then apply the formula.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute the average price per item: average = (total cost)/(total number of items). This gives a quick estimate of the overall cost.</description>
  <example>If 12 items cost $100 in total, the average price is $100/12 ≈ $8.33 per item.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Apply the unitary method: find the cost of one item, then multiply by the total quantity to get the overall cost.</description>
  <example>If one item costs $4.5, then 20 items cost 20 × $4.5 = $90.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check for off-by-one errors: when grouping items into blocks, ensure the last block may be partial and adjust its cost accordingly.</description>
  <example>For 11 items grouped into 5 full pairs and 1 extra, compute 5 × (P + 0.6P) plus the cost of the single item P.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert any fractional or decimal quantity into a single unit by multiplying by the appropriate factor. For example, to convert “0.5 dozen” into individual items, multiply 0.5 by 12.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 0.75 dozen cookies. Multiply 0.75 by 12 to get 9 cookies.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When combining or subtracting quantities given in different units, first convert all to a common unit. This ensures accurate addition or subtraction.</description>
  <example>You have 2 dozen apples and 18 apples. Convert 2 dozen to 24 apples, then add: 24 + 18 = 42 apples.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions like “a dozen + b dozen.” Factor out the dozen: (a + b) dozen = (a + b) × 12.</description>
  <example>Compute 3 dozen + 4 dozen by writing (3 + 4) dozen = 7 dozen, then multiply by 12 to get 84 items.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Track net change by subtracting consumed or removed quantities from the total. Net = initial + received – used.</description>
  <example>Start with 50 items, receive 15 more, then use 20. Net = 50 + 15 – 20 = 45 items remaining.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always perform a sanity check: verify that the final count is reasonable given the initial and received amounts. If it’s negative or too large, re-examine conversions and arithmetic.</description>
  <example>If you start with 100 items, receive 50, and use 70, you expect 80 left. If you get 80, it’s correct; if you get 60, recheck your subtraction.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Translate word problems into algebraic expressions by assigning variables to unknown quantities and writing equations that represent relationships. This clarifies what you need to solve and sets up the correct framework.</description>
  <example>Suppose tickets cost p dollars for adults and q dollars for children, and you buy one of each. Let x be the total amount paid. Then x = p + q, which directly models the scenario.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>Use the change equation: total_given = total_cost + change_received. This relates the amount paid to the cost and any refund or leftover money.</description>
  <example>If the total cost of items is C and you receive R in change, then the amount you gave is C + R. For instance, if C = 15 and R = 2, then total_given = 17.</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by substituting your solution back into the original equations. This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic or setup errors.</description>
  <example>After finding total_given = 17, verify that 17 minus the cost (15) equals the change (2). If it does, the solution is consistent; if not, re-examine the setup.</example>
</note3>
  <note4>
  <description>Be mindful of unit consistency: ensure all monetary values are in the same unit (e.g., dollars) before adding or subtracting. Mixing units leads to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If one cost is given in cents and another in dollars, convert both to the same unit (e.g., cents) before summing. For instance, 10 dollars = 1000 cents, so 1000 + 50 = 1050 cents.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
  <description>When dealing with decimals, align decimal points and carry out addition/subtraction carefully. Misalignment can cause off-by-one errors in the final result.</description>
  <example>To add 12.5 and 10.0, write them as 12.5 + 10.0 = 22.5. Ensure both numbers have the same number of decimal places before performing the operation.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a fraction of a total to an actual count by multiplying the fraction by the total. This works because a fraction represents a part of the whole.</description>
  <example>For a total of T items and a fraction f, the count is f × T. For instance, if T = 100 and f = 1/10, then the count is (1/10) × 100 = 10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use unit rates to scale consumption or production over different time periods. A unit rate is the amount per one unit of time or quantity.</description>
  <example>If an item consumes R units per week, then per day it consumes R/7. For example, if R = 3.5 pounds per week, then per day it is 3.5/7 = 0.5 pounds.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the distributive property to multiply a sum by a scalar: a × (b + c) = a·b + a·c. This simplifies expressions when a fraction or decimal is multiplied by a sum.</description>
  <example>To compute (1/10) × (100 + 5), distribute: (1/10)×100 + (1/10)×5 = 10 + 0.5 = 10.5.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check consistency by verifying that the final unit matches the required unit. Ensure you convert between units (e.g., weeks to days) correctly before finalizing the answer.</description>
  <example>If you find 3.5 pounds per week but need per day, confirm you divide by 7 to get 0.5 pounds per day, not 3.5.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use estimation to catch arithmetic errors. Round numbers to simple values, perform a quick calculation, and compare to the exact result.</description>
  <example>Estimate (1/10)×100 ≈ 10 and 3.5/7 ≈ 0.5. If your exact result is 10.5, the estimate is close, indicating a likely correct answer.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>Convert percentage or fractional targets into absolute quantities by multiplying the base amount by the given factor. This ensures you work with actual numbers rather than percentages.</description>
  <example>For a target of 1.2 times 100 units, compute 1.2 × 100 = 120 units. For a target of 0.15 times 100 units, compute 0.15 × 100 = 15 units.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Handle partial days or days off by excluding them from the total count. Only include days or periods where sales occurred when summing totals.</description>
  <example>If sales are recorded only on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, sum sales on those three days. If Monday and Friday are closed, omit any sales data for those days.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Convert “half of” or “one-third of” statements into fractions by dividing the given quantity by the fraction’s denominator. This yields the exact portion sold.</description>
  <example>“Half of 40 crates” is 40 ÷ 2 = 20 crates. “One-third of 60 crates” is 60 ÷ 3 = 20 crates.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Compute the difference between a target and actual total by subtracting the sum of actual sales from the target. This gives the shortfall or excess.</description>
  <example>If the target is 120 units and actual sales sum to 100 units, the shortfall is 120 – 100 = 20 units.</example>

Define variables for each category (e.g., Q for queens, B for babies, W for workers).
Use the given ratios to form equations: W = r₁·B, B = r₂·Q, etc.
Substitute to express all variables in terms of one base variable (e.g., Q).
Multiply by the total count to get integer values for each category.
Check that all counts are integers and satisfy the original ratios.

1. <note1>
  <description>When items are bought in groups, multiply the number of groups by the number of items per group to get the total count. This applies whenever you have multiple sets of identical items.</description>
  <example>For instance, if you have 4 boxes and each box contains 5 pencils, the total number of pencils is 4 × 5 = 20.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the unit price to find the total cost by multiplying the total count by the cost per item. This works for any scenario where each item has the same price.</description>
  <example>If each book costs $12 and you buy 7 books, the total cost is 7 × 12 = $84.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When dealing with decimal prices, align decimal points and perform multiplication as with whole numbers, then place the decimal point in the product so that the total number of decimal places equals the sum of the multiplicands’ decimal places.</description>
  <example>Multiply 3.25 by 4: align decimals, compute 325 × 4 = 1300, then place the decimal so that there are two decimal places: 13.00.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check for rounding or precision issues by performing a quick estimate or by reversing the calculation (e.g., dividing the total by the unit price to see if you recover the original count).</description>
  <example>If you calculate a total cost of $123.45 for items priced at $12.35 each, divide 123.45 by 12.35 to confirm you get approximately 10 items.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Watch for hidden or extra costs (e.g., shipping, taxes) that aren’t included in the unit price. Ensure you account for all charges before finalizing the total.</description>
  <example>If each widget costs $5 but there’s a $2 shipping fee per order, and you buy 6 widgets, the total is (6 × 5) + 2 = $32.</example>
</note5>

Use the distributive property to combine like terms: a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c.  
 Convert all quantities to the same unit before multiplying or adding.  
 When a quantity is given as a fraction of another, multiply the fraction by the total.  
 Always check that units are consistent before performing arithmetic.

<note1>
    <description>When a quantity is described as a fraction of a total, convert it to a decimal or fraction before multiplying. This ensures accurate scaling of the part relative to the whole.</description>
    <example>Suppose you need 1/4 of 100 items. Convert 1/4 to 0.25 and compute 0.25 × 100 = 25 items.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>When distributing identical items among multiple recipients, multiply the number of recipients by the per-person amount. This gives the total needed for that group.</description>
    <example>If each of 5 people receives 3 items, then total = 5 × 3 = 15 items.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>When you have two or more groups with different per-person amounts, compute each group’s total separately and then sum them. This avoids mixing different rates in one calculation.</description>
    <example>Group A: 4 people × 2 items = 8 items; Group B: 6 people × 3 items = 18 items; Total = 8 + 18 = 26 items.</example>
  </note6>
  <note7>
    <description>Always check that the sum of all group totals equals the overall requirement. This verification step catches arithmetic or scaling errors.</description>
    <example>If you need 26 items in total and your computed groups sum to 26, the distribution is correct. If it differs, recheck each group’s calculation.</example>
  </note8>

Convert mixed units into a single unit (e.g. years to months) before performing arithmetic.
Use the difference of ages to find relative birth dates: subtract one person’s age from another’s to get the gap.
When a person reaches a certain age, add that age to their birth date to find the event date.
To find how many years ago an event occurred, subtract the event date from the current date.
Always check that units are consistent (e.g. both in years or both in months) before subtracting dates.

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the unit price to find the quantity sold: quantity = total revenue ÷ unit price. This works whenever you know how much you earned and the cost per item.</description>
  <example>Suppose an item sells for $p each and you earn $R. Then the number of items sold is R ÷ p. For instance, if p = 3 and R = 15, then items sold = 15 ÷ 3 = 5.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When items are sold in bundles, first find the number of bundles sold: bundles = bundle revenue ÷ bundle price. Then multiply by the bundle size to get individual items.</description>
  <example>If a bundle costs $B and you earn $R from bundles, then bundles sold = R ÷ B. If each bundle contains s items, total items = (R ÷ B) × s. For example, if B = 10, R = 50, and s = 4, then bundles = 50 ÷ 10 = 5, so items = 5 × 4 = 20.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine separate sales streams by summing their quantities: total = sum of individual quantities. This applies when you have multiple product types or time periods.</description>
  <example>Suppose you sell A items in one period and B items in another. Then total items = A + B. For instance, if A = 12 and B = 18, total = 12 + 18 = 30.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Scale a daily or per-period result to multiple days by multiplying by the number of periods: total = (per-period quantity) × number of periods. This is useful for multi-day or multi-session problems.</description>
  <example>If you sell Q items each day and there are d days, then total items = Q × d. For example, if Q = 7 and d = 4, then total = 7 × 4 = 28.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all prices and revenues use the same currency and that bundle sizes match the count of items. This prevents misapplication of formulas.</description>
  <example>If one revenue is in dollars and another in cents, convert them first. Also, verify that the bundle price covers exactly the listed number of items. For instance, if a bundle price is given for 5 items but you count 6, recheck the problem statement.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “k times” another, represent it as a multiplication: if A is k times B, then A = k·B. This converts verbal relationships into algebraic form.</description>
  <example>Suppose the number of red balls is 3 times the number of blue balls. If B = 5, then R = 3·5 = 15.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>For a total split into two parts, use the sum: if X and Y are disjoint groups, then total = X + Y. This ensures all elements are accounted for exactly once.</description>
  <example>If there are 8 apples in one basket and 12 in another, the total apples = 8 + 12 = 20.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a ratio or fraction is given, convert it to a multiplication factor: if A is p/q of B, then A = (p/q)·B. This handles fractional relationships directly.</description>
  <example>If the number of green marbles is 2/5 of the blue marbles, and B = 20, then G = (2/5)·20 = 8.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that all groups are mutually exclusive and collectively exhaustive. If any overlap or omission exists, adjust the model before summing.</description>
  <example>When counting students in clubs, ensure no student is counted in more than one club and that no student is left out.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>After forming equations, verify consistency by back-substituting values into original statements. This guards against algebraic or misinterpretation errors.</description>
  <example>Given R = 3·B and R + B = 20, if B = 4 then R = 12, and 12 + 4 = 16 ≠ 20, so the initial setup must be revisited.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert time units consistently by using the appropriate conversion factor (e.g., 1 day = 24 hours). This ensures all rates and durations are in the same unit before further calculations.</description>
  <example>Given a task takes 3 days, convert to hours by multiplying: 3 days × 24 hours/day = 72 hours.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute a single worker’s rate by dividing the fraction of work done by the time taken: rate = (fraction of job) ÷ (time in consistent units). This gives the work done per unit time.</description>
  <example>If one worker completes 0.4 of a job in 8 hours, the rate is 0.4 ÷ 8 = 0.05 job/hour.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the inverse relationship: time = (total work) ÷ (rate). This formula applies once you have the rate in consistent units.</description>
  <example>For a job of 1 unit and a rate of 0.05 job/hour, time = 1 ÷ 0.05 = 20 hours.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Scale the single-worker rate to multiple workers by multiplying by the number of workers: combined rate = (single rate) × (number of workers). This leverages the additive nature of identical tasks.</description>
  <example>With 4 workers each at 0.05 job/hour, combined rate = 0.05 × 4 = 0.2 job/hour.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the combined rate is positive and that the computed time is reasonable (e.g., less than or equal to the single-worker time if more workers are added). This guards against arithmetic or unit errors.</description>
  <example>If 2 workers at 0.05 job/hour each give 0.1 job/hour, time = 1 ÷ 0.1 = 10 hours, which is less than the single-worker 20 hours, confirming correctness.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any percentage or decimal to a fraction by dividing by 100 and simplifying. This makes multiplication and addition of parts more straightforward.</description>
  <example>For instance, 0.4 of a quantity is 0.4/1 = 4/10 = 2/5. Use this fraction to compute parts of a total.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a fraction of a total is given, multiply the fraction by the total to find the part. This applies to any “fraction of” or “percent of” scenario.</description>
  <example>If 2/5 of 10 items are selected, compute (2/5)×10 = 4 items. Always simplify before multiplying to avoid arithmetic errors.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum multiple parts by adding their values. Ensure all parts are expressed in the same unit before summing.</description>
  <example>Given parts of 4, 4, and 3, add them: 4 + 4 + 3 = 11. This gives the total of all selected items.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that the sum of all parts does not exceed the original total. This guards against overcounting or misinterpretation.</description>
  <example>If the total was 10 and the sum of parts is 11, re-examine each step. A valid total should match the original quantity.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a variable for the total to generalize the process. This helps in solving similar problems with different numbers.</description>
  <example>Let T be the total. If k items are taken, then the remaining is T – k. This approach scales to any total and part.</example>

<note1>
  <description>When one quantity is a constant multiple of another, set up the equation Q₁ = k·Q₂. This models “Q₁ is k times Q₂” and lets you solve for either variable.</description>
  <example>Suppose one container holds 3 times as much liquid as another. If the larger holds 12 units, then 12 = 3·Q₂, so Q₂ = 4 units.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “m times more than” another, interpret it as an addition: Q₁ = Q₂ + m·Q₂ = (1 + m)·Q₂. This avoids confusion with “k times as much.”</description>
  <example>If a box holds 5 times more apples than another, and the second holds 6 apples, then Q₁ = 6 + 5·6 = 36 apples.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into algebraic equations and solve step by step. First express each relationship, then isolate the unknown by dividing or subtracting as needed.</description>
  <example>Given A = 4·B and B = 2·C, substitute to get A = 4·(2·C) = 8·C. If A = 16, then C = 16/8 = 2.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all quantities use the same unit system and that the final answer matches the context (e.g., whole objects, decimal measurements).</description>
  <example>If a problem asks for the number of items, a fractional result like 3.5 indicates a misinterpretation; re-examine the model to ensure it counts discrete objects.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>After solving, verify by plugging the result back into the original relationships. This confirms no algebraic or interpretation errors occurred.</description>
  <example>If you find C = 2 and the model says B = 2·C, then B = 4. Substituting into A = 4·B gives A = 16, matching the given A.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>Convert percentage statements into decimal multipliers by dividing by 100. This lets you express “p% of a quantity” as (p/100)·quantity.</description>
  <example>“30% of the total” becomes 0.30·T, where T is the total. If T=200, then 0.30·200=60.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>Translate phrases like “k times of one hundred” into the expression k·100. This clarifies that the multiplier is k·100 rather than k.</description>
  <example>“2.4 times of one hundred” means 2.4·100=240. If that represents a subgroup, you use 240 in further calculations.</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>Set up a linear equation when a percentage of the total equals a known subgroup size. Use (p/100)·T = subgroup to solve for T.</description>
  <example>If 0.40·T = 240, then T = 240/0.40 = 600. This gives the total population before finding any other subgroup.</example>
</note3>
  <note4>
  <description>Use the complement principle to find the remaining subgroup: total minus the known subgroup. This is especially useful for “the rest” or “the other” categories.</description>
  <example>With total T=600 and subgroup=240, the other subgroup is 600−240=360. This avoids re-deriving the total each time.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
  <description>Always check your result by plugging it back into the original percentage statement. This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>Verify 0.40·600=240 matches the given subgroup. If it does, the solution is consistent; if not, re-examine the setup.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate verbal relationships into algebraic expressions by assigning variables to each unknown and writing equations for each statement. This converts word problems into solvable mathematical form.</description>
  <example>“A is k years older than B” becomes A = B + k. “C is m years younger than A” becomes C = A – m. These equations form the basis for solving the system.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use substitution to reduce a system of equations: solve one equation for one variable and substitute into the others. This simplifies the system to fewer variables.</description>
  <example>From A = B + k, substitute into C = A – m to get C = (B + k) – m. Then you have two equations in B and C, which can be solved together.</example>
</note3>
3. <note4>
  <description>Apply the sum or total condition to form a linear equation: if the sum of all variables equals a known total, write ∑ variables = total. This often yields the final equation to solve.</description>
  <example>Given A + B + C = T, substitute the expressions for A and C in terms of B to get (B + k) + B + ((B + k) – m) = T, which simplifies to a single equation in B.</example>
</note4>
4. <note5>
  <description>Check for consistency and integer solutions: after solving, verify that all variables satisfy original relationships and that any fractional or non-integer results make sense in context (e.g., ages must be whole numbers).</description>
  <example>If solving yields B = 2.5, check that A = B + k and C = A – m are also valid ages. If not, re-examine the setup for misinterpretation.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
    <description>When a quantity is described as “more than” or “less than” another, translate it into an addition or subtraction. Use the form: new = original ± difference.</description>
    <example>“A is 7 units more than B” becomes A = B + 7. “C is 4 units less than D” becomes C = D – 4.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>Chain multiple relationships by substituting one expression into another. This reduces the problem to a single variable or a simple expression.</description>
    <example>Given A = B + 7 and C = A + 4, substitute A into C: C = (B + 7) + 4 = B + 11.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>Always check for consistency by back-substituting your final expression into the original relationships. This ensures no arithmetic or sign errors.</description>
    <example>If you find C = B + 11, verify that C – 4 = B + 7, which matches the original A = B + 7.</example>
  </note6>
  <note7>
    <description>Use estimation or rounding to verify the plausibility of your result. If the computed value is far from the expected range, re-examine your steps.</description>
    <example>If B ≈ 10, then C ≈ 10 + 11 = 21, and C – 4 ≈ 17, which should match B + 7 ≈ 17, confirming the result.</example>
  </note8>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a percentage savings into a decimal multiplier by dividing the percentage by 100. This gives the fraction of the original cost that remains after the discount.</description>
  <example>For a 20% discount, compute 20/100 = 0.2. The remaining cost is 0.2 times the original price.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the multiplier to the original cost to find the discounted cost: discounted = original × (1 – discount_fraction). This directly yields the cost after the savings.</description>
  <example>With a 0.2 discount on an original price of P, the discounted cost is P × (1 – 0.2) = 0.8P.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>When the problem states “savings of d” on a cost C, the actual cost is C – d. This is useful when savings are given in absolute or relative terms.</description>
  <example>If the original cost is C and savings are d, then the final cost is C – d. For instance, if C = 100 and d = 20, the cost is 80.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that the discounted cost does not exceed the original cost. A valid discount must leave a positive remaining cost.</description>
  <example>After computing 0.8P, ensure 0.8P > 0. If the result is non-positive, re-examine the discount fraction or original cost.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use the complement principle: if a discount is d, then the cost is (1 – d) times the original. This avoids separate subtraction steps and reduces errors.</description>
  <example>For a 0.2 discount, compute 1 – 0.2 = 0.8, then multiply by the original price to get the final cost.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a purchase is made in installments, divide the total cost by the number of installments to find the monthly payment. This works because the total cost is evenly spread over the payment period.</description>
  <example>For a total cost of C, if payments are made over n months, each monthly payment is C/n. For instance, if C = 1000 and n = 4, each payment is 1000/4 = 250.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute simple interest on a principal P at rate r per period using I = P × r. This gives the interest accrued in one period without compounding.</description>
  <example>If P = 500 and r = 0.03, then interest for one period is 500 × 0.03 = 15. Over two periods, total interest is 15 × 2 = 30.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>For multiple identical items, multiply the unit cost by the number of items to get the total cost before any interest or fees. This ensures you account for all units correctly.</description>
  <example>If each item costs c and you buy n items, total cost is c × n. For example, if c = 200 and n = 5, total cost is 200 × 5 = 1000.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>When interest is charged on each installment, add the interest to the principal for each period to get the total amount due. This ensures you account for interest on the principal each time.</description>
  <example>For a principal P and rate r, first period total = P + P×r. If P = 300 and r = 0.02, first period total = 300 + 300×0.02 = 306.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the interest rate and time period match (e.g., monthly rate for monthly payments). Mismatched units can lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If a rate of 0.02 is given per month, applying it to a 3-month period gives 0.02×3 = 0.06 total rate. If the rate were given per year, you’d need to convert it first.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When two quantities are in a constant ratio, express one in terms of the other using a scaling factor k. If A = k·B, then B = A/k. This lets you convert between related measures without extra steps.</description>
  <example>Suppose one runner’s speed is twice another’s. If the faster runner covers distance D, the slower covers D/2. For instance, if D = 10, the slower covers 5.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the fundamental relation distance = speed × time to link any two of these variables. Rearranging gives speed = distance/time or time = distance/speed, enabling you to compute unknowns when two are known.</description>
  <example>If a cyclist travels 20 km at 5 km/h, time = 20/5 = 4 h. Conversely, if time is 2 h and speed is 10 km/h, distance = 10 × 2 = 20 km.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a problem gives a ratio of distances or speeds, set up a proportion and solve for the unknown. For distances in ratio m:n, if one is D, the other is (n/m)·D. This avoids separate equations.</description>
  <example>Two runners cover distances in a 3:4 ratio. If the first runs 12 km, the second runs (4/3)×12 = 16 km.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure speed is in distance/time units, distance in length units, and time in time units. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If speed is given as 60 miles/hour but time is in minutes, convert minutes to hours (e.g., 30 min = 0.5 h) before computing distance = 60 × 0.5 = 30 miles.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>After finding a time or distance, verify by plugging back into the original relation. This catches algebraic or unit errors and ensures the solution fits the problem’s context.</description>
  <example>If you find a runner takes 8 h at 5 km/h, check distance = 5 × 8 = 40 km. If the problem states the distance is 40 km, the solution is consistent.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a total is given, compute it by multiplying the fraction by the total. This applies whenever you need a portion of a whole quantity.</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, if 3/10 of them leave, the number that leave is (3/10)·T.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a previously computed quantity, multiply that quantity by the new fraction. This is useful when a second event depends on the result of the first.</description>
  <example>If 3/10 of T leave, then 1/2 of that number returns, so the return count is (1/2)·[(3/10)·T].</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>When a new event is described as “k times” a previous event, multiply the previous count by k. This handles direct proportional relationships.</description>
  <example>If 3/10 of T leave, and twice that many leave again, the second departure is 2·[(3/10)·T].</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>To find how many items remain after some leave, subtract the total that left from the original total. This gives the residual count.</description>
  <example>From T items, if (3/10)·T leave, then the remaining count is T – (3/10)·T = (7/10)·T.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>When all items that left but haven’t returned return, use the residual count from the previous step. This ensures no item is double-counted.</description>
  <example>If (7/10)·T remain after departures, then all those that left but haven’t returned return, so the return count is (7/10)·T.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When items have different unit prices, compute each subtotal by multiplying the quantity of each item by its unit price, then sum all subtotals to get the total cost.</description>
  <example>For 3 widgets at $4 each and 2 gadgets at $6 each, subtotal = 3×4 + 2×6 = 12 + 12 = 24.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify sums of products: a·x + a·y = a·(x + y). This can reduce arithmetic steps when multiple items share the same unit price.</description>
  <example>Instead of 5×3 + 5×7, compute 5×(3 + 7) = 5×10 = 50.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always check for decimal alignment when multiplying decimals: count total decimal places in factors and place the decimal in the product accordingly.</description>
  <example>For 2.5 × 0.4, there are two decimal places total, so 2.5×0.4 = 1.00 (or 1).</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Verify your result by reversing the calculation: divide the total cost by the sum of quantities to see if you recover the average unit price.</description>
  <example>If total cost is 24 for 5 items, then 24 ÷ 5 = 4.8, confirming the unit price was $4.80.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Watch for rounding errors when dealing with decimals: carry enough precision in intermediate steps and round only at the final step to maintain accuracy.</description>
  <example>Compute 1.234 × 5.6789 = 7.0000002, then round to 7.0000002 if needed, rather than rounding 1.234 to 1.23 first.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity increases by a fraction f, multiply the original amount by (1 + f). This directly accounts for the proportional increase.</description>
  <example>Original: 100 units; increase: 1/4. New = 100 × (1 + 1/4) = 125 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity decreases by a fraction f, multiply the original amount by (1 – f). This directly accounts for the proportional decrease.</description>
  <example>Original: 100 units; decrease: 1/5. New = 100 × (1 – 1/5) = 80 units.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always convert percentages to decimals or fractions before multiplying. A p% increase is p/100, and a p% decrease is –p/100.</description>
  <example>Original: 200 units; increase: 25%. New = 200 × (1 + 0.25) = 250 units.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check that the result is reasonable by comparing it to the original. An increase should be larger, a decrease smaller, and the sign of the multiplier indicates direction.</description>
  <example>Original: 150 units; increase: 1/3. New = 200 units; since 200 > 150, the result is consistent.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use unit analysis: ensure the multiplier has no units, so the result’s units match the original. This helps catch mistakes in setup.</description>
  <example>Original: 50 items; increase factor: 0.2. New = 50 × 0.2 = 10 items; both sides are in “items,” so the calculation is valid.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply directly to find fractional amounts.</description>
  <example>“20% of X” becomes 0.20·X. For instance, 20% of 500 is 0.20·500 = 100.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the unit-rate method: find how many units cover one unit of need, then multiply by the total need. This avoids piecemeal percentage calculations.</description>
  <example>If one bottle covers 0.20 of a person’s daily need, then one person’s need is 1/0.20 = 5 bottles. For 100 people, you need 5·100 = 500 bottles.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When scaling by a factor k, multiply the original quantity by k. This applies to both production capacity and demand.</description>
  <example>If the current capacity is C bottles and you need to scale up by 3, the new capacity is 3·C. If C = 1000, then 3·1000 = 3000.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Compute the difference between a target and an existing quantity by subtraction. This gives the additional amount needed.</description>
  <example>If you need T units and you have H units, the shortfall is T – H. For T = 1200 and H = 800, the difference is 1200 – 800 = 400.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all quantities use the same unit system before adding or subtracting. This prevents mismatches.</description>
  <example>If one rate is in “bottles per person” and another in “bottles per 100 people,” convert one to match the other before combining. For instance, 5 bottles/person × 100 people = 500 bottles.</example>

first note
<note1>
  <description>Convert a percentage increase to a multiplier by dividing the percentage by 100 and adding 1. This gives the factor by which the original quantity is scaled. Use this whenever a problem states “X% of Y” or “increased by X%.”</description>
  <example>Suppose a quantity is increased by 25%. The multiplier is (25/100)+1 = 1.25. If the original quantity is Q, the new quantity is Q×1.25.</example>
</note1>
Define variables for each type of animal (e.g. s for sheep, g for geese) and translate each condition into a linear equation.

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is increased by a fraction f, multiply the original by (1 + f). This converts a “times more” statement into a simple multiplication.</description>
  <example>Original distance = D, increase by f = 1/4. New distance = D × (1 + 1/4) = 5/4 D.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity is decreased by a fraction f, multiply the original by (1 – f). This handles “times less” or “percent off” statements.</description>
  <example>Original distance = D, decrease by f = 1/3. New distance = D × (1 – 1/3) = 2/3 D.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>For a fixed daily amount D over n days, the total is D × n. This applies to any uniform daily rate.</description>
  <example>Daily run = D, days = n. Total = D × n.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>When the number of days varies by month, use the known number of days in each month. For example, June has 30 days.</description>
  <example>Days in June = 30. If daily run = D, total = D × 30.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all distances and time periods use the same unit system before multiplying or summing.</description>
  <example>If D is in meters and n is in days, verify that the result is in meters over days, then convert if needed.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate “half as many as” into multiplication by ½. When a quantity is described as “half as many as” another, represent it as (½)·(that quantity).</description>
  <example>For instance, if A has 20 units and B has half as many, then B = ½·20 = 10 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate “more than” into addition. If one quantity is described as “k more than” another, add k to that quantity.</description>
  <example>For example, if C has 15 units and D has 3 more than C, then D = 15 + 3 = 18 units.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine expressions by substitution. Replace the variable in one expression with the result of the other to form a single expression.</description>
  <example>Given X = ½·Y and Z = X + k, substitute to get Z = ½·Y + k, then simplify.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify combined expressions. For expressions like a·(b + c), rewrite as a·b + a·c to make further operations easier.</description>
  <example>For example, ½·(Y + k) becomes ½·Y + ½·k, which can then be added to other terms.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by estimating or plugging in simple values. This helps catch arithmetic or logical errors before finalizing the answer.</description>
  <example>Suppose Y = 20 and k = 5; then Z = ½·20 + 5 = 10 + 5 = 15. If the result seems too small or too large, re-examine the setup.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Use the complement rule: the probability of an event not occurring is 1 minus the probability it does occur. This is useful when you know the chance of a “no” scenario and need the chance of “yes.”</description>
  <example>Suppose there is a 0.3 chance of rain. The chance it does not rain is 1 – 0.3 = 0.7.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply the multiplication rule for independent events: the probability both A and B happen is P(A) × P(B). This lets you combine sequential or independent scenarios.</description>
  <example>If the chance of a coin landing heads is 0.5 and the chance of rolling a six on a die is 1/6, then the chance of both is 0.5 × 1/6 = 1/12.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Use the law of total probability: if events B₁, B₂, …, Bₖ partition the sample space, then P(A) = Σ P(A|Bᵢ)·P(Bᵢ). This handles scenarios with multiple mutually exclusive cases.</description>
  <example>With two possible teachers, T₁ and T₂, and P(T₁)=0.6, P(T₂)=0.4, if P(homework collected|T₁)=0.8 and P(homework collected|T₂)=0.7, then P(homework collected)=0.6·0.8 + 0.4·0.7 = 0.48 + 0.28 = 0.76.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Model sequential decisions as a decision tree: list each stage’s outcomes and their probabilities, then multiply along branches and sum across branches to get the overall probability.</description>
  <example>For two stages, first a coin flip (H or T), then a die roll (1–6), you draw a tree with two branches for the coin, then six for the die. Multiply probabilities along each path and sum to get the total chance of a specific outcome.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Check for independence: if two events are not independent, use conditional probability P(A|B) instead of P(A)·P(B). Misusing the multiplication rule for dependent events leads to errors.</description>
  <example>If the chance of passing a test depends on whether you studied (P(pass|studied)=0.9, P(pass|no study)=0.2), and you know you studied with probability 0.7, then P(pass)=0.7·0.9 + 0.3·0.2 = 0.63 + 0.06 = 0.69.</example>
